This network included areas known to be involved in social perception and social cognition, including the right posterior superior temporal sulcus and the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC)/dorso anterior cingulate cortex (dACC). Connectivity analyses with an mPFC/dACC seed revealed coactivation with the left insula and amygdala during arm touch. These findings characterize a network of brain regions beyond the insula involved in coding CT-targeted affective touch.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=22) investigating perception of CT-targeted affective (social) touch, a social-processing task involving affiliation/social interaction; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of affective/social touch (CT-targeted gentle brushing), a social-related task (affiliation/attachment; social perception). Sample: 22 healthy right-handed adults aged 19–35 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate random-effects GLM results (arm>baseline, palm>baseline, arm>palm) with voxelwise thresholds, FDR/cluster correction, and tables of peak coordinates and figures. A PPI connectivity analysis is included but the paper clearly presents univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: External motivation to avoid prejudice alters neural responses to targets varying in race and status.
studies.abstract: Those who are high in external motivation to respond without prejudice (EMS) tend to focus on non-racial attributes when describing others. This fMRI study examined the neural processing of race and an alternative yet stereotypically relevant attribute (viz., socioeconomic status: SES) as a function of the perceiver's EMS. Sixty-one White participants privately formed impressions of Black and White faces ascribed with high or low SES. Analyses focused on regions supporting race- and status-based reward/salience (NAcc), evaluation (VMPFC) and threat/relevance (amygdala). Consistent with previous findings from the literature on status-based evaluation, we observed greater neural responses to high-status (vs low-status) targets in all regions of interest when participants were relatively low in EMS. In contrast, we observed the opposite pattern when participants were relatively high in EMS. Notably, all effects were independent of target race. In summary, White perceivers' race-related motivations similarly altered their neural responses to the SES of Black and White targets. Specifically, the findings suggest that EMS may attenuate the positive value and/or salience of high status in a mixed-race context. Findings are discussed in the context of the stereotypic relationship between race and SES.
keywords: external motivation to respond without prejudice
studies.abstract_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study (N=61 healthy adult White participants) performing a social impression-formation task of faces varying by race and socioeconomic status, examining neural responses (NAcc, VMPFC, amygdala). It investigates social perception/processing and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (impression formation; perception and understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (N=60 males, mean age 23.8). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (exploratory whole-brain regressions with voxel-wise thresholds and reported significant clusters, e.g., VMPFC cluster), not only ROI results. It therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked group results). No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Cerebral correlates and statistical criteria of cross-modal face and voice integration.
studies.abstract: Perception of faces and voices plays a prominent role in human social interaction, making multisensory integration of cross-modal speech a topic of great interest in cognitive neuroscience. How to define potential sites of multisensory integration using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is currently under debate, with three statistical criteria frequently used (e.g., super-additive, max and mean criteria). In the present fMRI study, 20 participants were scanned in a block design under three stimulus conditions: dynamic unimodal face, unimodal voice and bimodal face-voice. Using this single dataset, we examine all these statistical criteria in an attempt to define loci of face-voice integration. While the super-additive and mean criteria essentially revealed regions in which one of the unimodal responses was a deactivation, the max criterion appeared stringent and only highlighted the left hippocampus as a potential site of face- voice integration. Psychophysiological interaction analysis showed that connectivity between occipital and temporal cortices increased during bimodal compared to unimodal conditions. We concluded that, when investigating multisensory integration with fMRI, all these criteria should be used in conjunction with manipulation of stimulus signal-to-noise ratio and/or cross-modal congruency.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining perception and integration of faces and voices—a social perception/communication task—performed in human participants (n=20). Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit statement of clinical populations or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult participants and age range.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study (block design) investigating cross-modal face and voice integration, a social-related perceptual process (social communication / perception of others). Sample: 20 participants (MeSH lists Adult and Young Adult), satisfying healthy adult group requirement. The abstract reports group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses using multiple statistical criteria (super-additive, max, mean) that identified brain regions (e.g., left hippocampus, occipital and temporal cortices), indicating whole-brain task-evoked results generalizable to the healthy group. Although the study also includes PPI, it reports whole-brain activation loci rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: How do we empathize with someone who is not like us? A functional magnetic resonance imaging study.
studies.abstract: Previous research on the neural underpinnings of empathy has been limited to affective situations experienced in a similar way by an observer and a target individual. In daily life we also interact with people whose responses to affective stimuli can be very different from our own. How do we understand the affective states of these individuals? We used functional magnetic resonance imaging to assess how participants empathize with the feelings of patients who reacted with no pain to surgical procedures but with pain to a soft touch. Empathy for pain of these patients activated the same areas (insula, medial/anterior cingulate cortex) as empathy for persons who responded to painful stimuli in the same way as the observer. Empathy in a situation that was aversive only for the observer but neutral for the patient recruited areas involved in self-other distinction (dorsomedial prefrontal cortex) and cognitive control (right inferior frontal cortex). In addition, effective connectivity between the latter and areas implicated in affective processing was enhanced. This suggests that inferring the affective state of someone who is not like us can rely upon the same neural structures as empathy for someone who is similar to us. When strong emotional response tendencies exist though, these tendencies have to be overcome by executive functions. Our results demonstrate that the fronto-cortical attention network is crucially involved in this process, corroborating that empathy is a flexible phenomenon which involves both automatic and controlled cognitive mechanisms. Our findings have important implications for the understanding and promotion of empathy, demonstrating that regulation of one's egocentric perspective is crucial for understanding others.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating empathy (perception/understanding of others), reporting neural activation during a social-related task in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages aren’t specified, the study clearly fits the review’s focus and likely used healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy, perspective-taking, self–other distinction) in healthy adults (n=23, ages 19–34). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Pain > No Pain: Similar, Pain > No Pain: Dissimilar, No Pain: Dissimilar > Similar) with voxelwise results, tables/figures, and cluster coordinates, not limited to ROIs. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, they are supplemental to whole-brain activation results. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical original research with task-based fMRI data. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, not restricted-age or non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: From agents to objects: sexist attitudes and neural responses to sexualized targets.
studies.abstract: Agency attribution is a hallmark of mind perception; thus, diminished attributions of agency may disrupt social-cognition processes typically elicited by human targets. The current studies examine the effect of perceivers' sexist attitudes on associations of agency with, and neural responses to, images of sexualized and clothed men and women. In Study 1, male (but not female) participants with higher hostile sexism scores more quickly associated sexualized women with first-person action verbs ("handle") and clothed women with third-person action verbs ("handles") than the inverse, as compared to their less sexist peers. In Study 2, hostile sexism correlated negatively with activation of regions associated with mental state attribution-medial prefrontal cortex, posterior cingulate, temporal poles-but only when viewing sexualized women. Heterosexual men best recognized images of sexualized female bodies (but not faces), as compared with other targets' bodies; however, neither face nor body recognition was related to hostile sexism, suggesting that the fMRI findings are not explained by more or less attention to sexualized female targets. Diminished mental state attribution is not unique to targets that people prefer to avoid, as in dehumanization of stigmatized people. The current studies demonstrate that appetitive social targets may elicit a similar response depending on perceivers' attitudes toward them.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study 2 reports fMRI activation while participants viewed sexualized and clothed human targets, addressing mental state attribution (a social cognition task) in healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21 heterosexual male undergraduates, mean age ~21). The task probes social cognition (passive viewing of sexualized vs. clothed male/female targets targeting mentalizing/agency). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (4×21 ANOVA, deviant-cell contrasts) with voxelwise threshold p < .001 and cluster correction (AlphaSim), and presents whole-brain activation results in tables/figures (including correlations between hostile sexism and voxelwise activity). It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical groups. Therefore it satisfies the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

studies.title: Valuating other people's emotional face expression: a combined functional magnetic resonance imaging and electroencephalography study.
studies.abstract: Reading the facial expression of other people is a fundamental skill for social interaction. Human facial expressions of emotions are readily recognized but may also evoke the same experiential emotional state in the observer. We used event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging and multi-channel electroencephalography to determine in 14 right-handed healthy volunteers (29+/-6 years) which brain structures mediate the perception of such a shared experiential emotional state. Statistical parametric mapping showed that an area in the dorsal medial frontal cortex was specifically activated during the perception of emotions that reflected the seen happy and sad emotional face expressions. This area mapped to the pre-supplementary motor area which plays a central role in control of behavior. Low resolution brain electromagnetic tomography-based analysis of the encephalographic data revealed that the activation was detected 100 ms after face presentation onset lasting until 740 ms. Our observation substantiates recently emerging evidence suggesting that the subjective perception of an experiential emotional state-empathy-is mediated by the involvement of the dorsal medial frontal cortex.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used event-related fMRI (with EEG) while healthy adult participants (mean age 29) viewed and perceived others' emotional facial expressions—directly addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others/empathy). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports fMRI (event-related) during a social-related task (perception of others' emotional facial expressions/empathy) in 14 healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29±6, within 17–65). Group-level whole-brain univariate analysis was performed using Statistical Parametric Mapping and identified dorsal medial frontal cortex activation tied to perception of emotions — satisfying the requirement for an unmasked, voxelwise healthy-group task effect generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and does not report only between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Abnormal GABAergic function and face processing in schizophrenia: A pharmacologic-fMRI study.
studies.abstract: The involvement of the gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) system in schizophrenia is suggested by postmortem studies and the common use of GABA receptor-potentiating agents in treatment. In a recent study, we used a benzodiazepine challenge to demonstrate abnormal GABAergic function during processing of negative visual stimuli in schizophrenia. This study extended this investigation by mapping GABAergic mechanisms associated with face processing and social appraisal in schizophrenia using a benzodiazepine challenge. Fourteen stable, medicated schizophrenia/schizoaffective patients (SZ) and 13 healthy controls (HC) underwent functional MRI using the blood oxygenation level-dependent (BOLD) technique while they performed the Socio-emotional Preference Task (SePT) on emotional face stimuli ("Do you like this face?"). Participants received single-blinded intravenous saline and lorazepam (LRZ) in two separate sessions separated by 1-3weeks. Both SZ and HC recruited medial prefrontal cortex/anterior cingulate during the SePT, relative to gender identification. A significant drug by group interaction was observed in the medial occipital cortex, such that SZ showed increased BOLD signal to LRZ challenge, while HC showed an expected decrease of signal; the interaction did not vary by task. The altered BOLD response to LRZ challenge in SZ was significantly correlated with increased negative affect across multiple measures. The altered response to LRZ challenge suggests that abnormal face processing and negative affect in SZ are associated with altered GABAergic function in the visual cortex, underscoring the role of impaired visual processing in socio-emotional deficits in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI BOLD was acquired during a socio-emotional face preference task (social-related processing). The study includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and extract relevant data.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses task-based whole-brain BOLD fMRI during a socio-emotional preferential task (SePT) that probes social appraisal of faces (a social-related construct). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age ~41.5) and reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain statistical results (FWE-corrected clusters) from task contrasts; the text explicitly states that both HC and SZ recruited medial prefrontal/ACC during SePT and presents whole-brain task effects and coordinates (Figures/Tables and Supplementary materials). Thus it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample with reported results, and (3) whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps/generalizable healthy-group effects. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and healthy-group task activation is reported).

studies.title: Hyper- and Hypomentalizing in Patients with First-Episode Schizophrenia: fMRI and Behavioral Studies.
studies.abstract: Historically, research investigating neural correlates of mentalizing deficits in schizophrenia has focused on patients who have been ill for several years with lengthy exposure to medication. Little is known about the neural and behavioral presentations of theory-of-mind deficits in schizophrenia, shortly after the first episode of psychosis.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI and behavioral studies of theory-of-mind in first-episode schizophrenia but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included or provide task details. Insufficient information in the abstract to determine eligibility; include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study using the Animated Triangles Task (a validated social/mentalizing paradigm). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (N=17; mean age ~23.6) and the paper reports within-group task activations for controls (intentional > random movement) using whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analysis (FSL/FLAME group-level analysis with cluster correction). Whole-brain statistical maps/activations for the control group are described and shown (figures and supplementary material), and results for healthy adults are reported separately despite inclusion of a clinical group. The study therefore meets the inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult group, and whole-brain univariate healthy-group task effects).

studies.title: Understanding others' regret: a FMRI study.
studies.abstract: Previous studies showed that the understanding of others' basic emotional experiences is based on a "resonant" mechanism, i.e., on the reactivation, in the observer's brain, of the cerebral areas associated with those experiences. The present study aimed to investigate whether the same neural mechanism is activated both when experiencing and attending complex, cognitively-generated, emotions. A gambling task and functional-Magnetic-Resonance-Imaging (fMRI) were used to test this hypothesis using regret, the negative cognitively-based emotion resulting from an unfavorable counterfactual comparison between the outcomes of chosen and discarded options. Do the same brain structures that mediate the experience of regret become active in the observation of situations eliciting regret in another individual? Here we show that observing the regretful outcomes of someone else's choices activates the same regions that are activated during a first-person experience of regret, i.e. the ventromedial prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate cortex and hippocampus. These results extend the possible role of a mirror-like mechanism beyond basic emotions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating understanding of others' regret (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Abstract indicates task involves observing others’ emotions using fMRI. Participant health/ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study directly probing perception/understanding of others’ emotions (regret), a social-related construct. Participants are healthy adults (two samples of N=24 each; ages within 19–31 and 19–30), meeting the age and sample requirements. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (contrasts IP minus IF and OP minus OF, parametric modulators for regret/disappointment), conjunction analyses, and voxelwise statistical maps/activation foci with thresholds and coordinates (SPM5). Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are explicitly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Sharpened self-other distinction in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
studies.abstract: Differentiation between self-produced tactile stimuli and touch by others is necessary for social interactions and for a coherent concept of "self". In attention-deficit-hyperactivity-disorder (ADHD), tactile hypersensitivity and social cognition problems are part of the symptomatology, but pathophysiological mechanisms are largely unknown. Differentiation of self- and non-self- generated sensations might be key to understand and develop novel strategies for managing hypersensitivity. Here, we compared the neural signatures of affective self- and other-touch between adults with ADHD and neurotypical controls (NC).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study examines neural signatures of affective self- and other-touch (social-related processing) and includes neurotypical adult controls. The abstract does not explicitly state that a functional MRI task was used, so imaging modality/task details are insufficient; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and task specifics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (self- vs other-touch) relevant to social processing (perception/understanding of self and others). It includes a healthy adult control group (age range mean ~23–24, within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper reports univariate whole-brain task-evoked effects for the control group (e.g., whole-brain contrasts and figures for other-touch and self-touch in neurotypical controls, FWE-corrected whole-brain results), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence generalizable to healthy adults. Although a clinical ADHD group is also included, healthy-group maps and contrasts are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age out of range) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Mental action simulation synchronizes action-observation circuits across individuals.
studies.abstract: A frontoparietal action-observation network (AON) has been proposed to support understanding others' actions and goals. We show that the AON "ticks together" in human subjects who are sharing a third person's feelings. During functional magnetic resonance imaging, 20 volunteers watched movies depicting boxing matches passively or while simulating a prespecified boxer's feelings. Instantaneous intersubject phase synchronization (ISPS) was computed to derive multisubject voxelwise similarity of hemodynamic activity and inter-area functional connectivity. During passive viewing, subjects' brain activity was synchronized in sensory projection and posterior temporal cortices. Simulation induced widespread increase of ISPS in the AON (premotor, posterior parietal, and superior temporal cortices), primary and secondary somatosensory cortices, and the dorsal attention circuits (frontal eye fields, intraparietal sulcus). Moreover, interconnectivity of these regions strengthened during simulation. We propose that sharing a third person's feelings synchronizes the observer's own brain mechanisms supporting sensations and motor planning, thereby likely promoting mutual understanding.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in 20 healthy volunteers performing a social-related task (simulating a third person’s feelings/observing others), addressing perception/understanding of others. Fits inclusion criteria; age range not stated in abstract but participants are volunteers (likely adults). Recommend full-text review to confirm ages and other details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 21–47) employing a social-related task (explicit simulation of others’ actions/feelings during viewing of boxing clips). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked BOLD analyses (GLM contrasts such as simulate > watch and simulate-loser > simulate-winner) with statistical thresholding (FDR cluster-level), figures of activation maps, and ROI analyses; results are generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, resting-state-only, or limited to clinical groups. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Aberrant effective connectivity is associated with positive symptoms in first-episode schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Schizophrenia is a neurodevelopmental psychiatric disorder thought to result from synaptic dysfunction that affects distributed brain connectivity, rather than any particular brain region. While symptomatology is traditionally divided into positive and negative symptoms, abnormal social cognition is now recognized a key component of schizophrenia. Nonetheless, we are still lacking a mechanistic understanding of effective brain connectivity in schizophrenia during social cognition and how it relates to clinical symptomatology. To address this question, we used fMRI and dynamic causal modelling (DCM) to test for abnormal brain connectivity in twenty-four patients with first-episode schizophrenia (FES) compared to twenty-five matched controls performing the Human Connectome Project (HCP) social cognition paradigm. Patients had not received regular therapeutic antipsychotics, but were not completely drug naïve. Whilst patients were less accurate than controls in judging social stimuli from non-social stimuli, our results revealed an increase in feedforward connectivity from motion-sensitive V5 to posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS) in patients compared to matched controls. At the same time, patients with a higher degree of positive symptoms had more disinhibition within pSTS, a region computationally involved in social cognition. We interpret these findings the framework of active inference, where increased feedforward connectivity may encode aberrant prediction errors from V5 to pSTS and local disinhibition within pSTS may reflect aberrant encoding of the precision of cortical representations about social stimuli.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using the HCP social cognition paradigm (social task) that includes a matched healthy control group alongside first-episode schizophrenia patients. Meets criterion of fMRI social task and presence of healthy participants; not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study using the HCP social cognition (Animated Triangles) task, directly probing social perception/understanding. It includes a healthy adult control group (N=25) reported separately from the patient group. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation results for the healthy controls (e.g., V5 and pSTS activations with MNI coordinates), thresholded at p<0.05 FWE whole-brain corrected, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also includes a clinical group, healthy-group results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

studies.title: Developmental phonagnosia: Linking neural mechanisms with the behavioural phenotype.
studies.abstract: Human voice recognition is critical for many aspects of social communication. Recently, a rare disorder, developmental phonagnosia, which describes the inability to recognise a speaker's voice, has been discovered. The underlying neural mechanisms are unknown. Here, we used two functional magnetic resonance imaging experiments to investigate brain function in two behaviourally well characterised phonagnosia cases, both 32 years old: AS has apperceptive and SP associative phonagnosia. We found distinct malfunctioned brain mechanisms in AS and SP matching their behavioural profiles. In apperceptive phonagnosia, right-hemispheric auditory voice-sensitive regions (i.e., Heschl's gyrus, planum temporale, superior temporal gyrus) showed lower responses than in matched controls (n
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI experiments examined human voice recognition (social communication/perception) and included matched healthy control participants (adults ~32 years). Study is empirical (not a review) and fits age range and task domain; abstract provides sufficient evidence to warrant full-text inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of voice-identity/speaker recognition — a social-communication / perception-of-others task — with healthy adult control groups (n=16 and n=16; ages ~29–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts for controls (e.g., vocal>non-vocal and speaker>speech) with statistical maps and coordinate tables. Results for healthy/control participants are presented separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI on social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level univariate maps reported). No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Neural responses to dynamic multimodal stimuli and pathology-specific impairments of social cognition in schizophrenia and depression.
studies.abstract: Individuals with schizophrenia and people with depression both show abnormal behavioural and neural responses when perceiving and responding to emotional stimuli, but pathology-specific differences and commonalities remain mostly unclear.
studies.journal: The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports neural responses to social/emotional stimuli but does not specify that functional MRI was used nor whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm fMRI and healthy control group — include for full-text review to verify imaging modality and participant characteristics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy to dynamic multimodal social stimuli). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=24; mean age ~35, within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task analyses (mixed-effects GLM, F- and T-contrasts), thresholded cluster-corrected maps and stereotaxic coordinate tables (Tables and figures) and explicitly describes within-group contrasts for each participant group, including controls. The healthy-group task effects are therefore available as whole-brain activation maps/coordinates and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or missing healthy whole-brain maps) are violated. Accordingly the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Amygdala lesions do not compromise the cortical network for false-belief reasoning.
studies.abstract: The amygdala plays an integral role in human social cognition and behavior, with clear links to emotion recognition, trust judgments, anthropomorphization, and psychiatric disorders ranging from social phobia to autism. A central feature of human social cognition is a theory-of-mind (ToM) that enables the representation other people's mental states as distinct from one's own. Numerous neuroimaging studies of the best studied use of ToM--false-belief reasoning--suggest that it relies on a specific cortical network; moreover, the amygdala is structurally and functionally connected with many components of this cortical network. It remains unknown whether the cortical implementation of any form of ToM depends on amygdala function. Here we investigated this question directly by conducting functional MRI on two patients with rare bilateral amygdala lesions while they performed a neuroimaging protocol standardized for measuring cortical activity associated with false-belief reasoning. We compared patient responses with those of two healthy comparison groups that included 480 adults. Based on both univariate and multivariate comparisons, neither patient showed any evidence of atypical cortical activity or any evidence of atypical behavioral performance; moreover, this pattern of typical cortical and behavioral response was replicated for both patients in a follow-up session. These findings argue that the amygdala is not necessary for the cortical implementation of ToM in adulthood and suggest a reevaluation of the role of the amygdala and its cortical interactions in human social cognition.
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using a false-belief (theory-of-mind) task—clearly social cognition—conducted in humans. Abstract reports large healthy comparison groups (480 adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (false-belief) reasoning—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The paper includes healthy adult reference groups: a large MIT sample (n=462; age range 18–69) and a Caltech sample (n=18; age range 21–46). The manuscript reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the Belief > Photo contrast for the MIT reference group (voxelwise, FWE-corrected) and for the Caltech group (cluster-level corrected), and these healthy-group maps are clearly described and generalizable. The study therefore meets the fMRI, social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain evidence inclusion criteria. It does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy-group whole-brain maps are provided).

studies.title: Individualism, conservatism, and radicalism as criteria for processing political beliefs: a parametric fMRI study.
studies.abstract: Politics is a manifestation of the uniquely human ability to debate, decide, and reach consensus on decisions affecting large groups over long durations of time. Recent neuroimaging studies on politics have focused on the association between brain regions and specific political behaviors by adopting party or ideological affiliation as a criterion to classify either experimental stimuli or subjects. However, it is unlikely that complex political beliefs (i.e., "the government should protect freedom of speech") are evaluated only on a liberal-to-conservative criterion. Here we used multidimensional scaling and parametric functional magnetic resonance imaging to identify which criteria/dimensions people use to structure complex political beliefs and which brain regions are concurrently activated. We found that three independent dimensions explained the variability of a set of statements expressing political beliefs and that each dimension was reflected in a distinctive pattern of neural activation: individualism (medial prefrontal cortex and temporoparietal junction), conservatism (dorsolateral prefrontal cortex), and radicalism (ventral striatum and posterior cingulate). The structures we identified are also known to be important in self-other processing, social decision-making in ambivalent situations, and reward prediction. Our results extend current knowledge on the neural correlates of the structure of political beliefs, a fundamental aspect of the human ability to coalesce into social entities.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where participants evaluated complex political beliefs, engaging social-cognitive processes (self–other processing, social decision-making). Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluation of political beliefs involving self–other processing, social decision-making, and perspective-taking). Sample: healthy adult participants (fMRI N=26; ages 22–45), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, task-evoked whole-brain analyses (second-level random-effects; statistical maps thresholded and peak coordinates reported; Table of coordinates and Talairach values provided). Analyses are univariate task activations (parametric modulation) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Functional activation abnormalities during facial emotion perception in schizophrenia patients and nonpsychotic relatives.
studies.abstract: Deficits in facial emotion perception in schizophrenia may be a marker of disorder liability. Previous functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies investigating these deficits have been limited by task demands that may recruit other impaired cognitive processes in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI of facial emotion perception is a social-processing task relevant to the review. Abstract does not clearly state presence of healthy adult control group or participants’ ages; nonpsychotic relatives may be healthy but this is ambiguous. Insufficient information in abstract to exclude, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study investigates facial emotion perception (a social-related processing task) using a passive viewing task. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=27; mean age ~40, within 17–65). The authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (within-group activation maps and contrasts such as faces vs. scrambled and emotional vs. neutral), thresholded and corrected (cluster-forming z>2.3, p<0.05), with within-group activation results for the control group described (complete within-group activations provided in the Supplementary Material) and illustrated in figures/tables. Results for the healthy/control group are therefore clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and uses task-based fMRI (not solely ROI or connectivity-only analyses). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Functional deficit of the medial prefrontal cortex during emotional sentence attribution in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Functional brain imaging research has already demonstrated that patients with schizophrenia had difficulties with emotion processing, namely in facial emotion perception and emotional prosody. However, the moderating effect of social context and the boundary of perceptual categories of emotion attribution remain unclear. This study investigated the neural bases of emotional sentence attribution in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study uses an fMRI task of emotional sentence attribution, a social-related process. Abstract does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm presence of healthy participants, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study includes a healthy adult control group (n=25, mean age ~33) and reports task-based fMRI whole-brain analyses. The paradigm probes social-related processing (emotional sentence attribution; social communication/theory-of-mind domain). Group-level whole-brain results are reported (main task effects, group effects and Task×Group interaction) with FWE-corrected voxelwise maps and coordinate tables. The paper explicitly states healthy controls significantly activated the medial prefrontal cortex during the emotional task, indicating an identifiable healthy-group task activation map (reported via interaction and plotted activations). Thus it provides whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results attributable to a healthy adult sample and meets inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neuronal correlates of social cognition in borderline personality disorder.
studies.abstract: Patients with borderline personality disorder (BPD) have severe problems in social interactions that might be caused by deficits in social cognition. Since the findings about social-cognitive abilities in BPD are inhomogeneous, ranging from deficits to superior abilities, we aimed to investigate the neuronal basis of social cognition in BPD. We applied a paradigm with three social cognition tasks, differing in their complexity: basal processing of faces with a neutral expression, recognition of emotions, and attribution of emotional intentions (affective ToM). A total of 13 patients with BPD and 13 healthy matched controls (HCs) were included in a functional magnet resonance imaging study. BPD patients showed no deficits in social cognition on the behavioral level. However, while HCs showed increasing activation in areas of the mirror neuron system with increasing complexity in the social-cognitive task, BPD patients had hypoactivation in these areas and hyperactivation in the amygdala which were not modulated by task complexity. This activation pattern seems to reflect an enhanced emotional approach in the processing of social stimuli in BPD that allows good performance in standardized social-cognitive tasks, but might be the basis of social-cognitive deficits in real-life social interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using social-cognition tasks (face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) that includes a healthy matched control group. Meets the review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not report exact ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This peer-reviewed fMRI study experimentally manipulates social-cognitive processes (basal face processing, emotion recognition, affective Theory-of-Mind) using task-based event-related fMRI. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age ~30) reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation results (single-group results at P<0.001 uncorrected are provided in Supplementary Tables S1–S4) and whole-brain group comparisons; although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain healthy-group task effects are clearly described. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult group, and whole-brain univariate results). Note: sample size is small and clinical group present, but healthy-control whole-brain data are reported separately.

studies.title: Event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging measures of neural activity to positive social stimuli in pre- and post-treatment depression.
studies.abstract: Relationships between aberrant social functioning and depression have been explored via behavioral, clinical, and survey methodologies, highlighting their importance in the etiology of depression. The neural underpinnings of these relationships, however, have not been explored.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Title/abstract indicate event-related fMRI to positive social stimuli (a social-related task). However, the abstract does not specify whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based whole-brain fMRI of social-related stimuli (positive social interaction, faces, erotica) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=14; mean age 28.2). Voxelwise, univariate whole-brain analyses (stimulus group × participant group × scan ANOVAs) are reported with mapwise-corrected clusters and Talairach coordinates (Tables 3–5) and simple-effects for control subjects are described, meeting the requirement to provide healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical results. The task assesses social-perception and social-affective constructs relevant to the review objective. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it should be included.

studies.title: Disgust and biological descriptions bias logical reasoning during legal decision-making.
studies.abstract: Legal decisions often require logical reasoning about the mental states of people who perform gruesome behaviors. We use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to examine how brain regions implicated in logical reasoning are modulated by emotion and social cognition during legal decision-making. Participants read vignettes describing crimes that elicit strong or weak disgust matched on punishment severity using the US Federal Sentencing Guidelines. An extraneous sentence at the end of each vignette described the perpetrator's personality using traits or biological language, mimicking the increased use of scientific evidence presented in courts. Behavioral results indicate that crimes weak in disgust receive significantly less punishment than the guidelines recommend. Neuroimaging results indicate that brain regions active during logical reasoning respond less to crimes weak in disgust and biological descriptions of personality, demonstrating the impact of emotion and social cognition on logical reasoning mechanisms necessary for legal decision-making.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI was used while participants performed a social-related legal reasoning task probing perception/understanding of others (disgust responses and personality descriptions). No indication of clinical samples; fits healthy adult cognitive social processing. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults: participants (n=20; age 18–45) completed a legal decision-making task probing responsibility and punishment (perception/understanding of others, moral/social cognition). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts and regressions with peak voxel coordinates and multiple-comparison correction (whole-brain results in Tables 1–4), not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. Healthy adult group results are reported separately and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (task fMRI of social-related processing; healthy adult sample within age range; whole-brain group-level univariate maps reported). No exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Emotional expressions in voice and music: same code, same effect?
studies.abstract: Scholars have documented similarities in the way voice and music convey emotions. By using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) we explored whether these similarities imply overlapping processing substrates. We asked participants to trace changes in either the emotion or pitch of vocalizations and music using a joystick. Compared to music, vocalizations more strongly activated superior and middle temporal cortex, cuneus, and precuneus. However, despite these differences, overlapping rather than differing regions emerged when comparing emotion with pitch tracing for music and vocalizations, respectively. Relative to pitch tracing, emotion tracing activated medial superior frontal and anterior cingulate cortex regardless of stimulus type. Additionally, we observed emotion specific effects in primary and secondary auditory cortex as well as in medial frontal cortex that were comparable for voice and music. Together these results indicate that similar mechanisms support emotional inferences from vocalizations and music and that these mechanisms tap on a general system involved in social cognition.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where participants performed emotion-tracing tasks on vocalizations and music—addresses social communication and emotion perception (social cognition). Not a review. Abstract doesn't specify participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of healthy adults (N=16, ages 18–26) that explicitly probes social-related processing: participants continuously tracked emotional expression (emotion task) in voices and music, engaging processes related to perception/understanding of others (medial SFG/ACC; theory-of-mind/empathy). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., emotion task > pitch task, voice > rest, music > rest), with cluster-corrected statistics, peak coordinates, figures, and ROI follow-ups. Results are reported for the healthy participant group and are generalizable within the adult range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Impaired neural processing of social attribution in anorexia nervosa.
studies.abstract: Anorexia nervosa (AN) patients have been found to have problems in social cognition, including the process of thinking about other people's thoughts and feelings, often referred to as Theory of Mind (ToM). We examined neural correlates relating to thinking about social relationships in 17 women in recovery from anorexia (RAN) and 17 healthy women (CON) using a functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) task. The task consisted of short videos of moving shapes that subjects viewed either in the context of performing a social decision related to how the shapes interacted: "People: All friends?" or in the context of performing a visuospatial task related to how the shapes moved after bumping into each other: "Bumper cars: Same weight?". The RAN participants showed reduced activation in the social cognition network, with the most robust differences in the right temporoparietal junction (RTPJ). There were no significant differences between the CON and RAN groups in regions more active during the visuospatial task. These neural correlates show differences in the processing of social knowledge in RAN subjects suggesting that biological impairments in social cognition may contribute to pathology in AN.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using a social cognition/Theory of Mind task (social attribution) and includes a healthy control group of adults. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy participants present). No exclusion criteria met.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social attribution (People vs Bumper) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=17, ages 18–39). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts for the People - Bumper condition for controls (one-sample t-test group maps shown in Fig. 3 and peak coordinates/clusters reported in tables), and also provides between-group comparisons. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and include whole-brain activation clusters and coordinate tables, satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes healthy adults).

studies.title: Mild adverse childhood experiences increase neural efficacy during affective theory of mind.
studies.abstract: Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) affect the development of social cognition (and identify a risk factor for several physical and mental disorders). Theory of Mind (ToM) is a key predictor of social functioning, mental health, and quality of life. No previous study explored the effect of mild ACEs on the neural correlates of ToM in healthy humans. In 23 healthy participants, we used brain blood oxygen level-dependent fMRI to study the effect of ACEs on the neural responses to tasks targeting affective and cognitive ToM. Results pointed out an association between ACEs and a lower neural response in the vermis of the cerebellum (r = -.85), precentral gyrus, and inferior frontal operculum (putative Mirror Neural System, r = -.78) during affective ToM. A lower recruitment of these brain regions, paralleled by the same performance, could express an increased neural efficacy in inferring affective mental states driven by previous experience, in this case, ACEs.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study reports BOLD fMRI during affective and cognitive Theory of Mind tasks (social processing) in a sample of 23 healthy adult participants; participants fall within target age range; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient information for inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related (affective and cognitive Theory of Mind), (2) Sample consists of healthy adults (N=23) within the 17–65 range, (3) The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (AToM vs control and CToM vs control) with voxelwise thresholding and FDR cluster correction and provides tables/coordinates and figures of significant clusters, and (4) Not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore this study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Imaging attentional and attributional bias: an fMRI approach to the paranoid delusion.
studies.abstract: The pathophysiology of auditory hallucinations and delusions of control has been elucidated using functional imaging. Despite their clinical importance, there have been few similar attempts to investigate paranoid delusions. We have examined two components of social cognition (attentional and attributional biases) that contribute to the formation and maintenance of paranoid delusions, using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating attentional and attributional biases (components of social cognition). Abstract does not state whether a healthy adult group (age 17–65) was included or provide participant details. Not a review. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants and ages.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult (normal) subjects performing social-cognition tasks (attentional and attributional judgments about self-relevant/threatening material), fitting the review’s social-related constructs (perception/understanding of self/others). Group-level task activations are reported (named cortical and subcortical regions with Brodmann areas), indicating whole-brain univariate task-evoked results for the healthy group rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Participant group is healthy adults; results are presented as generalizable within-group activations. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) are met. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neural correlates of moral reasoning in autism spectrum disorder.
studies.abstract: In our study, we tried to clarify whether patients with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) reveal different moral decision patterns as compared to healthy subjects and whether common social interaction difficulties in ASD are reflected in altered brain activation during different aspects of moral reasoning. 28 patients with high-functioning ASD and 28 healthy subjects matched for gender, age and education took part in an event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging study. Participants were confronted with textual dilemma situations followed by proposed solutions to which they could agree or disagree. On a neural level, moral decision making was associated with activation in anterior medial prefrontal regions, the temporo-parietal junction and the precuneus for both groups. However, while patients and healthy controls did not exhibit significant behavioral differences, ASD patients showed decreased activation in limbic regions, particularly the amygdala, as well as increased activation in the anterior and the posterior cingulate gyrus during moral reasoning. Alterations of brain activation in patients might thus indicate specific impairments in empathy. However, activation increases in brain regions associated with the 'default mode network' and self-referential cognition also provide evidence for an altered way of patients' cerebral processing with regard to decision making based on social information.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI was used during moral reasoning (a social cognition task). The study includes a healthy control group of adults (matched to ASD group). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study of moral reasoning (a social-cognition task). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=28, mean age ~31) reported separately. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy controls (one-sample analyses and pooled contrasts; results reported in Table 3 and Figure 2, FWE-corrected), not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Simulating fiction: individual differences in literature comprehension revealed with FMRI.
studies.abstract: When we read literary fiction, we are transported to fictional places, and we feel and think along with the characters. Despite the importance of narrative in adult life and during development, the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying fiction comprehension are unclear. We used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate how individuals differently employ neural networks important for understanding others' beliefs and intentions (mentalizing), and for sensori-motor simulation while listening to excerpts from literary novels. Localizer tasks were used to localize both the cortical motor network and the mentalizing network in participants after they listened to excerpts from literary novels. Results show that participants who had high activation in anterior medial prefrontal cortex (aMPFC; part of the mentalizing network) when listening to mentalizing content of literary fiction, had lower motor cortex activity when they listened to action-related content of the story, and vice versa. This qualifies how people differ in their engagement with fiction: some people are mostly drawn into a story by mentalizing about the thoughts and beliefs of others, whereas others engage in literature by simulating more concrete events such as actions. This study provides on-line neural evidence for the existence of qualitatively different styles of moving into literary worlds, and adds to a growing body of literature showing the potential to study narrative comprehension with neuroimaging methods.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study probing mentalizing (understanding others’ beliefs/intentions) and sensorimotor simulation while participants listened to literary fiction. This targets social cognitive processing in (presumably) healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study examines mentalizing (Theory-of-Mind) during comprehension of literary fiction—directly addressing social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy adults (N=18; ages 18–27), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Mentalizing > Action and Action > Mentalizing) with correction for multiple comparisons and localized activations (aMPFC, rTPJ, etc.), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study also includes ROI analyses but does not rely solely on them. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Direction-sensitive codes for observed head turns in human superior temporal sulcus.
studies.abstract: Humans and other primates are adept at using the direction of another's gaze or head turn to infer where that individual is attending. Research in macaque neurophysiology suggests that anterior superior temporal sulcus (STS) contains a direction-sensitive code for such social attention cues. By contrast, most human functional Magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies report that posterior STS is responsive to social attention cues. It is unclear whether this functional discrepancy is caused by a species difference or by experimental design differences. Furthermore, social attention cues are dynamic in naturalistic social interaction, but most studies to date have been restricted to static displays. In order to address these issues, we used multivariate pattern analysis of fMRI data to test whether response patterns in human right STS distinguish between leftward and rightward dynamic head turns. Such head turn discrimination was observed in right anterior STS/superior temporal gyrus (STG). Response patterns in this region were also significantly more discriminable for head turn direction than for rotation direction in physically matched ellipsoid control stimuli. Our findings suggest a role for right anterior STS/STG in coding the direction of motion in dynamic social attention cues.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human fMRI study examining neural coding of dynamic social attention cues (direction of observed head turns) in right STS/STG — directly relevant to social perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit participant age details, so include for full-text to confirm sample meets age/health criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29, range 22–38) investigating perception of others’ head turns — a social-attention / perception-of-others task. The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (gray-matter–masked full-volume and ROI-constrained analyses) with voxelwise results and coordinates (FWE-corrected p-values) and figures/tables described in the text. The sample consists of healthy adults and results are reported for that group. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and coordinate results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only connectivity or only patient groups) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: I See Your Effort: Force-Related BOLD Effects in an Extended Action Execution-Observation Network Involving the Cerebellum.
studies.abstract: Action observation (AO) is crucial for motor planning, imitation learning, and social interaction, but it is not clear whether and how an action execution-observation network (AEON) processes the effort of others engaged in performing actions. In this functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study, we used a "squeeze ball" task involving different grip forces to investigate whether AEON activation showed similar patterns when executing the task or observing others performing it. Both in action execution, AE (subjects performed the visuomotor task) and action observation, AO (subjects watched a video of the task being performed by someone else), the fMRI signal was detected in cerebral and cerebellar regions. These responses showed various relationships with force mapping onto specific areas of the sensorimotor and cognitive systems. Conjunction analysis of AE and AO was repeated for the "0th" order and linear and nonlinear responses, and revealed multiple AEON nodes remapping the detection of actions, and also effort, of another person onto the observer's own cerebrocerebellar system. This result implies that the AEON exploits the cerebellum, which is known to process sensorimotor predictions and simulations, performing an internal assessment of forces and integrating information into high-level schemes, providing a crucial substrate for action imitation.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study involving action observation and execution assessing perception of others' effort—falls under 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (social processing). Human participants implied; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI social-related task.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of action observation/execution addressing perception and understanding of others’ applied force—a social perceptual process relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Participants: healthy adult sample (n=12, mean age 26) within 17–65. Methods: task-based fMRI with whole-brain, group-level, univariate GLM analyses (SPM12), voxelwise maps and conjunction analyses reported, thresholds and cluster coordinates described; cerebellar SUIT and whole-brain results provided. Results are presented as group-level task-evoked whole-brain activation maps and coordinates. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not between-group-only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Identifying autism from neural representations of social interactions: neurocognitive markers of autism.
studies.abstract: Autism is a psychiatric/neurological condition in which alterations in social interaction (among other symptoms) are diagnosed by behavioral psychiatric methods. The main goal of this study was to determine how the neural representations and meanings of social concepts (such as to insult) are altered in autism. A second goal was to determine whether these alterations can serve as neurocognitive markers of autism. The approach is based on previous advances in fMRI analysis methods that permit (a) the identification of a concept, such as the thought of a physical object, from its fMRI pattern, and (b) the ability to assess the semantic content of a concept from its fMRI pattern. These factor analysis and machine learning methods were applied to the fMRI activation patterns of 17 adults with high-functioning autism and matched controls, scanned while thinking about 16 social interactions. One prominent neural representation factor that emerged (manifested mainly in posterior midline regions) was related to self-representation, but this factor was present only for the control participants, and was near-absent in the autism group. Moreover, machine learning algorithms classified individuals as autistic or control with 97% accuracy from their fMRI neurocognitive markers. The findings suggest that psychiatric alterations of thought can begin to be biologically understood by assessing the form and content of the altered thought's underlying brain activation patterns.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study scanning adults (17 with high-functioning autism and matched control participants) while they thought about 16 social interactions. Includes a healthy adult control group and uses a social-related task (perception/representation of social interactions), meeting the inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study includes a healthy adult control group (17 age- and IQ-matched controls) and uses fMRI during a social-related task (thinking about interpersonal interactions/self-related cognition). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM contrasts (social interactions > fixation) for the groups, with reported activation maps/locations and thresholding (p=0.001 uncorrected, extent 5 voxels) described for the control group. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults in the specified age range. The study is empirical, not limited to ROIs or resting-state/connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Social cognition in schizophrenia: Validation of an ecological fMRI task.
studies.abstract: Neuroimaging studies have revealed brain regions involved in social cognition, which reportedly show functional alterations in schizophrenia. However, the social neural network has not been investigated with regards to language perception and social interactions in daily life. Here we developed and validated an integrative fMRI task to explore the neural basis of social cognition with regards to language perception in schizophrenia. The task comprised listening to film extracts and inferring mental states to characters. We first identified the functional network activated during the task in 28 healthy controls (HC). Next, we evaluated the reproducibility of Blood-Oxygen-Level Dependent (BOLD) variations in 14 HC participants. Finally, we investigated network impairment in 20 patients with schizophrenia (SZ) compared to HC. The HC group exhibited bilateral activation in the superior and middle temporal gyri (including the poles and the temporo-parietal junction). Overall, our novel integrative task induced activation of a functional network with good reproducibility and involved in language conveying social information. Compared to the HC group, the SZ group showed decreased recruitment of the right temporo-parietal junction. These findings may be useful for testing the impact of remediation on the brain, particularly on the network of language conveying social information.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI task assesses social cognition (inferring mental states from film extracts; language-based social information) and includes healthy control groups (28 HC; reproducibility sample). This meets the review focus on fMRI social processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not state ages explicitly, but presence of adult healthy controls is likely; include for full-text review to confirm ages/details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based fMRI of social cognition using ecological language-based stimuli (listening to film excerpts of social interactions) and directly targets social-related processing (theory of mind/attribution). It includes a healthy adult group (HC-S1, n=28; ages 18–65) and presents a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (INT > HIN) for the healthy controls, thresholded at p<0.05 FWE, with coordinates and cluster tables (Table 2) and figures. Healthy-group results are reported separately from the patient group, and whole-brain task activation maps and peak coordinates are clearly described. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, includes healthy adults within age range, empirical data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Brain activation during self- and other-reflection in bipolar disorder with a history of psychosis: Comparison to schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Reflecting on the self and on others activates specific brain areas and contributes to metacognition and social cognition. The aim of the current study is to investigate brain activation during self- and other-reflection in patients with bipolar disorder (BD). In addition, we examined whether potential abnormal brain activation in BD patients could distinguish BD from patients with schizophrenia (SZ).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study uses fMRI to assess self- and other-reflection (social processing). Abstract does not specify presence of a healthy control group aged 17–65; insufficient information to confirm inclusion of healthy adults, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self- and other-reflection) and includes a healthy adult control group (21 HCs). The paper reports within-group, whole-brain univariate task effects for the healthy/control group (e.g., self > semantic and other > semantic activations in VMPFC, DMPFC, ACC, PCC, precuneus, etc.) using voxelwise FWE-corrected thresholds, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group task activations are clearly described. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: The neural basis of shared preference learning.
studies.abstract: During our daily lives, we often learn about the similarity of the traits and preferences of others to our own and use that information during our social interactions. However, it is unclear how the brain represents similarity between the self and others. One possible mechanism is to track similarity to oneself regardless of the identity of the other (Similarity account); an alternative is to track each other person in terms of consistency of their choice similarity with respect to the choices they have made before (consistency account). Our study combined functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) and computational modelling of reinforcement learning (RL) to investigate the neural processes that underlie learning about preference similarity. Participants chose which of two pieces of artwork they preferred and saw the choices of one agent who usually shared their preference and another agent who usually did not. We modelled neural activation with RL models based on the similarity and consistency accounts. Our results showed that activity in brain areas linked to reward and social cognition followed the consistency account. Our findings suggest that impressions of other people can be calculated in a person-specific manner, which assumes that each individual behaves consistently with their past choices.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Original fMRI study investigating neural representation of social preference similarity and social cognition—meets topic of social-related processing. Abstract implies human participants performing an fMRI social task; not a review. Age of participants not specified; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and other eligibility details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social learning about others’ preference similarity (social cognition: perception/understanding of others; affiliation/liking measures). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 25.1, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLMs, conjunctions, cluster-corrected contrasts) with peak MNI coordinates and cluster statistics for multiple contrasts and parametric modulators. The methods and results clearly describe univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not patient-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Neural activation abnormalities during self-referential processing in schizophrenia: an fMRI study.
studies.abstract: Impairments in self-awareness contribute to disability in schizophrenia. Studies have revealed activation abnormalities in schizophrenia in cortical midline structures associated with self-reference. We used functional magnetic resonance imaging to compare activation throughout the brain in people with schizophrenia and healthy controls (Kelly et al., 2002) while they indicated whether trait adjectives described attributes of themselves, their mother or a former president of the United States. Blood oxygenation level dependent signal in each condition was compared to resting fixation. Patients were less likely and slower to endorse positive self-attributes, and more likely and quicker to endorse negative self-attributes than controls. Activation abnormalities reported previously in cortical midline structures were again noted. In addition, patients showed greater signal increases in frontal, temporal gyri and insula, and smaller signal decreases in posterior regions than healthy controls when thinking about themselves. Group differences were less evident when subjects were thinking about their mothers and tended to go in the opposite direction when thinking about a president. Many of the areas showing abnormality have been shown in other studies to differ between patients and controls in structure and with other activation paradigms. We suggest that general neuropathology in schizophrenia alters the neural system configurations associated with self-representation.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of self-referential processing (Perception/Understanding of Self), which is a social-related construct, and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages—insufficient detail to confirm 17–65—so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility and extract data.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI study of social-related processing (self-referential task), includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 31–58 within 17–65), and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group (activation maps and whole-brain corrected results for controls are described and shown). Although the paper also includes a clinical schizophrenia group, control-group results are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state-only, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain results) are violated.

studies.title: It is not always tickling: distinct cerebral responses during perception of different laughter types.
studies.abstract: Laughter is highly relevant for social interaction in human beings and non-human primates. In humans as well as in non-human primates laughter can be induced by tickling.
