Abstract does not explicitly state whether healthy control participants were included; because information is insufficient to confirm the required healthy adult group, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study uses a social-related task (visual perception of biological motion — perception/understanding of others). The sample includes 15 healthy adult controls reported separately (age- and IQ-matched to OCD patients), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts (biological motion vs scrambled) for the healthy/control group (tables and figures of group activation maps and second-level random-effects analyses are presented), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state methods, and healthy-group task effects are explicitly reported. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Effect of intentional bias on agency attribution of animated motion: an event-related fMRI study.
studies.abstract: Animated movements of simple geometric shapes can readily be interpreted as depicting social events in which animate agents are engaged in intentional activity. However, the brain regions associated with such intention have not been clearly elucidated. In this study, intentional bias was manipulated using shape and pattern animations while measuring associated brain activity using event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Twenty-five higher-intention involved and twenty-five lower-intention involved animations were presented to participants. Behavioral results showed that the degree of agency attribution of the mental state increased as intentional involvement increased. fMRI results revealed that the posterior superior temporal sulcus (STS), inferior temporal gyrus (ITG), inferior frontal gyrus (IFG), premotor, temporal pole, supramarginal gyrus, and superior parietal lobule (SPL) were activated while participants viewed the high-intention animations. In contrast, occipital, lingual, and middle frontal gyri were activated while the participants viewed the low-intention animations. These findings suggest that as agent attribution increases, the visual brain changes its functional role to the intentional brain and becomes a flexible network for processing information about social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining agency attribution/social perception using animated shapes—directly relevant to social processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or health status, so inclusion criterion about healthy adults (17–65) cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify participant demographics and health.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, mean age 25.2) that explicitly probes social cognition (agency attribution/theory of mind using Heider–Simmel-style animations). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (high>low intentionality and low>high) analyzed with random-effects SPM2 and thresholded at p<0.001, with reported activated regions and figures. Results for the healthy adult group are presented directly and are generalizable (not limited to a clinical subgroup). The study is empirical, task-based, and not ROI-, connectivity-, or resting-state-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Can we share a pain we never felt? Neural correlates of empathy in patients with congenital insensitivity to pain.
studies.abstract: Theories of empathy differ regarding the relative contributions of automatic resonance and perspective taking in understanding others' emotions. Patients with the rare syndrome of congenital insensitivity to pain cannot rely on "mirror matching" (i.e., resonance) mechanisms to understand the pain of others. Nevertheless, they showed normal fMRI responses to observed pain in anterior mid-cingulate cortex and anterior insula, two key regions of the so-called "shared circuits" for self and other pain. In these patients (but not in healthy controls), empathy trait predicted ventromedial prefrontal responses to somatosensory representations of others' pain and posterior cingulate responses to emotional representations of others' pain. These findings underline the major role of midline structures in emotional perspective taking and understanding someone else's feeling despite the lack of any previous personal experience of it--an empathic challenge frequently raised during human social interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of empathy for others' pain (perception/understanding of others), includes healthy control group; meets social-related task criterion and involves human participants. Not a review. Abstract indicates relevance for inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports task-based fMRI of empathy for pain, a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age 33 ±9, within 17–65) with group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses and contrasts (e.g., Painful vs Nonpainful; Painful vs Baseline) reported for the control group. Whole-brain results are presented in tables of coordinates and figures, and regression analyses for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and provides univariate whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Sex differences in own and other body perception.
studies.abstract: Own body perception, and differentiating and comparing one's body to another person's body, are common cognitive functions that have relevance for self-identity and social interactions. In several psychiatric conditions, including anorexia nervosa, body dysmorphic disorder, gender dysphoria, and autism spectrum disorder, self and own body perception, as well as aspects of social communication are disturbed. Despite most of these conditions having skewed prevalence sex ratios, little is known about whether the neural basis of own body perception differs between the sexes. We addressed this question by investigating brain activation using functional magnetic resonance imaging during a Body Perception task in 15 male and 15 female healthy participants. Participants viewed their own body, bodies of same-sex, or opposite-sex other people, and rated the degree that they appeared like themselves. We found that men and women did not differ in the pattern of brain activation during own body perception compared to a scrambled control image. However, when viewing images of other bodies of same-sex or opposite-sex, men showed significantly stronger activations in attention-related and reward-related brain regions, whereas women engaged stronger activations in striatal, medial-prefrontal, and insular cortices, when viewing the own body compared to other images of the opposite sex. It is possible that other body images, particularly of the opposite sex, may be of greater salience for men, whereas images of own bodies may be more salient for women. These observations provide tentative neurobiological correlates to why women may be more vulnerable than men to conditions involving own body perception.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI was used in healthy adult participants (15 male, 15 female) during a Body Perception task comparing own vs other bodies, targeting perception/understanding of self and others — a social-related construct. This meets the inclusion criteria; not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=30, ages ~26) examining perception and understanding of self and others (body perception, self–other distinction), which falls under the review’s social-related constructs. The authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., own body > scrambled, same-sex other > scrambled, opposite-sex other > scrambled) with cluster-corrected voxelwise thresholds and report group comparisons and coordinate tables/figures. Results are reported separately for healthy male and female participants (healthy sample only). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not non-empirical, participant ages within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Does self-construal predict activity in the social brain network? A genetic moderation effect.
studies.abstract: Neural activity in the social brain network varies across individuals with different cultural traits and different genetic polymorphisms. It remains unknown whether a specific genetic polymorphism may influence the association between cultural traits and neural activity in the social brain network. We tested whether the serotonin transporter promoter polymorphism (5-HTTLPR) affects the association between self-construals and neural activity involved in reflection of personal attributes of oneself and a significant other (i.e., mother). Using functional MRI, we scanned Chinese adults with short/short (s/s) or long/long (l/l) variants of the 5-HTTLPR during reflection of personal attributes of oneself and one's mother. We found that, while s/s and l/l genotype groups did not differ significantly in self-construals measured by the Self-Construal Scale, the relationship between self-construal scores and neural responses to reflection of oneself and mother was significantly different between the two genotype groups. Specifically, l/l but not s/s genotype group showed significant association between self-construal scores and activity in the medial prefrontal cortex, bilateral middle frontal cortex, temporoparietal junction, insula and hippocampus during reflection on mental attributes of oneself and mother. Our findings suggest that a specific genetic polymorphism may interact with a cultural trait to shape the neural substrates underlying social cognition.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining neural activity during reflection on self and mother (social cognition: perception/understanding of self/others). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (self- and mother-reflection vs celebrity) using healthy adult participants (Chinese college students, final N=34, ages ~19.5 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (self- vs celebrity; mother- vs celebrity) and whole-brain regression/hierarchical analyses with coordinates and tables of activations (thresholds and correction procedures described), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample is healthy adults and results are reported for the healthy/control group. The study does not rely only on ROI, connectivity-only, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Impaired Right Temporoparietal Junction-Hippocampus Connectivity in Schizophrenia and Its Relevance for Generating Representations of Other Minds.
studies.abstract: Schizophrenia is associated with impaired and exaggerated Theory of Mind processes, pointing on alterations in generating a representation of another person's mind. Despite recent work on healthy subjects suggesting that a coupling between the right temporoparietal junction (rTPJ) and the hippocampus is relevant for building representations of others' intentions, the neural basis of related dysfunctions in patients with schizophrenia remains unclear. Therefore, we used structural and functional magnetic resonance imaging together with a modified prisoner's dilemma game to test the hypotheses, that patients show dysfunctional social updating on behavioral level accompanied by altered rTPJ-hippocampus coupling on a functional and a structural level. During the task, 31 patients with schizophrenia and 20 healthy controls interacted with 3 playing partners, who behaved according to stable strategies competitively, cooperatively, or randomly. Our data show that patients adapted their social behavior less flexibly to the playing partners than healthy controls, indicating differences in forming mental representations of the counterparts' intentions. Patients showed lower functional connectivity between the rTPJ and temporal lobe regions such as the hippocampus, the fusiform gyrus, and the middle temporal gyrus, indicating that in patients the rTPJ fails to integrate memory-informed processing streams during mental state inferences. Remarkably, the rTPJ-hippocampus coupling accounted for the participants' adaptive social behavior in the task, suggesting that a neural pathway relevant for updating social knowledge and forming forward predictions in social interactions is altered in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used task-based functional MRI (modified prisoner's dilemma) probing social/ToM processing and included a healthy control group (n=20). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy adult controls and task-based fMRI meets inclusion; include for full-text to confirm participant ages and other details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study using an interactive social decision-making task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) that probes social cognition/Theory of Mind. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=20, ages 23–45) reported separately from the clinical group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy group (e.g., COMP>CONT, COOP>CONT, RAND>CONT and TASK>CONT), with results presented in tables/figures and cluster-level corrected maps. The reported analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches; whole-brain activation maps for the healthy/control group are explicitly described and used in conjunction analyses. Age range and reporting meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: A failure to grasp the affective meaning of actions in autism spectrum disorder subjects.
studies.abstract: The ability to grasp emotional messages in everyday gestures and respond to them is at the core of successful social communication. The hypothesis that abnormalities in socio-emotional behavior in people with autism are linked to a failure to grasp emotional significance conveyed by gestures was explored. We measured brain activity using fMRI during perception of fearful or neutral actions and showed that whereas similar activation of brain regions known to play a role in action perception was revealed in both autistics and controls, autistics failed to activate amygdala, inferior frontal gyrus and premotor cortex when viewing gestures expressing fear. Our results support the notion that dysfunctions in this network may contribute significantly to the characteristic communicative impairments documented in autism.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of perception of emotional (fearful vs neutral) gestures — a social communication task. Abstract reports both autism and control groups, so includes healthy participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of fearful vs. neutral body actions—social communication/perception of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=12, adult males within the 17–65 range) reported separately alongside an ASD group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts for the control group (e.g., Dynamic vs. Static; Fearful vs. Neutral), with tables of coordinates and statistical maps (see Tables 2–4 and Figures), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neural correlates of pragmatic language comprehension in autism spectrum disorders.
studies.abstract: Difficulties with pragmatic aspects of communication are universal across individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASDs). Here we focused on an aspect of pragmatic language comprehension that is relevant to social interaction in daily life: the integration of speaker characteristics inferred from the voice with the content of a message. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), we examined the neural correlates of the integration of voice-based inferences about the speaker's age, gender or social background, and sentence content in adults with ASD and matched control participants. Relative to the control group, the ASD group showed increased activation in right inferior frontal gyrus (RIFG; Brodmann area 47) for speaker-incongruent sentences compared to speaker-congruent sentences. Given that both groups performed behaviourally at a similar level on a debriefing interview outside the scanner, the increased activation in RIFG for the ASD group was interpreted as being compensatory in nature. It presumably reflects spill-over processing from the language dominant left hemisphere due to higher task demands faced by the participants with ASD when integrating speaker characteristics and the content of a spoken sentence. Furthermore, only the control group showed decreased activation for speaker-incongruent relative to speaker-congruent sentences in right ventral medial prefrontal cortex (vMPFC; Brodmann area 10), including right anterior cingulate cortex (ACC; Brodmann area 24/32). Since vMPFC is involved in self-referential processing related to judgments and inferences about self and others, the absence of such a modulation in vMPFC activation in the ASD group possibly points to atypical default self-referential mental activity in ASD. Our results show that in ASD compensatory mechanisms are necessary in implicit, low-level inferential processes in spoken language understanding. This indicates that pragmatic language problems in ASD are not restricted to high-level inferential processes, but encompass the most basic aspects of pragmatic language processing.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of pragmatic/social language processing (integration of speaker characteristics and message content) in adults; includes a matched healthy control group (ages likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of pragmatic (social) language processing (integration of speaker characteristics and sentence content), clearly a social-related task (social communication, perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=24; ages 18–39). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts for the control group (within-group contrasts and whole-brain analyses with tables of significant clusters for speaker-incongruent > speaker-congruent and speaker-congruent > speaker-incongruent; Tables 4 and 5 and Figures), not limited to ROI-only results. Although a clinical ASD group is also included, whole-brain results for the healthy control group are reported separately and meet the inclusion requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

studies.title: The Difference between Aesthetic Appreciation of Artistic and Popular Music: Evidence from an fMRI Study.
studies.abstract: To test the hypothesis that pleasure from artistic music is intellectual while that from popular music is physiological, this study investigated the different functional mechanisms between aesthetic appreciation of artistic and popular music using fMRI. 18 male non-musicians were scanned while they performed an aesthetic rating task for excerpts of artistic music, popular music and musical notes playing and singing (control). The rating scores of artistic and popular music excerpts were both significantly higher than that of control materials while the scores of them were not different. The fMRI results showed both artistic and popular conditions activated the VS and vmPFC, compared with control condition. When contrasted popular and artistic condition directly, we found popular music activated right putamen, while artistic music activated right mPFC. By parametric analysis, we found the activation of right putamen tracked the aesthetic ratings of popular music, whereas the BOLD signal in right mPFC tracked the aesthetic ratings of artistic music. These results indicate the reward induced by popular music is closer to a primary reward while that induced by artistic music is closer to a secondary reward. We also found artistic music activated ToM areas, including PCC/PC, arMFC and TPJ, when compared with popular music. And these areas also tracked aesthetic ratings of artistic music but not those of popular music. These results imply that the pleasure from former comes from cognitive empathy. In conclusion, this study gives clear neuronal evidences supporting the view that artistic music is of intelligence and social cognition involved while the popular music is of physiology.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI in healthy adult participants (male non-musicians) showing activation of ToM/social-cognition areas (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ) during aesthetic judgment; task implicates cognitive empathy/perception and understanding of others, meeting social-related processing criterion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=18 males, ages 18–24), using a task (listening to and rating musical excerpts) that produced task-evoked activations in brain regions linked to social cognition (DMN/ToM: arMFC, PCC/PC, temporal pole, TPJ/angular gyrus, hippocampus) and was interpreted by the authors as involving cognitive empathy and social-cognitive processes. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts (popular vs notes, artistic vs notes, and popular vs artistic) with tables/coordinates, cluster-level FDR correction and ROI follow-ups — not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants fall within the eligible adult age range. Although the task is aesthetic judgment rather than an explicit social-interaction paradigm, the authors explicitly link observed whole-brain activations to social-cognition/theory-of-mind processes, making the study relevant to social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Kinetics and Dose Dependency of Intranasal Oxytocin Effects on Amygdala Reactivity.
studies.abstract: Current neuroimaging perspectives on a variety of mental disorders emphasize dysfunction of the amygdala. The neuropeptide oxytocin (OXT), a key mediator in the regulation of social cognition and behavior, accumulates in cerebrospinal fluid after intranasal administration in macaques and humans and modulates amygdala reactivity in both species. However, the translation of neuromodulatory OXT effects to novel treatment approaches is hampered by the absence of studies defining the most effective dose and dose-response latency for targeting the amygdala.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports intranasal oxytocin effects on amygdala reactivity in humans and likely used neuroimaging; however it does not explicitly state the fMRI task or that participants performed a social-related task. Insufficient detail in abstract to determine task/social-processing criteria, so include for full-text review to confirm fMRI social task and participant details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI during a social-related emotional face recognition task (social perception/understanding of others). (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=116 males, mean age 24.7, within 17–65). (3) Reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical results (e.g., Fear>Neutral contrasts with voxelwise FWE-corrected results, whole-brain regression analyses), not limited to ROI-only analyses. (4) Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not only ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, or non-empirical). Therefore include.

studies.title: Altered brain activity and the effect of personality traits in excessive smartphone use during facial emotion processing.
studies.abstract: Excessive smartphone use is a phenomenon related to maladaptive smartphone use, leading to negative consequences. This study set out with the aim of assessing the effects of excessive smartphone use on behavioral and neural responses during facial emotional processing. We examined 25 excessive smartphone users and 27 normal control users using functional MRI during facial emotion processing and investigated Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System (BIS/BAS). The excessive smartphone use group (SP) showed neural deactivation in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) during the presentation of an angry face and emotional transition compared to that of the normal control group (NC). Additionally, the SP revealed neural deactivation of the superior temporal sulcus and temporo-parietal junction related to social interaction during emotional transition compared to the NC. We found that BAS-Reward Responsiveness level was correlated with behavioral responses during repeated happy faces related to emotional reward in SP compared to NC. It can thus be suggested that excessive smartphone use is likely to fail on cognitive control during emotional processing, and this impairment might be influenced on emotional processing related to social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used during facial emotion processing, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy control group of adults alongside excessive smartphone users, meeting the criterion of at least one healthy participant group. Abstract provides sufficient information to assess inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses task-based fMRI of facial emotion discrimination, a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). Participants include healthy adult controls (NC; ages 19–35) screened with a clinical interview. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task activation results and within-group contrasts for the control group (e.g., AH vs HH with FWE-corrected clusters reported), not only ROI or connectivity analyses. Methods and results present univariate, group-level whole-brain statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Age range and reporting meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Psychopathic traits and deception: functional magnetic resonance imaging study.
studies.abstract: There is relatively little existing information regarding the neural correlates of deception in individuals with psychopathic traits.
studies.journal: The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract mentions an fMRI study of deception (a social cognition construct) but gives insufficient detail about participant health status/ages and whether healthy adult controls were included. Include for full-text review to determine if healthy adults (17–65) participated and if the task meets social-processing criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (male, age 19–60) using a deception task that probes social cognition/understanding of others (deception, theory-of-mind-related processes). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain task contrasts (lie vs truth), thresholded maps and coordinates (Table 2/3, figures), and discusses whole-brain findings; results are generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes appropriate whole-brain univariate activation maps for the healthy group. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.
studies.full_text_path: /data/alejandro/projects/autonima-results/social-processing/ace_scrape/articles/html/The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science/19252152.html

studies.title: Neuronal correlates of altered empathy and social cognition in borderline personality disorder.
studies.abstract: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a severe psychiatric condition of undetermined brain underpinnings, which involves profound emotion regulation deficits and interpersonal impairment. To elucidate biopsychological markers of the disorder, we performed two studies: i.) assessing empathy and social cognition and ii.) measuring the psychophysical properties and functional brain correlates of empathic functioning in a total of fifty-one affected patients and 50 age- and gender-matched controls. In the behavioral study we applied the Multifaceted Empathy Test (MET), a new, ecologically valid measure to assess cognitive (i.e., social cognition) and emotional (i.e., empathic concern) empathy to a subset of participants. In the second study, functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging and skin conductance measurements were performed while participants took a scanner-adapted version of the MET. Patients with BPD showed impairments in cognitive and emotional empathy. Brain responses during cognitive empathy were significantly reduced in patients compared to controls in the left superior temporal sulcus and gyrus (STS/STG), where this reduction was associated with levels of intrusive symptomatology in the BPD group. During emotional empathy, patients with BPD exhibited greater brain activity than controls in the right middle insular cortex, a response that was associated with skin conductance responses in the patients. Results indicate that altered functioning of the STS/STG and insula represents pathophysiological mediators for reduced empathy in BPD, with an important role for intrusive symptomatology and levels of arousal. The findings thus support a conceptualization of BPD as involving deficits in both inferring others' mental states and being emotionally attuned to another person.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (Multifaceted Empathy Test) assessing cognitive and emotional empathy. The sample includes 50 age- and gender-matched healthy control participants alongside BPD patients (adult participants). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion: fMRI during social processing task with a healthy adult group.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (Multifaceted Empathy Test) probing cognitive and emotional empathy. It includes a healthy adult control group (female controls, ages in the reported range ~27–33). The paper reports univariate, whole-brain, task-evoked group-level activation results for the control group (see Tables 5 and 6 and accompanying text showing main effects of cognitive and emotional empathy in control subjects with MNI coordinates). Analyses used standard GLM-based whole-brain approaches (FSL) and report voxelwise activations generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets the review’s inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult whole-brain results). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or missing healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

studies.title: Traumatic brain injury affects the frontomedian cortex--an event-related fMRI study on evaluative judgments.
studies.abstract: Traumatic brain injuries represent the leading cause of death and disability in young adults in industrialized countries. Recently, it has been suggested that dysfunctions of the frontomedian cortex, which enables social cognition, are responsible for clinical deficits in the long-term. To validate this hypothesis, we examined brain activation in seven young adults suffering from diffuse axonal injury during a cognitive task that specifically depends on frontomedian structures, namely evaluative judgments, contrasted with semantic memory retrieval. Brain activation in patients was compared with healthy age and gender matched control subjects using event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging. Evaluative judgments were related to a neural network discussed in the context of self-referential processing and theory of mind. More precisely, the neural network consisted of frontomedian regions, the temporal pole, and the posterior superior temporal gyrus and sulcus/angular gyrus. Patients showed higher activations in this network and the inferior frontal gyrus, whereas healthy control subjects activated more dopaminergic structures, namely the ventral tegmental area, during evaluative judgments. One possible interpretation of the data is that deficits in the ventral tegmental area, and consequently the mesocorticolimbic projection system, have to be compensated for by higher brain activations in the frontomedian and anterior cingulate cortex in patients with diffuse axonal injury. In conclusion, our study supports the hypothesis that traumatic brain injury is characterized by frontomedian dysfunctions, which may be responsible for clinical deficits in the long-term and which might be modified by rehabilitative strategies in the future.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI study of evaluative judgments—a social-cognitive task involving self-referential processing/theory of mind. Abstract explicitly reports healthy age- and gender-matched control subjects described as young adults (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study of evaluative judgments (self-referential/social-cognition task) that falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=7, mean age 26.4±4.6, within 17–65) reported separately from the patient group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate activation results for the control group (one-sample t-test; threshold z>3.10) with coordinates and cluster information (Table 3 and figures), satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. It is empirical original fMRI work (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Separable and Replicable Neural Strategies During Social Brain Function in People With and Without Severe Mental Illness.
studies.abstract: Case-control study design and disease heterogeneity may impede biomarker discovery in brain disorders, including serious mental illnesses. To identify biologically and/or behaviorally driven as opposed to diagnostically driven subgroups of individuals, the authors used hierarchical clustering to identify individuals with similar patterns of brain activity during a facial imitate/observe functional MRI task.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI facial imitate/observe task (social processing) and includes people 'with and without severe mental illness', indicating a healthy control group is present. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used task-based fMRI during a social-related imitate/observe facial-emotion task (social processes domain). The sample includes healthy adult participants (controls age 18–55) reported separately within the study (discovery and independent replication samples include healthy control groups). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (imitate > observe) analyzed with voxelwise approaches and threshold-free cluster enhancement, including group analyses run separately by site and diagnostic group (supplementary figures/tables show group maps), providing whole-brain, generalizable healthy-group activation results. The study is empirical, within the target age range, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and reports appropriate whole-brain task activation maps for controls, so it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Emotional prosody processing in autism spectrum disorder.
studies.abstract: Individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) are characterized by severe deficits in social communication, whereby the nature of their impairments in emotional prosody processing have yet to be specified. Here, we investigated emotional prosody processing in individuals with ASD and controls with novel, lifelike behavioral and neuroimaging paradigms. Compared to controls, individuals with ASD showed reduced emotional prosody recognition accuracy on a behavioral task. On the neural level, individuals with ASD displayed reduced activity of the STS, insula and amygdala for complex vs basic emotions compared to controls. Moreover, the coupling between the STS and amygdala for complex vs basic emotions was reduced in the ASD group. Finally, groups differed with respect to the relationship between brain activity and behavioral performance. Brain activity during emotional prosody processing was more strongly related to prosody recognition accuracy in ASD participants. In contrast, the coupling between STS and anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) activity predicted behavioral task performance more strongly in the control group. These results provide evidence for aberrant emotional prosody processing of individuals with ASD. They suggest that the differences in the relationship between the neural and behavioral level of individuals with ASD may account for their observed deficits in social communication.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of emotional prosody (social communication) comparing ASD participants and healthy controls; meets criterion of social-related task and includes a healthy control group. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study includes a healthy adult control group (n=22 behavioral; n=21 fMRI; ages 20–46), uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (emotional prosody processing — perception/understanding of others), and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation results for controls (e.g., emotional vs neutral prosody contrasts, conjunction maps, FWE cluster-corrected whole-brain results). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper also reports voxelwise effective connectivity (PPI) but importantly provides whole-brain task activation maps for the control group, not limited to ROI-only analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

studies.title: Social cognition, the male brain and the autism spectrum.
studies.abstract: Behavioral studies have shown that, at a population level, women perform better on tests of social cognition and empathy than men. Furthermore Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASDs), which are characterized by impairments in social functioning and empathy, occur more commonly in males than females. These findings have led to the hypothesis that differences in the functioning of the social brain between males and females contribute to the greater vulnerability of males to ASD and the suggestion that ASD may represent an extreme form of the male brain. Here we sought to investigate this hypothesis by determining: (i) whether males and females differ in social brain function, and (ii) whether any sex differences in social brain function are exaggerated in individuals with ASD. Using fMRI we show that males and females differ markedly in social brain function when making social decisions from faces (compared to simple sex judgements) especially when making decisions of an affective nature, with the greatest sex differences in social brain activation being in the inferior frontal cortex (IFC). We also demonstrate that this difference is exaggerated in individuals with ASD, who show an extreme male pattern of IFC function. These results show that males and females differ significantly in social brain function and support the view that sex differences in the social brain contribute to the greater vulnerability of males to ASDs.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social cognition (social decisions from faces; affective processing) including healthy male and female participants and an ASD group. Fits inclusion: social-related task and healthy participants present. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm ages (17–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (approachability and intelligence judgements from faces) in healthy adults (47 controls, ages ~32, within 17–65). Group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts for the healthy/control groups are reported (social vs gender contrasts; SPM2 analyses, voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level correction; coordinates and figures provided). Although a clinical ASD group is also included, healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level activation maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: An integrative model of the neural systems supporting the comprehension of observed emotional behavior.
studies.abstract: Understanding others' emotions requires both the identification of overt behaviors ("smiling") and the attribution of behaviors to a cause ("friendly disposition"). Previous research suggests that whereas emotion identification depends on a cortical mirror system that enables the embodiment of observed motor behavior within one's own motor system, causal attribution for emotion depends on a separate cortical mentalizing system, so-named because its function is associated with mental state representation. We used fMRI to test an Identification-Attribution model of mirror and mentalizing system contributions to the comprehension of emotional behavior. Normal volunteers watched a set of ecologically valid videos of human emotional displays. During each viewing, volunteers either identified an emotion-relevant motor behavior (explicit identification) or inferred a plausible social cause (explicit attribution). These explicit identification and attribution goals strongly distinguished activity in the mirror and mentalizing systems, respectively. However, frontal mirror areas, though preferentially engaged by the identification goal, nevertheless exhibited activation when observers possessed the attribution goal. One of these areas-right posterior inferior frontal gyrus-demonstrated effective connectivity with areas of the mentalizing system during attributional processing. These results support an integrative model of the neural systems supporting the comprehension of emotional behavior, where the mirror system helps facilitate the rapid identification of emotional expressions that then serve as inputs to attributional processing in the mentalizing system.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy (‘‘normal volunteers’’) participants performing social-cognitive tasks (identifying emotions and attributing social causes). This addresses perception/understanding of others and meets inclusion; not a review. Full text can confirm participant ages if needed.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition (emotion understanding/attribution) in healthy adults (N=22, ages 19–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (How>Why, Why>How) with tables of MNI coordinates and FDR-corrected results, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task is social (perception and understanding of others). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, includes healthy adult group results, not only connectivity or between-group contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Compassion-based emotion regulation up-regulates experienced positive affect and associated neural networks.
studies.abstract: Emotion regulation research has primarily focused on techniques that attenuate or modulate the impact of emotional stimuli. Recent evidence suggests that this mode regulation can be problematic in the context of regulation of emotion elicited by the suffering of others, resulting in reduced emotional connectedness. Here, we investigated the effects of an alternative emotion regulation technique based on the up-regulation of positive affect via Compassion-meditation on experiential and neural affective responses to depictions of individuals in distress, and compared these with the established emotion regulation strategy of Reappraisal. Using fMRI, we scanned 15 expert practitioners of Compassion-meditation either passively viewing, or using Compassion-meditation or Reappraisal to modulate their emotional reactions to film clips depicting people in distress. Both strategies effectively, but differentially regulated experienced affect, with Compassion primarily increasing positive and Reappraisal primarily decreasing negative affect. Imaging results showed that Compassion, relative to both passive-viewing and Reappraisal increased activation in regions involved in affiliation, positive affect and reward processing including ventral striatum and medial orbitfrontal cortex. This network was shown to be active prior to stimulus presentation, suggesting that the regulatory mechanism of Compassion is the stimulus-independent endogenous generation of positive affect.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult practitioners using compassion-meditation and reappraisal while viewing others in distress—addresses social/affiliative processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI study using a social-affective task (film clips of people in distress) in a healthy adult sample (n=15, ages 45–62). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Watch-Negative > Watch-Neutral; Compassion > Watch-Negative; Reappraisal > Watch-Negative) with cluster-level FWE correction, presented in tables/figures and described in text. Not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly reported. Although participants are expert meditators (a specialized healthy subgroup), they are within the eligible age range and reported separately. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: Neural correlates of second-language communication and the effect of language anxiety.
studies.abstract: Communicative speech is a type of language use that involves goal-directed action targeted at another person based on social interactive knowledge. Previous studies regarding one's first language (L1) have treated the theory of mind system, which is associated with understanding others, and the sensorimotor system, which is associated with action simulation, as important contributors to communication. However, little is known about the neural basis of communication in a second language (L2), which is limited in terms of its use as a communication tool. In this fMRI study, we manipulated the type of speech (i.e., communication vs. description) and the type of language (L1 vs. L2) to identify the specific brain areas involved in L2 communication. We also attempted to examine how the cortical mechanisms underlying L2 speech production are influenced by oral proficiency and anxiety regarding L2. Thirty native Japanese speakers who had learned English as an L2, performed communicative and descriptive speech-production tasks in both L1 and L2 while undergoing fMRI scanning. We found that the only the L2 communication task recruited the left posterior supramarginal gyrus (pSMG), which may be associated with the action simulation or prediction involved in generating goal-directed actions. Furthermore, the neural mechanisms underlying L2 communication, but not L2 description, were sensitive to both oral proficiency and anxiety levels; a) activation in the left middle temporal gyrus (MTG) increased as oral proficiency levels increased, and b) activation in the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC), including the left insula, decreased as L2 anxiety levels increased. These results reflect the successful retrieval of lexical information in a pragmatic context and an inability to monitor social behaviors due to anxiety. Taken together, the present results suggest that L2 communication relies on social skills and is mediated by anxiety and oral proficiency.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining social communication (L2 communicative speech vs description) in a group of healthy adult native Japanese speakers. Task involves social interaction/theory-of-mind and communication processes, meeting the review’s social-related fMRI criterion. Not a review article.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (30 native Japanese speakers) that manipulated communicative vs descriptive speech in L1 and L2 — a social-communication task relevant to the review’s scope (Social Communication). The abstract reports group-level task-evoked activation results (e.g., left posterior supramarginal gyrus, left MTG, OFC/insula), consistent with univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants are described as healthy adult native speakers; although exact ages are not provided in the abstract, the sample is presented as adult language learners and thus falls within the review’s target population. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups, non-empirical) appear to be violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI evidence of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Functional similarity of facial emotion processing between people with a first episode of psychosis and healthy subjects.
studies.abstract: Neurofunctional and behavioral abnormalities in facial emotion processing (FEmoP) have been consistently found in schizophrenia patients, but studies assessing brain functioning in early phases are scarce and the variety of experimental paradigms in current literature make comparisons difficult. The present work focuses on assessing FEmoP in people experiencing a psychotic episode for the first time with different experimental paradigm approaches.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The study examines facial emotion processing (a social cognition task) and includes healthy subjects alongside first-episode psychosis patients. The abstract refers to neurofunctional/brain functioning but does not explicitly state fMRI or participant ages; information is insufficient to confirm imaging modality or age range, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: the study used task-based fMRI of a social-related process (facial emotion processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (N=31; age range reported 19.68–36.39, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses for the healthy/control group (one-sample and paired t-tests; results reported in tables and text, e.g., Table 3 and supplemental within-group t-tests) with FWE-corrected whole-brain thresholds. It is empirical and provides whole-brain task activation maps/coordinate results for the healthy group, so it is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Perception of social cues of danger in autism spectrum disorders.
studies.abstract: Intuitive grasping of the meaning of subtle social cues is particularly affected in autism spectrum disorders (ASD). Despite their relevance in social communication, the effect of averted gaze in fearful faces in conveying a signal of environmental threat has not been investigated using real face stimuli in adults with ASD. Here, using functional MRI, we show that briefly presented fearful faces with averted gaze, previously shown to be a strong communicative signal of environmental danger, produce different patterns of brain activation than fearful faces with direct gaze in a group of 26 normally intelligent adults with ASD compared with 26 matched controls. While implicit cue of threat produces brain activation in attention, emotion processing and mental state attribution networks in controls, this effect is absent in individuals with ASD. Instead, individuals with ASD show activation in the subcortical face-processing system in response to direct eye contact. An effect of differences in looking behavior was excluded in a separate eye tracking experiment. Our data suggest that individuals with ASD are more sensitive to direct eye contact than to social signals of danger conveyed by averted fearful gaze.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI study examining perception of social cues (fearful faces with gaze) — a social-related task — that includes a matched healthy adult control group in addition to ASD participants. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social perception (fearful faces with gaze direction) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, mean age 23.7±5.9) reported separately from the ASD group. The paper presents whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked group analyses for the control group (within-group contrasts such as AVERTED>DIRECT and AVERTED>FIXATION) with thresholding, TFCE/FWE correction, and reported activation maps/tables. The task is clearly social (perception/understanding of others). Thus all inclusion criteria are met (fMRI social task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain univariate group-level results generalizable to healthy adults). No exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: An event related functional magnetic resonance imaging study of facial emotion processing in Asperger syndrome.
studies.abstract: People with Asperger syndrome (AS) have life-long deficits in social behavior. The biological basis of this is unknown, but most likely includes impaired processing of facial emotion. Human social communication involves processing different facial emotions, and at different intensities. However nobody has examined brain function in people with AS when implicitly (unconsciously) processing four primary emotions at varying emotional intensities.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of facial emotion processing (a social-related task). Abstract does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included; insufficient information to rule out presence of healthy participants. Include for full-text review to confirm sample composition and eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This paper reports event-related fMRI of implicit facial emotion processing (a clearly social task) including a separate healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age ~27, within 17–65). The manuscript provides group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts for the control group (face vs fixation; emotion intensity trends; tables of coordinates and figures), and reports activations generalizable to healthy adults. It therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample reported separately, whole-brain univariate group maps presented). No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Acceptance versus reappraisal: Behavioral, autonomic, and neural effects.
studies.abstract: Emotion regulation (ER) is an important skill for well-being. Cognitive reappraisal is a goal-oriented cognitive change strategy. Acceptance involves decentering from immediate habits of reactivity, observing moment-to-moment shifts in thoughts, emotions, and sensations. These two regulation strategies are thought to have different effects on emotion; however, no study has examined the differential effects of reappraisal and acceptance on behavioral, autonomic, and brain responses in the context of ideographic personally salient negative self-beliefs. Thirty-five right-handed, healthy adults were presented idiographic negative self-beliefs embedded in autobiographical scripts. We measured negative emotion ratings, autonomic psychophysiology, and functional magnetic resonance imaging blood oxygen-level dependent responses while participants read neutral statements, reacted to their own negative self-beliefs, and implemented reappraisal and acceptance strategies. Compared with react, reappraisal resulted in significantly lesser negative emotion and respiration rate; no differences in heart rate and skin conductance level; greater brain responses implicated in cognitive control, language, and social cognition; and lesser amygdala responses. Compared with react, acceptance resulted in significantly lesser negative emotion, respiration rate, and heart rate; no difference in skin conductance level; and greater brain responses in networks implicated in cognitive control and attention. Compared with acceptance, reappraisal resulted in significantly lesser negative emotion; no difference in respiration rate and skin conductance level; higher heart rate; greater brain responses in brain regions implicated in cognitive control; and lesser brain responses in amygdala. Reappraisal is more effective than acceptance in down-regulating negative emotion, but may require greater recruitment of autonomic, cognitive, and brain resources. ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT02036658.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI while participants processed idiographic negative self-beliefs and implemented reappraisal/acceptance—tasks probing perception/understanding of self (a social-related construct). Sample consisted of healthy adult participants and the abstract reports task-based BOLD responses. Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=35, ages 22.6–55.4) that investigates emotion regulation during participant-generated autobiographical social situations (social embarrassment/shame) — a social-related task involving perception/understanding of self. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (react vs neutral; reappraisal vs react; acceptance vs react; direct contrasts) with cluster-corrected voxelwise results, tables and figures, and an a priori amygdala ROI supplement. All inclusion criteria are met (social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level maps reported). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: Effective connectivity of brain regions underlying third-party punishment: Functional MRI and Granger causality evidence.
studies.abstract: Third-party punishment (TPP) for norm violations is an essential deterrent in large-scale human societies, and builds on two essential cognitive functions: evaluating legal responsibility and determining appropriate punishment. Despite converging evidence that TPP is mediated by a specific set of brain regions, little is known about their effective connectivity (direction and strength of connections). Applying parametric event-related functional MRI in conjunction with multivariate Granger causality analysis, we asked healthy participants to estimate how much punishment a hypothetical perpetrator deserves for intentionally committing criminal offenses varying in levels of harm. Our results confirmed that TPP legal decisions are based on two domain-general networks: the mentalizing network for evaluating legal responsibility and the central-executive network for determining appropriate punishment. Further, temporal pole (TP) and dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (PFC) emerged as hubs of the mentalizing network, uniquely generating converging output connections to ventromedial PFC, temporo-parietal junction, and posterior cingulate. In particular, dorsomedial PFC received inputs only from TP and both its activation and its connectivity to dorsolateral PFC correlated with degree of punishment. This supports the hypothesis that dorsomedial PFC acts as the driver of the TPP activation pattern, leading to the decision on the appropriate punishment. In conclusion, these results advance our understanding of the organizational elements of the TPP brain networks and provide better insights into the mental states of judges and jurors tasked with blaming and punishing legal wrongs.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy participants performing a third-party punishment task tapping mentalizing and evaluation of others (social cognition). Fits social-related processing criteria. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria. The study uses task-based fMRI probing a social cognition construct (third-party punishment/mentalizing and social decision-making). Sample: 26 healthy adult participants (mean age 26), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (GLM contrast Decision Phase: Experimental > Control) with whole-brain FDR-corrected maps (q(FDR)<0.05) and tables/coordinates, plus a parametric modulation cluster-level correction—thus providing whole-brain voxelwise activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Although the paper also reports effective connectivity (GCA), it additionally provides the required univariate whole-brain healthy-group task effects. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported). Therefore include.

studies.title: Human cortical activity evoked by contextual processing in attentional orienting.
studies.abstract: The ability to assess another person's direction of attention is paramount in social communication, many studies have reported a similar pattern between gaze and arrow cues in attention orienting. Neuroimaging research has also demonstrated no qualitative differences in attention to gaze and arrow cues. However, these studies were implemented under simple experiment conditions. Researchers have highlighted the importance of contextual processing (i.e., the semantic congruence between cue and target) in attentional orienting, showing that attentional orienting by social gaze or arrow cues could be modulated through contextual processing. Here, we examine the neural activity of attentional orienting by gaze and arrow cues in response to contextual processing using functional magnetic resonance imaging. The results demonstrated that the influence of neural activity through contextual processing to attentional orienting occurred under invalid conditions (when the cue and target were incongruent versus congruent) in the ventral frontoparietal network, although we did not identify any differences in the neural substrates of attentional orienting in contextual processing between gaze and arrow cues. These results support behavioural data of attentional orienting modulated by contextual processing based on the neurocognitive architecture.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI study examining attentional orienting to gaze cues (social communication/perception of others). Abstract reports fMRI neural activity related to social cues and does not indicate clinical populations. Participant ages not specified—include for full-text review to confirm demographics and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based fMRI in a sample of healthy adults (22 participants aged ~23), using a social attention paradigm (gaze vs arrow cueing) that probes social perception/communication processes. The paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses (whole-brain FWE-corrected thresholds and reported clusters; peak coordinates/tables and figures), and additionally reports ROI/SVC results. All inclusion criteria are satisfied: (1) fMRI during a social-related task, (2) healthy adult sample within 17–65, (3) group-level whole-brain task-evoked univariate maps are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and empirical data are provided). Therefore the study should be included.

studies.title: Cognitive regulation alters social and dietary choice by changing attribute representations in domain-general and domain-specific brain circuits.
studies.abstract: Are some people generally more successful using cognitive regulation or does it depend on the choice domain? Why? We combined behavioral computational modeling and multivariate decoding of fMRI responses to identify neural loci of regulation-related shifts in value representations across goals and domains (dietary or altruistic choice). Surprisingly, regulatory goals did not alter integrative value representations in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex, which represented all choice-relevant attributes across goals and domains. Instead, the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) flexibly encoded goal-consistent values and predicted regulatory success for the majority of choice-relevant attributes, using attribute-specific neural codes. We also identified domain-specific exceptions: goal-dependent encoding of prosocial attributes localized to precuneus and temporo-parietal junction (not DLPFC). Our results suggest that cognitive regulation operated by changing specific attribute representations (not integrated values). Evidence of domain-general and domain-specific neural loci reveals important divisions of labor, explaining when and why regulatory success generalizes (or doesn't) across contexts and domains.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI study examining altruistic (prosocial) choice and neural encoding in regions (precuneus, TPJ) implicated in social cognition. It uses healthy adult participants likely, but participant age/health not specified in abstract. Meets the review objective (social-related processing). Include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics and ages.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used task-based fMRI including an altruism paradigm (choices affecting self and an anonymous partner), which directly probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others and social decision-making). Participants were healthy adults (N=55 for altruism; subset N=37 for food), ages within 17–65. The paper reports whole-brain voxelwise GLMs (trial-wise choice regressors) and refers to conventional univariate analyses (Appendix 1 – Univariate Analysis of fMRI Data), and presents group-level voxelwise results and cluster coordinates (conjunctions, MNI coordinates) for neural effects; these meet the requirement for group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps (reported in main text and supplementary material). The study does not restrict results to ROIs only, nor is it solely connectivity or resting-state. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: The shaping of social perception by stimulus and knowledge cues to human animacy.
studies.abstract: Although robots are becoming an ever-growing presence in society, we do not hold the same expectations for robots as we do for humans, nor do we treat them the same. As such, the ability to recognize cues to human animacy is fundamental for guiding social interactions. We review literature that demonstrates cortical networks associated with person perception, action observation and mentalizing are sensitive to human animacy information. In addition, we show that most prior research has explored stimulus properties of artificial agents (humanness of appearance or motion), with less investigation into knowledge cues (whether an agent is believed to have human or artificial origins). Therefore, currently little is known about the relationship between stimulus and knowledge cues to human animacy in terms of cognitive and brain mechanisms. Using fMRI, an elaborate belief manipulation, and human and robot avatars, we found that knowledge cues to human animacy modulate engagement of person perception and mentalizing networks, while stimulus cues to human animacy had less impact on social brain networks. These findings demonstrate that self-other similarities are not only grounded in physical features but are also shaped by prior knowledge. More broadly, as artificial agents fulfil increasingly social roles, a challenge for roboticists will be to manage the impact of pre-conceived beliefs while optimizing human-like design.
studies.journal: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an original fMRI experiment in which healthy participants viewed human and robot avatars with belief manipulation, probing person perception and mentalizing (social cognition). This fits the review objective (fMRI of social processing in healthy adults). Not a systematic review/meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an original fMRI study with healthy adult participants (final N=23, mean age 26.4, right-handed, within 17–65). The task probes social perception (animacy, action observation, mentalizing) during event-related fMRI. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (main effects of agent form and belief manipulation, and interactions) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level corrections; peak coordinates and cluster tables are provided. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity only. Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: A look at actions: direct gaze modulates functional connectivity of the right TPJ with an action control network.
studies.abstract: Social signals such as eye contact and motor actions are essential elements of social interactions. However, our knowledge about the interplay of gaze signals and the control of actions remains limited. In a group of 30 healthy participants, we investigated the effect of gaze (direct gaze vs averted) on behavioral and neural measures of action control as assessed by a spatial congruency task (spatially congruent vs incongruent button presses in response to gaze shifts). Behavioral results demonstrate that inter-individual differences in condition-specific incongruency costs were associated with autistic traits. While there was no interaction effect of gaze and action control on brain activation, in a context of incongruent responses to direct gaze shifts, a psychophysiological interaction analysis showed increased functional coupling between the right temporoparietal junction, a key region in gaze processing, and the inferior frontal gyri, which have been related to both social cognition and motor inhibition. Conversely, incongruency costs to averted gaze were reflected in increased connectivity with action control areas implicated in top-down attentional processes. Our findings indicate that direct gaze perception inter-individually modulates motor actions and enforces the functional integration of gaze-related social cognition and action control processes, thereby connecting functional elements of social interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing a social-related gaze/action control task (direct vs averted gaze; social cognition and action control). Fits constructs of social perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of social processing (direct vs. averted gaze; social cognition, perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (n=30; ages 19–41). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (main effects and contrasts of congruency and gaze) using voxelwise statistics with cluster-forming and FWE correction and provides coordinates/tables and figures of activation maps; thus whole-brain evidence is available. Although the study also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally reports univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group. Participants are within the required age range and results for the healthy sample are reported. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, empirical original fMRI data). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Technology, expertise and social cognition in human evolution.
studies.abstract: Paleolithic stone tools provide concrete evidence of major developments in human behavioural and cognitive evolution. Of particular interest are evolving cognitive mechanisms implied by the cultural transmission of increasingly complex prehistoric technologies, hypothetically including motor resonance, causal reasoning and mentalizing. To test the relevance of these mechanisms to specific Paleolithic technologies, we conducted a functional magnetic resonance imaging study of Naïve, Trained and Expert subjects observing two toolmaking methods of differing complexity and antiquity: the simple 'Oldowan' method documented by the earliest tools 2.5 million years ago; and the more complex 'Acheulean' method used to produce refined tools 0.5 million years ago. Subjects observed 20-s video clips of an expert demonstrator, followed by behavioural tasks designed to maintain attention. Results show that observational understanding of Acheulean toolmaking involves increased demands for the recognition of abstract technological intentions. Across subject groups, Acheulean compared with Oldowan toolmaking was associated with activation of left anterior intraparietal and inferior frontal sulci, indicating the relevance of resonance mechanisms. Between groups, Naïve subjects relied on bottom-up kinematic simulation in the premotor cortex to reconstruct unfamiliar intentions, and Experts employed a combination of familiarity-based sensorimotor matching in the posterior parietal cortex and top-down mentalizing involving the medial prefrontal cortex. While no specific differences between toolmaking technologies were found for Trained subjects, both produced frontal activation relative to Control, suggesting focused engagement with toolmaking stimuli. These findings support motor resonance hypotheses for the evolutionary origins of human social cognition and cumulative culture, directly linking these hypotheses with archaeologically observable behaviours in prehistory.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social cognition (mentalizing, motor resonance, recognition of others' intentions) while observing a demonstrator. Task clearly involves perception/understanding of others, meeting the review's inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Naïve n=11, Trained n=10, Expert n=5) that investigates observational understanding/ social cognition (perception and understanding of others, mentalizing) during toolmaking demonstrations. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Toolmaking vs Control; Acheulean vs Oldowan) with voxelwise statistical maps and tables of coordinates (FDR-corrected results, extent thresholds). Results for the healthy groups are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults (no clinical groups). The study uses task-based fMRI (not only ROI, connectivity, or resting-state), and provides whole-brain activation maps and coordinate tables. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Cerebral processing of social rejection in patients with borderline personality disorder.
studies.abstract: An intense fear of abandonment or rejection is a central feature of social relationships for individuals with borderline personality disorder (BPD). A total of 20 unmedicated BPD patients and 20 healthy participants (HC, matched for age and education) played a virtual ball-tossing game including the three conditions: exclusion, inclusion and a control condition with predefined game rules, whereas cerebral activity was assessed using functional magnetic resonance imaging. Subjective experiences of exclusion were assessed after each blocked condition. Both groups felt similarly excluded during the exclusion condition; however, BPD subjects felt more excluded than HC during the inclusion and control conditions. In all three conditions, BPD patients showed a stronger engagement of the dorsal anterior cingulate and medial prefrontal cortex. For HC, activation in several cerebral regions such as the insula and the precuneus differed depending on the interaction situation, whereas for BPD subjects activation in these regions was not modulated by experimental conditions. Subjects with BPD differed from HC in both their subjective reactions to and their neural processing of social interaction situations. Our data suggest that individuals with BPD have difficulty in discriminating between social situations, and tend to hypermentalize during social encounters that are not determined by the intentions of others.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was conducted during a social ball‑tossing (exclusion/inclusion) task assessing social interaction processing; the study includes a healthy control group. No exclusion criteria are met. Age range not specified in abstract but participants were matched for age, so include for full‑text review to confirm ages.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: the study uses task-based fMRI during a social interaction paradigm (cyberball) directly probing social exclusion/inclusion; includes a healthy adult control group (n=20, ages within adult range) with results reported separately; reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (main effect of condition, interaction effects, and a two-sample t-test for group effects) and refers to t-contrasts in the Supplementary Data, and the text describes within-group post-hoc activations for the healthy control group. The task and reported whole-brain results are relevant to social-related processing (affiliation/mentalizing). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are reported/described).
