These men also displayed a lack of startle potentiation while viewing fearful faces and showed reduced skin conductance response when greeting an unfamiliar experimenter in comparison with the control group. The current findings may be related to social cognition deficits reported previously in children and adults with the premutation. The aetiology for this dysfunction may be elevated FMR1 mRNA or reduced FMR1 protein that occurs in carriers with higher premutation CGG repeat alleles.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI paradigm measuring brain response to fearful faces (social-emotional processing) and includes a matched healthy control group of adult males. This meets inclusion criteria of fMRI during social-related task with at least one healthy adult group.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study uses task-based fMRI probing social-emotional face processing (fearful vs scrambled/calm faces), which is a social-related task. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; age range 26–55, mean ~39.8) reported separately from the clinical premutation group. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain task activation results for the control group (within-group contrasts and tables of peak coordinates, figures showing bilateral amygdala and other activations), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also includes a clinical premutation group, results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or absent healthy-group whole-brain map) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Representing Multiple Observed Actions in the Motor System.
studies.abstract: There is now converging evidence that others' actions are represented in the motor system. However, social cognition requires us to represent not only the actions but also the interactions of others. To do so, it is imperative that the motor system can represent multiple observed actions. The current fMRI study investigated whether this is possible by measuring brain activity from 29 participants while they observed 2 right hands performing sign language gestures. Three key results were obtained. First, brain activity in the premotor and parietal motor cortex was stronger when 2 hands performed 2 different gestures than when 1 hand performed a single gesture. Second, both individual observed gestures could be decoded from brain activity in the same 2 regions. Third, observing 2 different gestures compared with 2 identical gestures activated brain areas related to motor conflict, and this activity was correlated with parietal motor activity. Together, these results show that the motor system is able to represent multiple observed actions, and as such reveal a potential mechanism by which third-party social encounters could be processed in the brain.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants observing others' actions, addressing perception and understanding of others (social cognition/social communication). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract clearly reports task and healthy sample, meeting inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of action/interaction observation (social perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=29, ages 18–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Observation > Neutral; 2H DIFF > 2H SAME; Squeeze > No Squeeze) with FWE-corrected results, peak coordinates, figures, and tables—meeting the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy/control group. The task is an explicit social-related action observation paradigm (not resting-state or connectivity-only), and results for the healthy sample are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not connectivity-only; participants within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Social evaluations under conflict: negative judgments of conflicting information are easier than positive judgments.
studies.abstract: In the current study, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging to investigate how the brain facilitates social judgments despite evaluatively conflicting information. Participants learned consistent (positive or negative) and ambivalent (positive and negative) person information and were then asked to provide binary judgments of these targets in situations that either resolved conflict by prioritizing a subset of information or not. Self-report, decision time and brain data confirm that integrating contextual information into our evaluations of objects or people allows for nuanced (social) evaluations. The same mixed trait information elicited or failed to elicit evaluative conflict dependent on the situation. Crucially, we provide data suggesting that negative judgments are easier and may be considered the 'default' action when experiencing evaluative conflict: weaker activation in dorsolateral prefrontal cortex during trials of evaluative conflict was related to a greater likelihood of unfavorable judgments, and greater activation was related to more favorable judgments. Since negative outcome consequences are arguably more detrimental and salient, this finding supports the idea that additional regulation and a more active selection process are necessary to override an initial negative response to evaluatively conflicting information.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Task-based fMRI study investigating social judgments of persons (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports original experimental data (not a review) and likely involves healthy adult participants. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–29). The task is explicitly social (impression formation/decisions about target persons across situational contexts). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (multilevel whole-brain MLM and cluster-wise results with MNI coordinates and thresholding), along with ROI follow-ups — satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps from the healthy group. Participants are within the eligible adult age range and results are reported for the healthy sample. The study does not fall under any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a between-group-only contrast, and is original empirical data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Brain mechanisms of persuasion: how 'expert power' modulates memory and attitudes.
studies.abstract: Human behaviour is affected by various forms of persuasion. The general persuasive effect of high expertise of the communicator, often referred to as 'expert power', is well documented. We found that a single exposure to a combination of an expert and an object leads to a long-lasting positive effect on memory for and attitude towards the object. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we probed the neural processes predicting these behavioural effects. Expert context was associated with distributed left-lateralized brain activity in prefrontal and temporal cortices related to active semantic elaboration. Furthermore, experts enhanced subsequent memory effects in the medial temporal lobe (i.e. in hippocampus and parahippocampal gyrus) involved in memory formation. Experts also affected subsequent attitude effects in the caudate nucleus involved in trustful behaviour, reward processing and learning. These results may suggest that the persuasive effect of experts is mediated by modulation of caudate activity resulting in a re-evaluation of the object in terms of its perceived value. Results extend our view of the functional role of the dorsal striatum in social interaction and enable us to make the first steps toward a neuroscientific model of persuasion.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI to probe neural mechanisms of persuasion/expert influence, a social-related process (social interaction, trust, attitude). It reports primary neuroimaging results in humans and is not a review. Participant ages not specified in abstract, but the study involves healthy human subjects; include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (persuasion/expert influence) in healthy adult participants (young right-handed females, mean age 21.8). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation analyses (SME/SAE and expertise contrasts) with tables of coordinates and statistical maps; although ROIs/SVC were used for some hypotheses, whole-brain results are reported and discussed. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are clearly presented. The study is not connectivity-only, not a review, and includes original fMRI data generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Oxytocin promotes facial emotion recognition and amygdala reactivity in adults with asperger syndrome.
studies.abstract: The neuropeptide oxytocin has recently been shown to enhance eye gaze and emotion recognition in healthy men. Here, we report a randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that examined the neural and behavioral effects of a single dose of intranasal oxytocin on emotion recognition in individuals with Asperger syndrome (AS), a clinical condition characterized by impaired eye gaze and facial emotion recognition. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we examined whether oxytocin would enhance emotion recognition from facial sections of the eye vs the mouth region and modulate regional activity in brain areas associated with face perception in both adults with AS, and a neurotypical control group. Intranasal administration of the neuropeptide oxytocin improved performance in a facial emotion recognition task in individuals with AS. This was linked to increased left amygdala reactivity in response to facial stimuli and increased activity in the neural network involved in social cognition. Our data suggest that the amygdala, together with functionally associated cortical areas mediate the positive effect of oxytocin on social cognitive functioning in AS.
studies.journal: Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used to examine facial emotion recognition (a social cognitive task) and the study included a neurotypical adult control group alongside individuals with Asperger syndrome, meeting the requirement of at least one healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria apply.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (facial emotion recognition). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (14 males, mean age 23.6) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain results and tables of activated clusters) for the NT control group (e.g., inferior frontal gyrus and fusiform gyrus clusters), not only ROI analyses. The healthy-group maps and coordinates are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults, satisfying all inclusion criteria.
studies.full_text_path: /data/alejandro/projects/autonima-results/social-processing/ace_scrape/articles/html/html/Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology/24067301.html

studies.title: Superior temporal activation in response to dynamic audio-visual emotional cues.
studies.abstract: Perception of emotion is critical for successful social interaction, yet the neural mechanisms underlying the perception of dynamic, audio-visual emotional cues are poorly understood. Evidence from language and sensory paradigms suggests that the superior temporal sulcus and gyrus (STS/STG) play a key role in the integration of auditory and visual cues. Emotion perception research has focused on static facial cues; however, dynamic audio-visual (AV) cues mimic real-world social cues more accurately than static and/or unimodal stimuli. Novel dynamic AV stimuli were presented using a block design in two fMRI studies, comparing bimodal stimuli to unimodal conditions, and emotional to neutral stimuli. Results suggest that the bilateral superior temporal region plays distinct roles in the perception of emotion and in the integration of auditory and visual cues. Given the greater ecological validity of the stimuli developed for this study, this paradigm may be helpful in elucidating the deficits in emotion perception experienced by clinical populations.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI studies of emotion perception using dynamic audio-visual stimuli, a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). It describes fMRI block-design comparisons of emotional vs neutral and bimodal vs unimodal. The abstract does not state participant health status or ages; because it meets the review topic and may include healthy adults, include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of others’ emotional facial and prosodic cues — social communication/perception). Sample includes healthy adults (Study 1: N=10, ages 18–33; Study 2: N=5, ages 18–23) within the 17–65 range, reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts and maps (multiple whole-brain analyses and conjunctions are described; Tables 3–4 and figures show voxelwise peaks and cluster coordinates with thresholds p<.001/.0001 and statements like “Whole-brain analysis on group averaged maps”), not only ROI or connectivity results. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Predicting the brain activation pattern associated with the propositional content of a sentence: Modeling neural representations of events and states.
studies.abstract: Even though much has recently been learned about the neural representation of individual concepts and categories, neuroimaging research is only beginning to reveal how more complex thoughts, such as event and state descriptions, are neurally represented. We present a predictive computational theory of the neural representations of individual events and states as they are described in 240 sentences. Regression models were trained to determine the mapping between 42 neurally plausible semantic features (NPSFs) and thematic roles of the concepts of a proposition and the fMRI activation patterns of various cortical regions that process different types of information. Given a semantic characterization of the content of a sentence that is new to the model, the model can reliably predict the resulting neural signature, or, given an observed neural signature of a new sentence, the model can predict its semantic content. The models were also reliably generalizable across participants. This computational model provides an account of the brain representation of a complex yet fundamental unit of thought, namely, the conceptual content of a proposition. In addition to characterizing a sentence representation at the level of the semantic and thematic features of its component concepts, factor analysis was used to develop a higher level characterization of a sentence, specifying the general type of event representation that the sentence evokes (e.g., a social interaction versus a change of physical state) and the voxel locations most strongly associated with each of the factors. Hum Brain Mapp 38:4865-4881, 2017. © 2017 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of sentence comprehension that includes factors labeled 'social interaction' among event types, suggesting social-content processing. Abstract does not report participant health status or age range nor confirm that task specifically targeted social cognition. Insufficient details to rule out/include based on criteria, so include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and task relevance.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=7, ages 20–35). Task involved reading sentences that include social content (people, social interactions, social norms); factor analysis identifies a clear ‘people/social interactions’ dimension linked to specific brain regions. Whole-brain fMRI data were collected and group-level analyses/factor-derived voxel clusters and associated brain locations are reported (group-level results and voxel clusters across cortex; Supporting Information reported). The study reports task-evoked activation patterns generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: The "vegetarian brain": chatting with monkeys and pigs?
studies.abstract: An array of brain regions in the fronto-parietal and temporal lobes cooperates to process observation and execution of actions performed by other individuals. Using functional MRI, we hypothesized that vegetarians and vegans might show brain responses to mouth actions performed by humans, monkeys, and pigs different from omnivores. We scanned 20 omnivores, 19 vegetarians, and 21 vegans while watching a series of silent videos, which presented a single mouth action performed by a human, a monkey, and a pig. Compared to omnivores, vegetarians and vegans have increased functional connectivity between regions of the fronto-parietal and temporal lobes versus the cerebellum during observation of mouth actions performed by humans and, to the same degree, animals. Vegans also had increased connectivity with the supplementary motor area. During human mouth actions, increased amygdala activity in vegetarians and vegans was found. More critically, vegetarians recruited the right middle frontal gyrus and insula, which are involved in social mirroring, whereas vegans activated the left inferior frontal gyrus and middle temporal gyrus, which are part of the mirror neuron system. Monkey mouth actions triggered language network activity in both groups, which might be due to the attempt to decode monkey mouth gesture, with an additional recruitment of associative temporo-occipital areas in vegans, whereas pig mouth actions activated empathy-related regions, including the anterior cingulum. These results support the role of the action observation-execution matching system in social cognition, which enables us to interact not only with our conspecifics but also with species in phylogenetic proximity to humans.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI in healthy adult participants (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) during observation of mouth actions probing action observation/mirror neuron, empathy, and social cognition processes. Fits the review objective of social-related processing; not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text screening.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (observation of mouth actions/oral communicative actions) in healthy adults. Sample: 60 right-handed healthy participants (ages 18–60) meeting the age criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (within-group and between-group ANOVAs, paired t-tests) with results shown in tables of coordinates and FWE-corrected voxelwise thresholds. Whole-brain activations (e.g., IFG, MTG, amygdala, cerebellum) are reported clearly for the healthy groups. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: The role of the amygdala in naturalistic mentalising in typical development and in autism spectrum disorder.
studies.abstract: The substantial discrepancy between mentalising in experimental settings v. real-life social interactions hinders the understanding of the neural basis of real-life social cognition and of social impairments in psychiatric disorders.
studies.journal: The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract lacks methodological detail: it does not state whether an fMRI scan was used, the ages or health status of participants, or task specifics. Title suggests study of mentalising in typical development and autism (likely includes healthy controls and social-cognition tasks), but information is insufficient to determine eligibility from the abstract alone. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI use and participant ages/health.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of naturalistic social cognition (mentalising/ToM) using a task with dynamic film stimuli. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, ages 19–46) with results reported separately. The paper reports within-group whole-brain univariate task contrasts (ToM > physical inference) for the control group, with cluster-corrected whole-brain activations presented in figures and Table 3. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps) and does not violate any exclusion criteria.
studies.full_text_path: /data/alejandro/projects/autonima-results/social-processing/ace_scrape/articles/html/The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science/26585095.html

studies.title: Pruning or tuning? Maturational profiles of face specialization during typical development.
studies.abstract: Face processing undergoes significant developmental change with age. Two kinds of developmental changes in face specialization were examined in this study: specialized maturation, or the continued tuning of a region to faces but little change in the tuning to other categories; and competitive interactions, or the continued tuning to faces accompanied by decreased tuning to nonfaces (i.e., pruning).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract examines face processing (a social-related construct) but does not state fMRI use or participant ages. Because key inclusion criteria (fMRI during social task; healthy adults 17–65) cannot be confirmed from abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of face processing (social perception/Perception and Understanding of Others), using a face>object/texture localizer and passive viewing blocks. It includes a healthy adult sample (51 adults, ages 18–42) reported separately from children. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (face>object, face>texture) using mixed-effects FLAME analyses with cluster correction and presents whole-brain statistical maps and ROI definitions derived from those maps. The study is task-evoked, univariate, and provides healthy-group whole-brain activation results generalizable to adults, meeting all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Brain activations during judgments of positive self-conscious emotion and positive basic emotion: pride and joy.
studies.abstract: We aimed to investigate the neural correlates associated with judgments of a positive self-conscious emotion, pride, and elucidate the difference between pride and a basic positive emotion, joy, at the neural basis level using functional magnetic resonance imaging. Study of the neural basis associated with pride might contribute to a better understanding of the pride-related behaviors observed in neuropsychiatric disorders. Sixteen healthy volunteers were studied. The participants read sentences expressing joy or pride contents during the scans. Pride conditions activated the right posterior superior temporal sulcus and left temporal pole, the regions implicated in the neural substrate of social cognition or theory of mind. However, against our prediction, we did not find brain activation in the medial prefrontal cortex, a region responsible for inferring others' intention or self-reflection. Joy condition produced activations in the ventral striatum and insula/operculum, the key nodes of processing of hedonic or appetitive stimuli. Our results support the idea that pride is a self-conscious emotion, requiring the ability to detect the intention of others. At the same time, judgment of pride might require less self-reflection compared with those of negative self-conscious emotions such as guilt or embarrassment.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy volunteers (n=16) performing judgments of pride and joy during scanning. Tasks probe social cognition/theory of mind and perception/understanding of self/others, matching the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages ~21), using task-based paradigms assessing judgments of pride and joy (social/self-conscious and basic positive emotions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (pride vs neutral, joy vs neutral, pride vs joy) with voxelwise statistical maps reported as peak coordinates, tables, and figures, and regression analyses linking ratings to activations. The task addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of self and others/toM). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, not only between-group contrasts, participants are within 17–65). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: The anterior cingulate cortex: monitoring the outcomes of others' decisions.
studies.abstract: The ability to attribute mental states to others and understand the basis of their decisions is essential for human social interaction. A controversial theory states that this is achieved by simulating another's information processing in one's own neural circuits. The anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) is known to play an important role in the registration of discrepancies between the predicted and actual outcomes of decisions (prediction errors).When positive and negative feedback fails altogether, the failure may also signal errors in the prediction that the outcome of that decision would be informative and guide future decisions. Does the ACC signal that an outcome is unexpectedly uninformative? When an outcome directed to others is uninformative, do we understand their mental states by simulating them in the circuits of the ACC in our own brain? The aim of our study was to test for these two possibilities in the human brain with event-related fMRI. We tested whether the ACC processes errors in the prediction of informative feedback and whether the ACC is also activated when scanned subjects process the same outcomes of another's decisions. We show that each is processed by a separate subregion of the ACC.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI study examining processing of others' decision outcomes (social cognition/perception of others), matching review objective. Abstract does not state participant age range or explicit confirmation of healthy adults; insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify participant health/age.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=12, mean age 21) that explicitly investigates social cognition (monitoring/mentalizing about others' decisions). The authors report group-level, voxelwise second-level analyses (random-effects ANOVA, F-contrasts) and present SPM maps and peak coordinates for activations in the ACC (with small-volume correction applied to an anatomically defined ACC mask). Results are task-evoked, univariate, and reported for the healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range). Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Neuroanatomical substrates involved in unrelated false facial recognition.
studies.abstract: Identifying faces is a process central for social interaction and a relevant factor in eyewitness theory. False recognition is a critical mistake during an eyewitness's identification scenario because it can lead to a wrongful conviction. Previous studies have described neural areas related to false facial recognition using the standard Deese/Roediger-McDermott (DRM) paradigm, triggering related false recognition. Nonetheless, misidentification of faces without trying to elicit false memories (unrelated false recognition) in a police lineup could involve different cognitive processes, and distinct neural areas. To delve into the neural circuitry of unrelated false recognition, we evaluated the memory and response confidence of participants while watching faces photographs in an fMRI task. Functional activations of unrelated false recognition were identified by contrasting the activation on this condition vs. the activations related to recognition (hits) and correct rejections. The results identified the right precentral and cingulate gyri as areas with distinctive activations during false recognition events suggesting a conflict resulting in a dysfunction during memory retrieval. High confidence suggested that about 50% of misidentifications may be related to an unconscious process. These findings add to our understanding of the construction of facial memories and its biological basis, and the fallibility of the eyewitness testimony.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using a face-recognition task probing false facial recognition, which falls under ‘perception and understanding of others’ (social processing). The abstract reports task-based fMRI activations and does not indicate a patient-only sample or that it is a review. Meets inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria apparent.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, final N=17; ages 19–36). Task probes face perception/recognition (socially relevant: perception/understanding of others). Authors report group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts (differential activations for false recognition vs. hits/correct rejections) with cluster correction and Talairach coordinates; results presented as whole-brain maps/coordinates (not ROI-only). Age range and healthy-group reporting meet inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria (not connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore it qualifies for inclusion.

studies.title: Through your eyes or mine? The neural correlates of mental state recognition in Huntington's disease.
studies.abstract: Huntington's disease (HD) can impair social cognition. This study investigated whether patients with HD exhibit neural differences to healthy controls when they are considering mental and physical states relating to the static expressions of human eyes. Thirty-two patients with HD and 28 age-matched controls were scanned with fMRI during two versions of the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task: The standard version requiring mental state judgments, and a comparison version requiring judgments about age. HD was associated with behavioral deficits on only the mental state eyes task. Contrasting the two versions of the eyes task (mental state > age judgment) revealed hypoactivation within left middle frontal gyrus and supramarginal gyrus in HD. Subgroup analyses comparing premanifest HD patients to age-matched controls revealed reduced activity in right supramarginal gyrus and increased activity in anterior cingulate during mental state recognition in these patients, while manifest HD was associated with hypoactivity in left insula and left supramarginal gyrus. When controlling for the effects of healthy aging, manifest patients exhibited declining activation within areas including right temporal pole. Our findings provide compelling evidence for a selective impairment of internal emotional status when patients with HD appraise facial features in order to make social judgements. Differential activity in temporal and anterior cingulate cortices may suggest that poor emotion regulation and emotional egocentricity underlie impaired mental state recognition in premanifest patients, while more extensive mental state recognition impairments in manifest disease reflect dysfunction in neural substrates underlying executive functions, and the experience and interpretation of emotion.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) and includes an age-matched healthy control group (n=28). Participants are adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) that includes a healthy adult control group (age-matched; n=28). The task probes mental state/affective theory-of-mind (social perception). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level results and coordinates (Tables 2 and 3; figures and supporting information) including contrasts and comparisons involving the healthy control group and control subgroup effects. Although clinical HD groups are the primary focus, healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked results and comparisons are clearly reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Oxytocin Modulates Amygdala Reactivity to Masked Fearful Eyes.
studies.abstract: The amygdala reveals enhanced reactivity to fearful eye whites, even when they are backwardly masked by a neutral face and therefore processed with limited visual awareness. In our fMRI study, we investigated whether this effect is indeed associated with fear detection within the eyes of the neutral face mask, or more generally, with reactivity to any salient increase in eye white area. In addition, we examined whether a single dose of intranasal oxytocin would modulate amygdala responses to masked fearful eye whites via a double-blind, placebo-controlled pharmacological protocol. We found that increased amygdala responses to salient changes within a face's eye region occurred specifically for masked fearful eyes but not for similar increases in white area as induced by nonsocial control stimuli. Administration of oxytocin attenuated amygdala responses to masked fearful eye whites. Our results suggest that the amygdala is particularly tuned to potential threat signals from the eye region. The dampening effects of oxytocin on early amygdala reactivity may reflect reduced vigilance for facial threat cues at a preconscious level. Future studies may investigate whether this early modulation accounts for the beneficial effects of oxytocin on social cognition in anxiety-related disorders, as suggested by previous studies.
studies.journal: Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining amygdala responses to masked fearful eye whites (a social threat cue) and modulation by intranasal oxytocin, matching the review objective of social processing. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study of social perception (masked fearful vs happy eye whites) in healthy adult participants (initial N=50; analyzed N=43; ages ~24). The task probes social-related processing (perception of others’ emotional eye cues) and includes a standard group-level random-effects analysis. Although ROI/SVC analyses in the amygdala are reported, the paper also reports exploratory whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Fearful>Happy) with reported clusters (pulvinar, ACC, orbitofrontal cortex) and references to Supplementary Tables of whole-brain results. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.
studies.full_text_path: /data/alejandro/projects/autonima-results/social-processing/ace_scrape/articles/html/html/Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology/25881796.html

studies.title: Hyperfunctioning of the right posterior superior temporal sulcus in response to neutral facial expressions presents an endophenotype of schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Deficits in social cognition have been proposed as a marker of schizophrenia. Growing evidence suggests especially hyperfunctioning of the right posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS) in response to neutral social stimuli reflecting the neural correlates of social-cognitive impairments in schizophrenia. We characterized healthy participants according to schizotypy (n = 74) and the single-nucleotide polymorphism rs1344706 in ZNF804A (n = 73), as they represent risk variants for schizophrenia from the perspectives of personality traits and genetics, respectively. A social-cognitive fMRI task was applied to investigate the association of right pSTS hyperfunctioning in response to neutral face stimuli with schizotypy and rs1344706. Higher right pSTS activation in response to neutral facial expressions was found in individuals with increased positive (trend) and disorganization symptoms, as well as in carriers of the risk allele of rs1344706. In addition, a positive association between right-left pSTS connectivity and disorganization symptoms during neutral face processing was revealed. Although these findings warrant replication, we suggest that right pSTS hyperfunctioning in response to neutral facial expressions presents an endophenotype of schizophrenia. We assume that right pSTS hyperfunctioning is a vulnerability to perceive neutral social stimuli as emotionally or intentionally salient, probably contributing to the emergence of symptoms of schizophrenia.
studies.journal: Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used an fMRI social-cognitive task (neutral facial expressions) and included a sample of healthy participants (schizotypy/genetic groups). Meets review objective of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults. Age not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition in a sample of healthy adult participants using a task probing neutral face processing, emotion recognition, and affective theory-of-mind (social-related constructs). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task effects (one-sample t-tests and whole-brain contrasts) with a stated whole-brain significance threshold (p<0.05 FWE, k=10) and presents whole-brain results (figures and Supplementary Table). Although ROI and connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain, healthy-group task activation maps are clearly provided. Participants are healthy adults and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Distinct representations for facial identity and changeable aspects of faces in the human temporal lobe.
studies.abstract: The neural system underlying face perception must represent the unchanging features of a face that specify identity, as well as the changeable aspects of a face that facilitate social communication. However, the way information about faces is represented in the brain remains controversial. In this study, we used fMR adaptation (the reduction in fMRI activity that follows the repeated presentation of identical images) to ask how different face- and object-selective regions of visual cortex contribute to specific aspects of face perception. We report that activity in the face-selective region of the fusiform gyrus (FG) was reduced following repeated presentations of the same face. Adaptation in this area was not sensitive to changes in image size, but was sensitive to changes in viewpoint. In contrast, face-selective regions in the superior temporal lobe failed to adapt to identical presentations of the same face, but showed an increased response when the same face was shown from different viewpoints and with different expressions. These results reveal a largely size-invariant neural representation in the inferior temporal lobe that could be involved in the recognition of facial identity, and a separate face-selective region in the superior temporal lobe that could be used to detect changeable aspects of faces. The absence of fMR-adaptation in object-selective regions of visual cortex challenges the idea that a more distributed network of areas is used to represent information about faces.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating face perception and changeable aspects (viewpoint, expression) relevant to Social Communication. It reports fMRI adaptation in face-selective regions, indicating a social-related processing task in humans. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of face perception that explicitly manipulates changeable social aspects (gaze, expression, viewpoint)—tasks directly related to Social Communication/Perception of Others. Participants are healthy adult subjects (n=8) and results are reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses (FEAT Z-statistic images, thresholded maps, and Talairach coordinates in Table 1) for contrasts such as faces > objects and adaptation effects, providing whole-brain activation information (figures and coordinate tables). The study is empirical, not connectivity-only, and includes whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neural Mechanisms Underlying Affective Theory of Mind in Violent Antisocial Personality Disorder and/or Schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Among violent offenders with schizophrenia, there are 2 sub-groups, one with and one without, conduct disorder (CD) and antisocial personality disorder (ASPD), who differ as to treatment response and alterations of brain structure. The present study aimed to determine whether the 2 groups also differ in Theory of Mind and neural activations subsuming this task. Five groups of men were compared: 3 groups of violent offenders-schizophrenia plus CD/ASPD, schizophrenia with no history of antisocial behavior prior to illness onset, and CD/ASPD with no severe mental illness-and 2 groups of non-offenders, one with schizophrenia and one without (H). Participants completed diagnostic interviews, the Psychopathy Checklist Screening Version Interview, the Interpersonal Reactivity Index, authorized access to clinical and criminal files, and underwent functional magnetic resonance imaging while completing an adapted version of the Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Task (RMET). Relative to H, nonviolent and violent men with schizophrenia and not CD/ASPD performed more poorly on the RMET, while violent offenders with CD/ASPD, both those with and without schizophrenia, performed similarly. The 2 groups of violent offenders with CD/ASPD, both those with and without schizophrenia, relative to the other groups, displayed higher levels of activation in a network of prefrontal and temporal-parietal regions and reduced activation in the amygdala. Relative to men without CD/ASPD, both groups of violent offenders with CD/ASPD displayed a distinct pattern of neural responses during emotional/mental state attribution pointing to distinct and comparatively successful processing of social information.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used during a social cognition task (Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Task) and the study includes a non-offender healthy control group (H). Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, affective Theory of Mind). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=18; ages within 17–65) with results analyzed separately. The methods describe group-level, voxelwise whole-brain one-sample t tests for each of the five groups and second-level whole-brain between-group ANOVAs; reported whole-brain activation results and coordinates (cluster- and FWE-corrected) are provided in the paper (figures/tables and ROI follow-ups). The paper is empirical and not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for providing a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map suitable for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Lost for emotion words: what motor and limbic brain activity reveals about autism and semantic theory.
studies.abstract: Autism spectrum conditions (ASC) are characterised by deficits in understanding and expressing emotions and are frequently accompanied by alexithymia, a difficulty in understanding and expressing emotion words. Words are differentially represented in the brain according to their semantic category and these difficulties in ASC predict reduced activation to emotion-related words in limbic structures crucial for affective processing. Semantic theories view 'emotion actions' as critical for learning the semantic relationship between a word and the emotion it describes, such that emotion words typically activate the cortical motor systems involved in expressing emotion actions such as facial expressions. As ASC are also characterised by motor deficits and atypical brain structure and function in these regions, motor structures would also be expected to show reduced activation during emotion-semantic processing. Here we used event-related fMRI to compare passive processing of emotion words in comparison to abstract verbs and animal names in typically-developing controls and individuals with ASC. Relatively reduced brain activation in ASC for emotion words, but not matched control words, was found in motor areas and cingulate cortex specifically. The degree of activation evoked by emotion words in the motor system was also associated with the extent of autistic traits as revealed by the Autism Spectrum Quotient. We suggest that hypoactivation of motor and limbic regions for emotion word processing may underlie difficulties in processing emotional language in ASC. The role that sensorimotor systems and their connections might play in the affective and social-communication difficulties in ASC is discussed.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI examined processing of emotion words (social-affective semantic processing) and included typically-developing control participants. This addresses social-related processing in healthy adults. Age ranges are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm ages, but inclusion is warranted.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study includes a healthy adult control group (n=18; mean age ~28.6) and uses task-based fMRI to probe processing of emotion words — a social/emotion-related construct relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Other’. The paper reports voxelwise, whole-brain, task-evoked statistical results: FWE-corrected whole-brain contrasts (controls > ASC) identifying clusters (motor, insula, basal ganglia) with coordinates, and within-group analyses in the control sample showing emotion-word-specific activations (reported with statistics). These results are presented at the group level and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although several contrasts are reported as between-group (controls>ASC), the manuscript also provides control-related group effects and coordinates and thus supplies whole-brain univariate evidence from the healthy/control group. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Aberrant neural responses to social rejection in patients with schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Patients with schizophrenia often show abnormal social interactions, which may explain their social exclusion behaviors. This study aimed to elucidate patients' brain responses to social rejection in an interactive situation. Fifteen patients with schizophrenia and 16 healthy controls participated in the functional magnetic resonance imaging experiment with the virtual handshake task, in which socially interacting contents such as acceptance and refusal of handshaking were implemented. Responses to the refusal versus acceptance conditions were evaluated and compared between the two groups. Controls revealed higher activity in the refusal condition compared to the acceptance condition in the right superior temporal sulcus, whereas patients showed higher activity in the prefrontal regions, including the frontopolar cortex. In patients, contrast activities of the right superior temporal sulcus were inversely correlated with the severity of schizophrenic symptoms, whereas contrast activities of the left frontopolar cortex were positively correlated with the current anxiety scores. The superior temporal sulcus hypoactivity and frontopolar hyperactivity of patients with schizophrenia in social rejection situations may suggest the presence of mentalizing deficits in negative social situations and inefficient processes of socially aberrant stimuli, respectively. These abnormalities may be one of the neural bases of distorted or paranoid beliefs in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using a social-interaction task (virtual handshake) contrasting social acceptance vs refusal; includes a healthy control group (n=16) of adults. Meets inclusion criteria of social-related fMRI and presence of healthy participants. Not a review/meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study using a social-interactive 'virtual handshake' task that manipulates social acceptance vs. rejection (social-related processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=16; mean age ~27) reported separately from the schizophrenia group. The paper reports group-level, within-group whole-brain univariate contrasts for the healthy/control group (refusal > acceptance), with reported regions (right pSTS, right thalamus) and cluster/statistical thresholds; results are described in text/tables/figures and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although a clinical group is present, healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly provided. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes appropriate age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Neural correlates of social cooperation and non-cooperation as a function of psychopathy.
studies.abstract: Psychopathy is a disorder involving a failure to experience many emotions that are necessary for appropriate social behavior. In this study, we probed the behavioral, emotional, and neural correlates of psychopathic traits within the context of a dyadic social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract examines neural correlates of social cooperation/non-cooperation within a dyadic social interaction and psychopathic traits, implying fMRI during a social task and likely healthy adult participants. The abstract does not explicitly state ‘fMRI’ or participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and sample characteristics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social interaction (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (N=30, mean age 21.2). The task probes social cooperation/defection (affiliation/social decision-making), satisfying the social-related task requirement. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (random-effects and fixed-effects), thresholded maps and coordinate tables for within-group contrasts (e.g., choice C vs D; CC, CD, DC, DD vs others), and figures showing activations (including whole-brain voxelwise results and tables). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range age) are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: It's all in the eyes: subcortical and cortical activation during grotesqueness perception in autism.
studies.abstract: Atypical face processing plays a key role in social interaction difficulties encountered by individuals with autism. In the current fMRI study, the Thatcher illusion was used to investigate several aspects of face processing in 20 young adults with high-functioning autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and 20 matched neurotypical controls. "Thatcherized" stimuli were modified at either the eyes or the mouth and participants discriminated between pairs of faces while cued to attend to either of these features in upright and inverted orientation. Behavioral data confirmed sensitivity to the illusion and intact configural processing in ASD. Directing attention towards the eyes vs. the mouth in upright faces in ASD led to (1) improved discrimination accuracy; (2) increased activation in areas involved in social and emotional processing; (3) increased activation in subcortical face-processing areas. Our findings show that when explicitly cued to attend to the eyes, activation of cortical areas involved in face processing, including its social and emotional aspects, can be enhanced in autism. This suggests that impairments in face processing in autism may be caused by a deficit in social attention, and that giving specific cues to attend to the eye-region when performing behavioral therapies aimed at improving social skills may result in a better outcome.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining face processing (social and emotional aspects) using the Thatcher illusion; includes a matched neurotypical control group of young adults (healthy participants aged within 17–65). Task is social-related and meets inclusion criteria; not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study used a social-related face-processing task (Thatcher Illusion) probing social/emotional processing. It reports data from a healthy adult control group (NT; n=18, mean age ~25.8, within the 17–65 range) separately from the ASD group. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (upright vs. inverted) for the control group, including mixed-effects GLM (FLAME) results and thresholding (cluster Z>2.3, corrected p=0.05) and displays whole-brain activation maps and descriptions. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social task, healthy adult sample reported separately, and whole-brain task-evoked group results). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults).

studies.title: Direct gaze elicits atypical activation of the theory-of-mind network in autism spectrum conditions.
studies.abstract: Eye contact plays a key role in social interaction and is frequently reported to be atypical in individuals with autism spectrum conditions (ASCs). Despite the importance of direct gaze, previous functional magnetic resonance imaging in ASC has generally focused on paradigms using averted gaze. The current study sought to determine the neural processing of faces displaying direct and averted gaze in 18 males with ASC and 23 matched controls. Controls showed an increased response to direct gaze in brain areas implicated in theory-of-mind and gaze perception, including medial prefrontal cortex, temporoparietal junction, posterior superior temporal sulcus region, and amygdala. In contrast, the same regions showed an increased response to averted gaze in individuals with an ASC. This difference was confirmed by a significant gaze direction × group interaction. Relative to controls, participants with ASC also showed reduced functional connectivity between these regions. We suggest that, in the typical brain, perceiving another person gazing directly at you triggers spontaneous attributions of mental states (e.g. he is "interested" in me), and that such mental state attributions to direct gaze may be reduced or absent in the autistic brain.
authors: Elisabeth A H von dem Hagen
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social processing (direct vs averted gaze; theory-of-mind/gaze perception). Includes a matched control group of healthy participants. Abstract does not state exact ages but likely adult sample; meets inclusion of at least one healthy group performing a social-related task. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (gaze perception/communicative intent; theory-of-mind network), meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (male adults, reported separately from the ASC group). The paper reports group-level, univariate within-group contrasts for controls (e.g., controls: direct gaze > averted gaze) with coordinates and figures, and describes whole-brain contrasts (faces vs. null) that were FWE-corrected at the whole-brain level used to define control networks. Results for the healthy/control group are presented separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, task-based fMRI (not solely connectivity/ROI-only), so it satisfies all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

studies.title: The experience of social exclusion in women with a history of suicidal acts: a neuroimaging study.
studies.abstract: Suicidal behaviors result from a complex interaction between social stressors and individual vulnerability. However, little is known of the specific neural network supporting the sensitivity to social stressors in patients at risk of suicidal acts. Using functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging, we investigated brain processing of social rejection in suicide attempters. Thirty-six euthymic women with a history of depression and suicidal behavior were compared to 41 euthymic women with a history of depression but no suicidal attempt, and 28 healthy controls. The Cyberball Game was used as a validated social exclusion paradigm. Relative to healthy controls, both patient groups reported higher levels of social distress related to the task, without significant differences according to suicidal status. Compared to patients without any history of suicide attempt and healthy controls, suicide attempters showed decreased contrast in the left insula and supramarginal gyrus during the exclusion vs. inclusion condition, after controlling for number of depressive episodes, medication, mood disorder type or social phobia. Our study highlights impaired brain response to social exclusion in euthymic female suicide attempters in regions previously implicated in pain tolerance and social cognition. These findings suggest sustained brain dysfunctions related to social perception in suicide attempters.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion paradigm, directly assessing social processing. Includes a healthy control group (n=28) alongside clinical groups. Age range not reported in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the 17–65 criterion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study uses fMRI during a social-related task (the Cyberball social exclusion paradigm). It includes a healthy adult control group (HC; n=28) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate effects for the healthy controls (main effect of condition in HC: left anterior insula/inferior frontal gyrus) thresholded at voxelwise FWE-corrected p<0.05 with k≥10 voxels, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the sample is female-only, participants are healthy adults and the healthy-group whole-brain task activation is clearly presented, so the study meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neural basis of attributional style in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Attributional style means how people typically infer the causes of emotional behaviors. No study has shown neural basis of attributional style in schizophrenia, although it was suggested as a major area of social cognition research of schizophrenia. Fifteen patients with schizophrenia and 16 healthy controls underwent functional magnetic resonance imaging while performing three (happy, angry, and neutral) conditions of attribution task. Each condition included inferring situational causes of an avatar' (virtual character) emotional or neutral behavior. In the between-groups contrast maps of the happy conditions, the patient group compared to the control group showed decreased activations in the inferior frontal (BA 44) and the ventral premotor cortex (BA 6), in which the % signal changes were associated with negative symptoms. In the angry conditions, the patient group compared to the control group exhibited increased activations in the precuneus/posterior cingulate cortex (Pcu/PCC) (BA 7/31), in which the % signal changes were related to positive symptoms. In conclusion, patients with schizophrenia may have functional deficits in mirror neuron system when attributing positive behaviors, which may be related to a lack of inner simulation and empathy and negative symptoms. In contrast, patients may have increased activation in the Pcu/PCC related to self-representations while attributing negative behaviors, which may be related to failures in self- and source-monitoring and positive symptoms.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI was used while participants performed an attribution task (inferring causes of emotional behaviors) — a social cognition paradigm. The study includes a healthy control group (n=16). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social attribution (inferring situational causes of avatars’ emotional behaviors) that included a healthy adult control group (n=16). The authors performed whole-brain, voxelwise GLM analyses and report cluster coordinates and statistics (Table 1) and mean % signal changes for the control group, indicating healthy-group task-evoked univariate effects (e.g., significant positive % signal changes in IFG, VPMC, etc.). The task is a social-related process (attribution of others’ emotions) and results for the healthy/control group are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state only, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain task effect) apply. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: The neural correlates of persuasion: a common network across cultures and media.
studies.abstract: Persuasion is at the root of countless social exchanges in which one person or group is motivated to have another share its beliefs, desires, or behavioral intentions. Here, we report the first three functional magnetic resonance imaging studies to investigate the neurocognitive networks associated with feeling persuaded by an argument. In the first two studies, American and Korean participants, respectively, were exposed to a number of text-based persuasive messages. In both Study 1 and Study 2, feeling persuaded was associated with increased activity in posterior superior temporal sulcus bilaterally, temporal pole bilaterally, and dorsomedial prefrontal cortex. The findings suggest a discrete set of underlying mechanisms in the moment that the persuasion process occurs, and are strengthened by the fact that the results replicated across two diverse linguistic and cultural groups. Additionally, a third study using region-of-interest analyses demonstrated that neural activity in this network was also associated with persuasion when a sample of American participants viewed video-based messages. In sum, across three studies, including two different cultural groups and two types of media, persuasion was associated with a consistent network of regions in the brain. Activity in this network has been associated with social cognition and mentalizing and is consistent with models of persuasion that emphasize the importance of social cognitive processing in determining the efficacy of persuasive communication.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI studies in healthy adult participants (American and Korean samples) assessed neural responses during persuasion tasks (text and video). Persuasion engages social cognition/mentalizing relevant to social communication and understanding of others, meeting the review’s social-related task criterion. Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult samples (three studies; mean ages ~20) involving social-related tasks (persuasion/mentalizing, perception and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (persuasive > unpersuasive) with thresholding and coordinate tables/figures (e.g., p < .001 uncorrected; Tables/Figures reporting MNI coordinates), which are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control groups. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Mental hoop diaries: emotional memories of a college basketball game in rival fans.
studies.abstract: The rivalry between the men's basketball teams of Duke University and the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill (UNC) is one of the most storied traditions in college sports. A subculture of students at each university form social bonds with fellow fans, develop expertise in college basketball rules, team statistics, and individual players, and self-identify as a member of a fan group. The present study capitalized on the high personal investment of these fans and the strong affective tenor of a Duke-UNC basketball game to examine the neural correlates of emotional memory retrieval for a complex sporting event. Male fans watched a competitive, archived game in a social setting. During a subsequent functional magnetic resonance imaging session, participants viewed video clips depicting individual plays of the game that ended with the ball being released toward the basket. For each play, participants recalled whether or not the shot went into the basket. Hemodynamic signal changes time locked to correct memory decisions were analyzed as a function of emotional intensity and valence, according to the fan's perspective. Results showed intensity-modulated retrieval activity in midline cortical structures, sensorimotor cortex, the striatum, and the medial temporal lobe, including the amygdala. Positively valent memories specifically recruited processing in dorsal frontoparietal regions, and additional activity in the insula and medial temporal lobe for positively valent shots recalled with high confidence. This novel paradigm reveals how brain regions implicated in emotion, memory retrieval, visuomotor imagery, and social cognition contribute to the recollection of specific plays in the mind of a sports fan.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was performed on healthy adult college fans during a task involving recall tied to fan perspective and emotional responses; the study examines social-cognition/affiliation (fan identity) processes, matching the review’s social-related task criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (male college students, ages ~20–23) using a task that probes social-related processing (fan identity, self-referential processing, perspective taking/mentalizing about players and rival fans). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM; tables and figures list whole-brain activation for contrasts such as emotional intensity and valence) with appropriate thresholding and small-volume corrections for ROIs. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable within the specified age range. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults engaged in social cognition-related processes.

studies.title: Animated brain: a functional neuroimaging study on animacy experience.
studies.abstract: Previous research used animated geometric figures to investigate social cognitive processes involved in ascribing mental states to others (e.g. mentalizing). The relationship between animacy perception and brain areas commonly involved in social cognition, as well as the influence of particular motion patterns on animacy experience, however, remains to be further elucidated. We used a recently introduced paradigm for the systematic variation of motion properties, and employed functional magnetic resonance imaging to identify the neural mechanisms underlying animacy experience. Based on individual ratings of increased animacy experience the following brain regions of the "social neural network" (SNN), known to be involved in social cognitive processes, were recruited: insula, superior temporal gyrus, fusiform gyrus, parahippocampal gyrus and the ventromedial prefrontal cortex bilaterally. Decreased animacy experience was associated with increased neural activity in the inferior parietal and inferior frontal gyrus, key constituents of the human "mirror neuron system" (hMNS). These findings were corroborated when analyses were based on movement patterns alone, irrespective of subjective experience. Additionally to the areas found for increased animacy experience, an increase in interactive movements elicited activity in the amygdala and the temporal pole. In conclusion, the results suggest that the hMNS is recruited during a low-level stage of animacy judgment representing a basic disposition to detect the salience of movements, whereas the SNN appears to be a high-level processing component serving evaluation in social and mental inference.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating animacy/social cognition using animated geometric figures; reports social neural network and mirror neuron system activations. Not a review. Although ages/health not explicitly stated, it implies healthy human participants; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related animacy perception task in healthy adults (n=15 males, mean age 26.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (parametric contrasts and t-/F-contrasts) with voxelwise results and tables of MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE corrections. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. Results for the healthy control group are reported explicitly and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of task-evoked whole-brain fMRI in healthy adults.

studies.title: Brain circuits involved in understanding our own and other's internal states in the context of romantic relationships.
studies.abstract: Social interactions require the capacity to understand both our and other's internal states. These semi-independent skills, the ability to understand oneself and others, seem to rely on the same type of representations and recruit similar brain areas. In this study, we looked at the neural basis of self and other processing in the context of an interaction with a significant other. Fourty-two participants in a monogamous relationship completed an fMRI task in which they watched a set of video-vignettes of his/her romantic partner expressing emotional contents. Participants were asked to elaborate on his/her spouse´s experience (other condition) and on his/her own experience when watching the video-vignettes (self-condition). The results showed a significant overlap in the brain activation for both conditions (e.g. anterior insula, posterior cingulate/precuneus, inferior frontal gyrus, inferior parietal lobule). In addition, the self-condition recruited brain areas associated with interoceptive processing and affect sharing (e.g., posterior insula), whereas the other-condition engaged brain areas involved in the cognitive representation of another's internal states and self-other distinction (e.g., fusiform, supramarginal gyrus, angular gyrus and temporoparietal junction).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (romantic partners) performed a social task probing perception/understanding of self and others (affiliation/attachment context). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (understanding self and a romantic partner) in healthy adults. Sample: N=42 healthy, right-handed adults aged 23–40 (within 17–65). The task is a task-evoked, ecologically valid social paradigm (video vignettes of partner) contrasting self vs other and valence conditions. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (directional t-contrasts and ANOVA), with family-wise error correction and cluster thresholds; results are presented as tables and figures listing activated regions and corrected statistics. The study does not restrict to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Converging evidence for the advantage of dynamic facial expressions.
studies.abstract: Neuroimaging evidence suggests that dynamic facial expressions elicit greater activity than static face stimuli in brain structures associated with social cognition, interpreted as greater ecological validity. However, a quantitative meta-analysis of brain activity associated with dynamic facial expressions is lacking. The current study investigated, using three fMRI experiments, activity elicited by (a) dynamic and static happy faces, (b) dynamic and static happy and angry faces, and (c) dynamic faces and dynamic flowers. In addition, using activation likelihood estimate (ALE) meta-analysis, we determined areas concordant across published studies that (a) used dynamic faces and (b) specifically compared dynamic and static emotional faces. The middle temporal gyri (Experiment 1) and superior temporal sulci (STS; Experiment 1 and 2) were more active for dynamic than static faces. In contrasts with the baseline the amygdalae were more active for dynamic faces (Experiment 1 and 2) and the fusiform gyri were active for all conditions (all Experiments). The ALE meta-analyses revealed concordant activation in all of these regions as well as in areas associated with cognitive manipulations (inferior frontal gyri). Converging data from the experiments and the meta-analyses suggest that dynamic facial stimuli elicit increased activity in regions associated with interpretation of social signals and emotional processing.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Three fMRI experiments contrasted dynamic vs. static emotional faces — a social perception/communication task in human participants. The abstract does not specify participant ages but implies healthy adult samples and is not a review/meta-analysis. Insufficient detail on age/group composition, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of dynamic vs static facial expressions (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (mean ages ~25–26), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise analyses and provides coordinates and cluster results (tables and figures), including contrasts (dynamic>static, task>baseline) generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes whole-brain univariate maps suitable for meta-analysis. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Atypical brain activation patterns during a face-to-face joint attention game in adults with autism spectrum disorder.
studies.abstract: Joint attention behaviors include initiating one's own and responding to another's bid for joint attention to an object, person, or topic. Joint attention abilities in autism are pervasively atypical, correlate with development of language and social abilities, and discriminate children with autism from other developmental disorders. Despite the importance of these behaviors, the neural correlates of joint attention in individuals with autism remain unclear. This paucity of data is likely due to the inherent challenge of acquiring data during a real-time social interaction. We used a novel experimental set-up in which participants engaged with an experimenter in an interactive face-to-face joint attention game during fMRI data acquisition. Both initiating and responding to joint attention behaviors were examined as well as a solo attention (SA) control condition. Participants included adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) (n = 13), a mean age- and sex-matched neurotypical group (n = 14), and a separate group of neurotypical adults (n = 22). Significant differences were found between groups within social-cognitive brain regions, including dorsal medial prefrontal cortex (dMPFC) and right posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS), during the RJA as compared to SA conditions. Region-of-interest analyses revealed a lack of signal differentiation between joint attention and control conditions within left pSTS and dMPFC in individuals with ASD. Within the pSTS, this lack of differentiation was characterized by reduced activation during joint attention and relative hyper-activation during SA. These findings suggest a possible failure of developmental neural specialization within the STS and dMPFC to joint attention in ASD.
