fMRI study of perspective-taking during self/other evaluation (social processing). Includes a healthy adult control group (24 typically developed adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI hyperscanning study investigates joint attention, a social cognitive process, using real-time social interaction. Abstract does not specify participant ages or confirm healthy adult sample (17–65), so information is insufficient to determine eligibility; include for full-text review to verify sample characteristics and task details.

fMRI study of cognitive empathy (social processing) with both schizophrenia patients and a healthy control group (n=24). Not a review/meta-analysis. Controls are adult participants, meeting the healthy adult group inclusion criterion; task is social-related. Therefore eligible for inclusion.

Abstract reports an fMRI task of social-related processes (self-referential processing, perspective-taking). It does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included or participant ages, so information is insufficient to determine eligibility from the abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Study examines perception of emotional facial expressions (a social processing task) and likely involves amygdala functional response. However, the abstract does not explicitly state that fMRI was used nor whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient detail to confirm inclusion—include for full-text review to verify methods and participant groups.

Study examines functional/structural connectivity in children and adolescents with ASD (clinical pediatric sample). It does not include a healthy adult (age 17–65) participant group required by the review, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI functional connectivity correlates of autistic traits in neurotypical adults but does not indicate whether scans were acquired during a social-related task or at rest. Inclusion requires task-based social processing; the abstract is ambiguous. Include for full-text review to determine if a social task was used.

fMRI study of social-emotional (fearful face) processing, which is a social-related task. Includes a matched healthy adult control group (13 adults) within the target age range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract examines oxytocin’s influence on processing of socially relevant cues in humans, addressing social-related processing. The abstract lacks explicit details about fMRI methods and participant ages/health, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task involving social-related processing. Although healthy control groups are present, the review requires task-based fMRI of social processes; the abstract does not describe any social task. Therefore exclude.

Abstract describes an fMRI investigation of facial emotion/neutral face processing (a social-related task). The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included, so information is insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy participants and task details.

This study used resting-state fMRI in antipsychotic-naive adolescents with early-onset schizophrenia and healthy adolescent controls (not task-based social processing). Participants are adolescents, not healthy adults aged 17–65, and no social-related task was used.

Study uses a pediatric/adolescent sample (socially anxious adolescents) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Although it involves fMRI of social evaluation, participants are not within the required adult age range, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Study used fMRI during a facial emotion perception task (a social-related process) and included a healthy control group (n=22) of adult women. Meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

The study reports fMRI in a non-clinical (healthy) cohort performing the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social Theory-of-Mind task (Perception/Understanding of Others). At least one healthy participant group is included (even though structural analyses focus on stroke patients), and this is not a review. Age range isn’t specified in the abstract, but per instructions insufficient age info should prompt inclusion for full-text review.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (fALFF) and multimodal MRI to predict cognitive and symptom scores; it does not involve a task-based social processing paradigm or any social-related task in the abstract. Although healthy controls are included, the primary focus is prediction, not social processing, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. This study used resting-state and diffusion imaging to examine visuospatial working memory and DMN in adolescents (including ASD participants) rather than adults performing a social-related task.
Resting-state fMRI study in adolescents with autism (clinical sample) with no social-related task and participants outside the healthy adult (17–65) target. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI task assesses precision visuomotor/sensorimotor behavior (visually guided gripping) in individuals with ASD; not a social-processing task and does not report healthy adult social-task data. Does not meet review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI study using a theory-of-mind (social cognition) task in 109 healthy volunteers. Meets inclusion: social-related task, healthy adult participants present. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract focuses on fMRI connectivity in Huntington’s disease and does not clearly state inclusion of a healthy control group aged 17–65. Because the presence of healthy participants is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no social task); inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task. Although it involves social cognition and healthy adults, the absence of a task-based social paradigm excludes it.

Abstract reports BOLD signal in the face-processing network—a social-perception domain—in healthy young adults (mean ages 22–26). Though it does not explicitly state a task, the functional BOLD measures for face-processing warrant inclusion for full-text review to confirm task-based fMRI and exact paradigms.
Resting-state fMRI in youth (ages 8–15), not a task-based social processing study; participants are children/adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are described as 'boys' (children/adolescents) rather than adults; inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI and a social-context task, the healthy group does not appear to be within the adult age range, so it does not meet the age criterion.
Resting-state fMRI study in youth with autism, not a task-based social-processing fMRI in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This paper is a review article summarizing brain-imaging studies (systematic review), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses. Additionally, the abstract does not report any specific social-task fMRI in healthy participants.

Abstract does not explicitly state that fMRI was used, though the study examines frontal control over social approach–avoidance actions in healthy adults and is relevant to social processing. Insufficient information to confirm fMRI; include for full-text review.

Abstract addresses social interaction deficits in borderline personality disorder but does not state whether an fMRI was performed during a social task or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. Information is insufficient from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI was used during a social-related task (inferring others’ social emotions/beliefs). The study includes a typically-developing healthy control group (17 males), meeting the requirement for at least one healthy participant group. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm ages and extract data.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in individuals with autism spectrum disorder examining network connectivity. It does not report a task-based social processing paradigm in healthy adults (17–65). Thus it fails the requirement for task-based social-related fMRI in healthy participants.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (interpretation of social interactions) in healthy adult participants (N=16, ages 22–34). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (F-tests and post hoc t-tests; voxelwise FWE-corrected maps and cluster tables; coordinates reported) comparing verbal and non-verbal interaction types and contrasts among non-verbal categories. Results are clearly from the healthy adult sample and generalizable within that group. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical methods. Age criteria and healthy-group reporting are satisfied. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an original fMRI study of social communication (prosody-based communicative intentions) in healthy adult participants (n=22, mean age ~27). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) with voxel-wise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides activation maps and coordinates. Although PPIs are reported, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results for the healthy group are clearly presented. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of emotion perception (social communication / perception of others) in healthy adult participants (Study 1: n=25, ages 19–24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (3×3 repeated-measures ANOVA, whole-brain FWE-corrected results, and tables/figures listing activated clusters and coordinates). The tasks involve social-emotional processing (facial and vocal emotion perception), matching the review constructs. Participants are within the 17–65 age range. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity or between-group contrasts and provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=14, ages 23–50). Participants performed a social-related valence appraisal task (social vs. non-social images). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (social > non-social contrast; voxelwise t maps with cluster-level FDR correction) in the healthy sample and presents conjunction and ROI analyses. All inclusion criteria are satisfied (social task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and whole-brain task-evoked group results). None of the exclusion criteria apply (results are not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and are empirical). Note: sample size is small but does not disqualify inclusion under the review criteria.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: N=49, ages 19–34; Experiment 2: N=23, ages 18–30). The task concerns perception/understanding of others via visually observed social interactions, fitting the social-processing constructs. Crucially, the manuscript reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (e.g., interaction > independent actions contrast; FDR-corrected maps reported at 5%, and thresholds described), not only ROI analyses. Results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and described as generalizable group effects in healthy adults. The study does not fall under exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=18, ages within 17–65) that uses a social joint-action task (leader/follower interaction) relevant to social cognition/perception of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Leading>Following, conjunctions, and regression analyses) with cluster-level corrections and Talairach coordinates, presented in figures/tables and described in text. Although some regression results are reported at a lenient threshold and authors note exploratory status, whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy adult group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses and does not include only clinical or out-of-range participants. Therefore it satisfies the inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although this is an fMRI study of social impression formation in healthy adult participants (N=60, mean age 23.8) and examines social-cognitive processes, the manuscript reports multivariate behavioral PLS results (brain–behavior covariance / coactivation maps) rather than group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation contrasts. The paper refers to an earlier univariate analysis of the same dataset but does not present a group-level, voxelwise univariate task activation map or coordinate table clearly identified as a healthy-group task effect in this manuscript. The inclusion criteria require at least one group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group; this criterion is not met here. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing using an approach–avoidance task contrasting social vs nonsocial stimuli. Sample comprises healthy adult participants (male, mean age 21.4) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (first- and second-level contrasts for positive/negative and social/nonsocial conditions), ROI analyses with small-volume correction, and additionally notes exploratory whole-brain results beyond a priori ROIs (reported at corrected thresholds). It is empirical, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and provides task activation contrasts that are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 24.36, within 17–65). The tasks probe social cognition (mind perception; gaze-cueing/social attention). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked voxelwise analyses (parametric regressors of mind ratings and gaze-cueing effects) and reports cluster-corrected whole-brain results (vmPFC cluster surviving correction and tables/figures of activations). Analyses are clearly from the healthy/control sample and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/‘empathic accuracy’—perception and understanding of others) using the Empathic Accuracy Task. The sample includes a healthy adult group (final n=34, ages 20–30) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SPM12 first-level, random-effects group analyses, TFCE FWE-corrected results) including contrasts (emotional > neutral, happy vs sad) and voxelwise correlations with behavioral measures and continuous ratings; peak activations and cluster tables/figures are presented. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state results, nor only between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is an fMRI task study of social evaluation in healthy adults (age 18–28) and reports group-level voxelwise results and coordinates, the analyses and inference were restricted to predefined ROIs (search regions limited to amygdala, insula, IFG, ACC, thalamus, caudate, mOFC). The paper does not report unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation maps or results generalizable across the whole brain; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for studies that report only ROI-restricted results and no whole-brain task activation. All other inclusion criteria (healthy adults, task fMRI, social processes) are met, but the ROI-only reporting requires exclusion.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (responses to another person controlling subjects’ choices — social cognition/perception of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=51, mean age 22) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (controlled > free), including cluster-level FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates, and describes whole-brain covariate analyses; results are clearly generalizable to healthy adults. It therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, and includes whole-brain task activation maps).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self, friend, celebrity judgments—Perception and Understanding of Self/Others). Sample: 37 healthy adult males (mean age 22.9), within 17–65. Whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts are reported (self vs. celebrity; friend vs. celebrity) with voxelwise results and FDR-corrected peaks and coordinate tables. Analyses and results are clearly presented for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, not clinical-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI includes an explicit social cognition contrast (TOM vs Random) assessing perception/understanding of others. (2) Sample comprises healthy adults from the Human Connectome Project (n=787; ages 22–35+), reported separately. (3) The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-activation maps (Cohen's d and z statistic maps) for the healthy cohort, with tables/figures and coordinate information. (4) This is empirical original fMRI research. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy-group task effects are reported). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

The study uses task-based fMRI presenting erotic pictures and videos of other people, which falls under perception/understanding of others (a social-related construct). The sample consists of healthy adult women (ages 21–46) with results reported separately by orientation groups. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (one-sample and group comparisons; whole-brain maps and cluster results reported with p<0.05 FWE), not only ROI or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state only, not ROI-only, and healthy adult group-level whole-brain effects are provided). Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social joint-action (leading, following, mutual) using haptic contact — a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others, social communication, affiliation). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 40.4, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Leading+Following+Mutual > Solo+Alone; Leading+Solo > Mutual+Alone) with FDR correction and cluster thresholds, and provides Talairach coordinates and statistical maps/figures. It does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (N=36; mean ages ~24–25). The task involved observing cooperative and affective social interactions (social cognition constructs). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results (parametric and categorical contrasts) with tables of MNI coordinates and cluster-level FDR-corrected statistical maps, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are clearly reported. Although the study also includes DCM effective connectivity, it additionally provides univariate whole-brain activation maps, so it does not meet any exclusion criteria. Therefore it should be INCLUDED.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (directors n≈35, matchers n≈35; ages 18–33), investigating social/communicative (collaborative vs. individual) memory encoding and retrieval. It presents group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Collaborative > Individual, Collaborative > Arbitrary, Individual > Arbitrary, Arbitrary > Individual) with tables of coordinates and cluster-corrected results, and additionally reports ROI follow-up. The task is explicitly social/communication-related (collaborative label generation and referential communication). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (healthy adult sample, social-related fMRI task, and whole-brain task-evoked group results). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of healthy adult participants (three datasets, total N=59) using social-related tasks (person knowledge: famous faces/names; socially relevant concept words). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., social > non-social semantics) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster correction, and peak coordinates; whole-brain results are described in text/tables/figures. Healthy/control participant results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, nor connectivity- or patient-only; it thus meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition/decision-making (modified iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adults (n=20, ages 23–38). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., conjunction task>control, COMP>COOP, COOP>COMP) with tables of coordinates and cluster-corrected results, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task probes perception/understanding of others (Theory of Mind, social decision-making), matching the review constructs. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper also includes connectivity analyses but does not rely solely on ROI- or connectivity-only findings. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adults and probes social/attachment-related processing, the reported neuroimaging results are seed-based resting-state functional connectivity (post-narrative rest) analyses rather than group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps. The meta-analysis inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain voxelwise task activation map for the healthy group. This paper does not present such whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (it focuses on resting-state FC and seed-based connectivity), therefore it must be excluded.

Although the study is an fMRI investigation of social evaluation in a healthy adult sample (N=36) and meets the sample and task criteria, the reported neuroimaging results are analyzed and reported using a small-volume ROI approach focused on bilateral posterior vACC. The manuscript describes small-volume correction within an a priori vACC ROI and presents ROI-restricted activation clusters; it does not report or present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map or whole-brain coordinates for task contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group task effect, this study must be excluded under the exclusion criterion for ROI-only reporting.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of others’ body motion and potential for social involvement). Sample: 16 healthy adults (mean age 22.75), within 17–65. Whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses are reported: second-level ANOVAs on contrasts (FT vs FA, PLD vs HL) using MNI coordinates, FWE-corrected results and stereotaxic peak tables are described. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes whole-brain task activations with coordinate reporting. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (moral dilemma, kinship/affiliation) in healthy adults. Sample: 30 healthy adult females (ages 19–39) meeting the age criterion. The paper reports voxelwise whole-brain analyses: (1) group-level inter-subject correlation (ISC) maps across the whole brain with multiple comparisons correction, and (2) a group-level GLM contrast (decision vs. non-decision) from the moral-dilemma task with whole-brain cluster correction. Results are reported for the healthy sample and are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=14, ages 20–32) that investigates social perception (perception of third-party social interactions). It reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (interaction > independent; animate > physical) with peak MNI coordinates and group maps, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy group. The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others’ interactions). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes within-group healthy adult results). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Study uses task-based fMRI to investigate social/attachment-related processing (monogamy vs. adultery, relationship maintenance). Sample comprises 27 healthy adult males (ages 20–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (IAT incongruent vs. congruent) with cluster-level FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates (Table 3), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the go/no-go analysis included an ROI-based constrast for the right VLPFC, whole-brain IAT results are reported, and healthy-group effects are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria (only ROI, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (romantic/affiliation and sexual stimuli). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (heterosexual men, age 22–50). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked group-level results (e.g., sexual>neutral combined activation for all participants; within-group and between-group contrasts; tables of coordinates and whole-brain figures) analyzed with FSL and cluster correction. It is not ROI-only, nor connectivity/resting-state only, and includes healthy adult group task activation maps clearly reported. Although the sample is male-only and selected for monogamy extremes, participants are healthy adults and whole-brain task effects are provided, meeting inclusion criteria for studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind) in healthy adult participants (Exp.1: N≈17 analyzed, mean age 28.5; Exp.2: N=20, mean age 21.25), within the 17–65 age range. The task explicitly probes social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others’ beliefs and emotions) using mental-state stories and a Belief > Photo ToM localizer. The paper reports standard whole-brain preprocessing, normalization to MNI space, and provides group-level localization information (ROI definition referenced to Belief>Photo contrast and supplementary figures/tables; main contrasts and maps/ROIs are presented in figures and Supplementary Materials). The reported results are task-evoked and attributable to a healthy adult sample. There is no indication that only ROI or resting-state/ connectivity-only analyses were reported. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results reported).

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (implicit and explicit theory-of-mind) in healthy adults (N=22 after exclusions; mean age ~24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate GLM results from an explicit general-belief localizer (false-belief vs false-photograph) with a statistical threshold q(FDR)<0.05 and provides peak Talairach coordinates and figures. Although ROI analyses were used for the implicit task, the explicit localizer supplies an unmasked, whole-brain task-evoked map from the healthy/control group, satisfying the meta-analysis whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and the study is not connectivity-only or non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=34 males, ages 19–31 and 22–29 within 17–65 range); social-related task probing interpersonal emotions (schadenfreude/fremdscham) relevant to ‘‘Perception and Understanding of Others’’; reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (SIT vs NEUT) with family-wise-error corrected results and coordinates (MNI) and tables/figures; healthy/control group results are reported separately and generalizable (no patient-only sample). Not excluded by any criterion: analyses include whole-brain activation maps (not ROI-only), task-evoked univariate contrasts (not only connectivity), and participants are within age range. Therefore include for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although this fMRI study investigates social cognition (mental simulation of personally familiar people) in healthy adult participants (n=23 after exclusions; ages 18–27), it does not report a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map as required. The reported results are multivariate (searchlight MVPA/RSA) pattern-similarity maps and feature-selected RSA effects (voxelwise peaks/cluster coordinates reflect pattern similarity), not traditional univariate activation contrasts (e.g., task > baseline) generalized as an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group effect. Inclusion criteria specify at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map; because only multivariate voxelwise RSA results are presented, the study fails the whole-brain univariate evidence requirement and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19 included in imaging analyses; ages 18–30) that uses a social task (modified Trust Game) probing reciprocity, a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/prosocial behavior). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Gave $1.5X vs Gave $0; Gave $1.5X After Receiving vs After Not Receiving) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster-size correction, and coordinates reported in Table 3 and figures. Although the paper also includes ICA connectivity analyses, it nevertheless provides univariate whole-brain results for the healthy control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social influence/decision-making in healthy adults (n=62 neuroimaging cohort, ages 18–53). The task is explicitly social (groups of three interacting participants) and probes social influence/Perception and Understanding of Others. Analyses used whole-brain, voxelwise GLMs with random-effects group analysis, multiple-comparisons correction (SnPM), and report group-level activation maps (see NeuroVault link). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are satisfied: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and reported group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=41; ages 18–24) that uses a social-related task (decisions to share news with others vs select to read oneself) tapping social cognition, self- and other-related processing. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (select > content, share > content, share > select) with tables of coordinates and cluster statistics (Table 2) and whole-brain thresholding (p < .05, FWE-corrected), clearly identified for the healthy sample. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study in healthy adults (n=38, ages 19–29). The task is explicitly social (pseudo-interactive joke-telling with listener laughter as social feedback). The paper reports multiple group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., SELF vs OTHER, Group vs No Laughter, action–outcome contingency interaction) with voxelwise statistics and cluster-level FWE correction; results are presented in tables of coordinates and figures. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study is empirical with original fMRI data. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (imitation/observation of emotional faces) in healthy adult participants (initial N=28, final N=20; ages 18–55). The study reports group-level task-evoked neural activity and explicitly states a GLM in SPM8 replicating task PLS results (with voxelwise maps/figures and PLS voxel-pattern maps), providing whole-brain, univariate task activation evidence for the healthy sample. The task and behavioral assessments are directly social-cognitive (emotion recognition, theory of mind, deception/sarcasm). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, reports within-group healthy adult effects). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) fMRI social task — task explicitly probes mentalising/theory-of-mind (social cognition) with vignette-based intentionality questions; (2) sample — healthy adult participants in the fMRI experiment (N=17, mean age 22, right-handed, no neurological/psychiatric history), within the 17–65 range; (3) whole-brain evidence — reports group-level, random-effects, voxelwise SPM2 analyses (contrasts such as mentalising > factual and parametric mentalising > parametric factual), with statistical thresholding and whole-brain corrected results and coordinate tables/figures. Not excluded by any exclusion criterion (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, reports univariate whole-brain task activations for the healthy group). Therefore include.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (study 1: n=24, study 2: n=26; ages reported within adult range). The tasks probe social-related processing (retrieval of person knowledge: identity, social status, personality traits — clearly social cognition). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., all memory > baseline, status memory > baseline, trait memory > baseline; face vs name contrasts) with coordinates and tables (Table S6 and figures), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper also includes ROI, PPI, and DCM analyses, it additionally provides unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effects, so none of the exclusion criteria apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (mentalizing/social cognition and self-related processing) in healthy adult participants (two samples, ages 18–24). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain searches for regions associated with population-level retransmission ranks) with thresholding and cluster tables described in the main text and SI, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for healthy/control participants are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or clinical groups, so it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (face/emotion perception) in healthy adults (final N=25, ages 21–33). The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects contrast faces > objects from the localizer) and whole-brain searchlight analyses, with second-level one-sample t-tests and corrected inference. The task is social (emotion/age attribution), participants are within the required age range, and whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps are reported and clearly attributable to the healthy participant group. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria (healthy adult sample, fMRI social task, and group-level whole-brain results).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribution of emotion/mental states to human and non-human faces), conducted in healthy adults (N=16–17 analyzed; ages 21–46, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Emotion > Expression in the Explicit Task; Face > Scramble in the Implicit Task) with whole-brain cluster-level FWE correction and conjunction analyses described in the Methods and Results. While ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain voxelwise results are explicitly reported and thresholded. The sample is healthy adults and the reported maps are generalizable within the healthy group. Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (empathy for pain/perception and understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (male, 18–40). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (e.g., STRESS>CONTROL contrasts for INJECTION>QTIP and BIOPSY>QTIP) with family-wise error correction and coordinates of peak voxels, as well as conjunction and whole-brain results. Results and correlations are reported at the healthy-group level (stress and control groups are healthy adults) and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets the task domain, sample, and whole-brain reporting inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task is an fMRI-based social cognition task (Social Detection Task evaluating valence of naturalistic social interactions); sample comprises healthy adults (n=38, ages 18–30); the paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate activation results (multiple whole-brain contrasts, FWE-corrected, tables and figures provided) clearly derived from the healthy/control sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are reported). Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing, empathy for pain, and prosocial decision tasks) in a healthy adult sample (N=32 healthy right-handed female adults, mean age 22.7). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and random-effects analyses (voxelwise contrasts, cluster-level correction) with tables of MNI coordinates and cluster statistics. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain results are clearly reported. Tasks and contrasts map directly onto social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others, affiliation, prosocial behavior). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing (face encoding/recognition) in healthy adults (includes a 20–31 y subgroup), the reported imaging analyses are ROI-based: amygdala activity was extracted using WFU‑Pickatlas and MarsBaR and tested across genotypes. The paper does not present or describe any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group. Thus it fails the review’s required ‘‘whole-brain evidence’’ inclusion criterion and meets the exclusion criterion for ROI-only analyses.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (effects of social competition/mentalizing) in healthy adult participants (20 right-handed females, age 18–35). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Competition > No Competition at feedback; working memory performance-related deactivations) with tables of coordinates and cluster-corrected results, satisfying the whole-brain univariate reporting requirement. The task is clearly social (competition, social comparison, mentalizing), and results for the healthy adult group are reported directly (no restricted subgroup). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and participants are within the 17–65 age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI task study (Face Matching Task) probing processing of emotional faces — a social cognition paradigm (Perception/Understanding of Others). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=10, mean age 25), within the 17–65 range, and results for the healthy group are reported. The paper includes group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM analyses (first- and second-level one-sample t-tests) with contrasts (e.g., fear > neutral) and reports results/tables in the Supplementary Material (Table S2, Figures S1–S3), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps. Although the study also uses ICA, it additionally provides the required whole-brain univariate maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=25 right-handed females, mean age 23.2), using a social mentalizing task about friends and kin. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (friend > kin) and linear parametric whole-brain analyses across network layers, with cluster-thresholded statistical maps and coordinate tables (MNI) described in the text. Results are reported for the healthy adult sample separately; no ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only restrictions apply. Although the sample is female-only, participants fall within the 17–65 age range and meet the healthy adult criterion. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of prosocial (social-related) learning in healthy adults (n=31, males aged 19–32). The task manipulates social context (self, prosocial, no one) and uses task-evoked BOLD contrasts. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses with tables of peak coordinates and statistical maps (e.g., Tables S1–S4, main effects, conjunctions, whole-brain FWE and small-volume corrected results; Figures 2–3 and S3), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy control group are reported. The study is empirical with original fMRI data during a social task and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of emotion regulation in response to social stimuli (angry facial expressions), directly addressing social-related processing. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=60; age range 18–57), satisfying the 17–65 criterion and reporting healthy-group results separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Observe-angry > Observe-neutral; Decrease vs Observe-angry; Increase vs Observe-angry) with tables of peak coordinates and FWE-corrected cluster results, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although resting-state and seed-based analyses are also included, task-based whole-brain results for the healthy group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and is empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma), a social-processing task (reward, fairness, cooperation). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (final N=18, mean age ~21), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses with coordinates and thresholding (cluster-level FWE correction; MNI coordinates reported in Results and tables/figures), in addition to ROI analyses. No exclusion criteria apply (not limited to ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and is empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI evidence of social processing.

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=24, ages 19–31) using a social task involving cooperation and competition that probes perception/understanding of self and others. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses (GLMs) identifying activations in medial prefrontal regions (pgACC, area 9) and links these to behavior; whole-brain results are described and used to define ROIs. The task is explicitly social and relevant to the review constructs. No exclusion criteria are violated (not limited to ROI-only analyses, not resting-state, sample within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI of social-related processing (appraisal of attachment scenes; social cognition/mentalizing). (2) Sample includes a healthy adult group (N=25; ages 19–26) with results reported for that group. (3) Whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked results are reported (attachment vs. neutral contrast; MNI coordinates, cluster sizes, and cluster-level correction statistics provided). (4) The paper is empirical, task-based, and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI examining social-related processing (manipulations of sociality: human vs. computer; acquaintance vs. random individual) during social economic games (Prisoner’s Dilemma, Ultimatum/Welfare Game). (2) Sample consists of healthy adult participants (pilot N=10 college students; main study N=15 community adults; ages ≥18). (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical results (first-/second-/third-level GLM in FSL and SPM; cluster-thresholded maps Z>2.3, p<0.05 cluster-corrected in FSL; results shown at P<0.05 FWE in SPM) with coordinates and tables/figures described for healthy participants. Not excluded by any exclusion criterion (not ROI-only; includes whole-brain maps; not resting-state-only; healthy adult group reported separately). Thus eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (N=110, age 19–31) performing social-cognitive judgments (self-reference, other-reference vs syllable-count control). Group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM results are reported (contrasts: SR+OR > baseline; self > other; other > self) with FWE-corrected inference and coordinates/figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although DCM effective connectivity is also performed, the paper includes the required univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy adult sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) using a task where participants view actors grasping objects with emotional contexts (anger vs. joy). Sample: 20 healthy adults (ages 23–33) meeting the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (GLM/ANOVA contrasts and whole-brain FWE-corrected activations for angry vs. joyful sessions and grasping effects), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only findings. Results are clearly reported for the healthy sample and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, empirical data in healthy adults). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults: 34 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.2) watched a movie and neural responses to social interactions were the primary focus. The study reports both ROI analyses and a whole-brain voxelwise reverse-correlation analysis, including group-level statistical testing (χ2 goodness-of-fit, Bonferroni correction) and whole-brain-corrected maps visualized in Figure 3. These constitute group-level, univariate, voxelwise task-evoked effects generalizable to a healthy adult sample. The paper is empirical, not connectivity-only, and results for the healthy group are reported. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-connectivity only, participants within age range).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=40; mean age 27.8) using a social task (modified Cyberball with performance-evaluation and exclusion/inclusion conditions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (random-effects GLM), with voxel-level FWE-corrected results and tables of MNI coordinates for multiple contrasts (e.g., Exclusion > Inclusion, PG EX > FG EX, conjunction analyses). Results are clearly identified for the healthy adult sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and provides whole-brain univariate maps in text/tables/figures. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants and includes social tasks (theory-of-mind; attribution-of-attention), the primary analyses are localized group-level ICA restricted to a TPJ ROI and task-related regressions on IC time courses. The paper does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map or contrast for the healthy group (results are ROI-limited IC maps and seed-to-voxel functional connectivity). Because the inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain univariate task activation map generalizable to healthy adults, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game (a social economic exchange task) in healthy adult participants (n≈51; mean ages ~31 within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects GLM/ANOVA, voxelwise parametric regressors), with group-level statistical maps and coordinate tables (MNI) and corrected cluster results. Healthy-group effects are explicitly reported (pre/post training within MT and CT healthy cohorts) and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper also includes ROI and connectivity analyses, but it does not rely solely on ROI/connectivity; whole-brain task activations for the healthy group are present. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study is an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (n=19; ages 20–53) using a social cognition/Theory of Mind task (REMICS). It reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM contrasts) with peak coordinates and tables of significant clusters for multiple contrasts (e.g., SocAdj > PhyConf, Soc > Phy, Adj > Conf) and describes cluster-level correction — fulfilling whole-brain evidence requirements. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy sample are reported separately. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and should be INCLUDED in the review.

This is an original, empirical fMRI study of social cognition (impression updating / perception and understanding of others) conducted in healthy adult participants (N=21, ages 18–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (e.g., L2>F3 main effect and updating-by-condition interaction), provides coordinate tables and figures, and uses corrected thresholds for voxelwise inference—meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a between-group or clinical-only comparison. Participants fall within the eligible age range and results for the healthy group are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (emotion inference) in healthy adults (final N=18, mean age ~23.7). The task is social (inferring targets’ emotions from visual/verbal cues with feedback), and analyses report group-level, whole-brain univariate results (voxelwise contrasts, conjunctions, and tables of MNI coordinates) including VS, vMPFC, TPJ, PCC, and visual cortex. Thresholding and cluster-correction procedures are described. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical restrictions apply. Whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluation) in healthy adults (final N=31, ages 19–24). The task manipulations map onto ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ (agentic vs. communal self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts and regression analyses (e.g., SC vs SA, OC vs OA, SA vs Fixation) with coordinates and cluster statistics (voxel-wise p<0.001, cluster-level FWE p<0.05) in tables and figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy control sample are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind) in healthy adults (N=18, ages 21–38). It uses a task manipulating cooperation vs. competition and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., coop_active > coop_passive, comp_active > comp_passive, active > passive) with cluster-level correction and tables of coordinates (Table 1 and Supplementary Tables). Thus it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample within 17–65, and (3) whole-brain, group-level univariate results. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and reports within-group task effects generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (EmpaToM) manipulating empathy and Theory of Mind, using a task-based paradigm in healthy adults (N=178; mean age 40.9, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., emotional vs neutral videos; ToM vs non-ToM questions/videos) analyzed with SPM and one-sample t-tests, and provides activation peak tables and figures. Although the study also includes connectivity (resting-state, DCM), it clearly presents voxelwise task-evoked whole-brain results for the healthy sample. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processes (empathy, perspective taking, attention) using task-based paradigms (charitable donation, EmpaToM, Posner cueing) in healthy adult participants (N=33, ages 20–34). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise analyses (multiple GLMs) and univariate random-effects group results (e.g., a significant cluster for low>high donations in visual cortex and EmpaToM-derived group contrasts used with FWE correction), not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. Healthy-group results are clearly described and generalizable within the adult range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, patient-only groups, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI evidence in healthy adults and should be INCLUDED.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (subsample n=163, ages 19–35) using an interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma mentalizing paradigm (social cognition). The paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (mentalizing > control) with voxelwise results, cluster-level FWE correction, and tables/figures/coordinates describing whole-brain activations for the healthy sample. Participants are within the required adult age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The manuscript is empirical and includes original fMRI data. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain maps are provided). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based whole-brain fMRI in a social interaction paradigm (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) assessing retaliatory aggression, which is a social-related process. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=15 males, mean age 22.3), meeting the 17–65 age range and reported separately. The paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects analyses and parametric modulation results with Talairach coordinates and statistical maps (thresholds and cluster correction reported), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Results are clearly described as coming from the healthy/control group. Although sample size is small (not an exclusion), all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, out-of-range ages) are violated.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (female, ages 22–32; final N=19) using a social cognitive emotion-regulation task where a psychotherapist provides reappraisal instructions (Social-Reg). The study reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Social-Reg > Social-Look; Self-Reg contrasts) with tables of coordinates (Tables 1–3), cluster-wise FWE correction, figures, and brain–behavior correlations. The task probes social cognition/attachment and social regulation, directly relevant to social-related processing. It is not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity/resting-state analyses, and reports univariate whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task uses fMRI with a social-related paradigm (Cyberball ball‑toss) probing social interaction/enjoyment; sample consists of healthy adult participants (final N=31, mean age ~21, within 17–65); group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses are reported (random-effects paired t-tests, cluster-level FWE-corrected results, coordinates and clusters provided for right ventral striatum and precuneus); results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within the age range). Therefore the study should be included.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (n=25, mean age 24) that explicitly probes social-related processing: the meaning-rating task engages social/semantic interpretation of LEGO models and contrasts ‘meaning’ > ‘physical’, reporting activation in canonical social-cognition regions (dmPFC, TPJ, IFG). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts with peak MNI coordinates and corrected thresholds (FDR/FWE), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are within the 17–65 adult range and results for the healthy group are presented. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state, and includes appropriate within-group contrasts (main effects and interactions) generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social judgment task (dominance/trustworthiness perceptions) in healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 21–43). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (Social Judgment > Perceptual Judgment) with SPM analyses and FWE-corrected cluster results presented in tables and figures. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or clinical groups, and the healthy-group whole-brain activation maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, mean age 25.7) using a social-cognition/theory-of-mind task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate contrasts for task conditions (see Tables 2 and 3; voxel-wise and cluster-wise thresholds and peak MNI coordinates are provided), satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. The task examines social processing (agent-behavior and agent-mental conditions vs object-behavior) and thus fits the review’s social-related constructs. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (person perception and person knowledge) in healthy adults (n=21, mean age 24.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Bodies > Names, Traits > Neutral, and their interaction), thresholding procedures, cluster-level FWE correction, and peak coordinates overlapping with functional localisers. Results are presented for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses (although PPI is also reported). All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (race perception and subsequent trustworthiness evaluations) in a healthy adult sample (30 right‑handed White adults, ages 18–29). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole‑brain univariate analyses (e.g., first‑level [Black > White] contrasts submitted to second‑level covariate analyses) with cluster extent and voxelwise thresholds, and presents whole‑brain results in tables of coordinates (Tables 2 and 3) and figures. Although PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, the study clearly provides univariate whole‑brain task-evoked maps from the healthy/control group rather than only ROI or connectivity-only results. Age range, sample, task (face perception during fMRI and post-scan trustworthiness ratings), and reported whole-brain statistics satisfy the inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social evaluation (approving/disapproving videos) in a healthy adult sample (N=37; mean age 24.8, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (negative>neutral, positive>neutral, conjunction) with FWE-corrected results and tables of MNI coordinates and figures, clearly derived from the healthy participant group. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation maps). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, and reports within-group whole-brain effects).

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (n=24, mean age 25.2) using a social-related paradigm (perception of others’ facial expressions). Group-level univariate analyses were performed (mixed-effects FLAME) with parameter-estimate maps registered to MNI space. In addition, a separate group-level localiser (n=83 healthy participants) produced faces>scrambled whole-brain statistical maps (peak voxels and z-scores) that were explicitly used to define face-selective ROIs. Thus the paper provides group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from healthy adults and meets the sample and task criteria for inclusion in the meta-analysis of social processing.

The study used task-based fMRI during a social-related empathy task (participants received empathic vs. unempathic comments after negative performance feedback). Sample: 20 healthy adult participants (mean age 26), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., EE > EN, CE > CN, EE+CE > baseline) with voxelwise results, cluster sizes, MNI coordinates, and FWE-corrected statistics — i.e., whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches, and healthy-group within-subject contrasts are clearly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of affective theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (n=21 after exclusion; mean age 23.7, within 17–65). The task is social-related (affective ToM with/without emotional facial expressions). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., 3rdppA > 1stppV localizer; EFE > no EFE; interaction effects) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level inference, and ROI analyses supplementing these results. Although PPI connectivity is included, whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants are in target age range, and healthy-group results are presented). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-emotional processing (guilt) using task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (20 scanned; mean age 25.7). The paper reports within-group, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (e.g., guilt memories vs neutral memories) thresholded at p<0.001 with cluster extent and reports peak coordinates and clusters; SPM-based whole-brain analyses are explicitly described alongside small-volume corrections. Results are presented for the healthy/control group (within-group contrasts), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore the study meets the review’s task-based fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting inclusion criteria.

The paper is a conference proof-of-concept describing EEG-fMRI correlation and neurofeedback targeting the right posterior Superior Temporal Sulcus (pSTS). The abstract and available details indicate analyses focused on a predefined ROI (right pSTS) and correlation with EEG features; there is no report of a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map from a healthy adult sample. Participant details and whole-brain results for a healthy group are not presented. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring whole-brain task activation maps; exclude.

The available full text is a conference abstract with no methodological details (participant demographics, sample size, or age range) and does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy adult sample. The abstract describes BOLD response differences between dyadic and monadic fMRI and suggests network activation, but provides no tables/coordinates or explicit whole-brain healthy-group activation results. Because the study as presented fails to demonstrate the required whole-brain task activation maps and lacks clear reporting of a healthy adult group (17–65), it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (learning about others’ generosity) in healthy adults. The final analyzed sample (N=26) are healthy adults aged 19–37. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task-evoked statistical contrasts (e.g., Gifters > Lotteries, parametric SPE and predictability effects) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster-corrected inference. A computationally matched non-social condition is included, and results for the healthy group are presented and interpretable for the general adult population. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within the 17–65 range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition/theory-of-mind in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–27). The task explicitly elicits social-related processing (participants judged scenarios evoking 60 mental states). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses (searchlight MVPA and voxelwise univariate regression), cluster-corrected statistical maps, and tables of coordinates (Tables S2–S3 and figures). The healthy adult sample and whole-brain task-evoked results satisfy all inclusion criteria, and no exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy-age sample) are violated. Therefore it should be included in the review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perceived live social interaction/mentalizing) in healthy adults (N=29; ages 18–27). The task explicitly probes social communication/understanding of others (Live vs. recorded speech). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Live > Social; Social > Standard) thresholded and cluster-corrected and presents whole-brain results (figures and supplementary tables of activations). Data for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable to typical adults. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy for film characters) in healthy adults (n=26, mean age 30.3). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task analyses (mixed 2×3 ANOVA, emotion contrasts, multisensory contrast), with tables of cluster coordinates and FWE-corrected results (Tables 1 and 2) and figures showing whole-brain activations. Although the study also includes connectivity/DCM analyses, it clearly presents healthy-group voxelwise task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult subgroup reported).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult social networks that used a social task (viewing faces of real-world group members to assess popularity/social status). The paper reports whole-brain functional MRI data collected during the face-viewing task and uses independent functional localizers to identify neural systems; results describe activity in valuation and social-cognition systems that tracked targets’ sociometric popularity (group-level effects reported in figures/tables and supplemental material). Participants are members of real social groups (healthy adults), and the reported analyses are univariate task-evoked effects generalizable to the healthy group rather than limited to an ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-vs-control contrast. Although the provided excerpt does not list ages explicitly, the study context and journal article indicate a healthy adult sample. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (explicit control of interpersonal trust/distrust). Sample: healthy adults (n=60; mean age ~20.3), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., trust > age, distrust > age, attitude > age) with family-wise error–corrected thresholds, cluster extents, and MNI coordinates in tables and figures, generated from the healthy participant group. Results are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to a narrow subgroup. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, reports whole-brain maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of dynamic social gesture processing (social vs nonsocial intent) using an event-related task explicitly probing social cognition. Sample: 20 healthy young adults (mean age 21.4, range 16.9–25.7); the group is a healthy adult sample (majority ≥17) reported separately and analyzed as a healthy/control group. Whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses were performed and reported (FLAME group analysis, cluster-corrected Z maps, coordinates reported in Table 1 and figures). Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity methods. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, includes healthy adult task activation maps). Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI hyperscanning study of social interaction (mutual gaze and joint attention) in healthy adult participants (mean ages ~21–23). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked results (SPM analyses, cluster- and FWE-corrected statistics) and provides tables of peak coordinates and statistical maps for task contrasts and inter-individual synchronization. The tasks address social communication / perception of others (shared attention, joint attention, mutual gaze), and healthy-group results are reported and generalizable. The study is not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity-only or resting-state, and includes healthy adults within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI experiment on social communication (speech-act comprehension) in healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 18–41). The study reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses with FDR-corrected voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Request > Naming; Words > Faces) and describes whole-brain results in the text and figures. Although ROI/SVC analyses were also performed, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps are reported and generalized to the healthy group. The sample falls within the 17–65 range; no clinical groups confound the healthy-group results. The study is empirical and not limited to connectivity or ROI-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (processing agency vs. communion) in a healthy adult sample (N=42, ages 18–25). It provides group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (contrasts: agency vs. fixation, communion vs. fixation, conjunction, and between-condition contrasts) with cluster correction (AlphaSim) and presents results in figures/tables. It is not ROI-only nor connectivity-only and includes healthy adult results generalizable to the target population. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (racial prejudice, perception of others' facial disgust) using a task-based passive viewing paradigm in healthy adult participants (n=26, mean age ~21). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts and an interaction ((disgusted out-group–neutral out-group)–(disgusted in-group–neutral in-group)) with cluster-level family-wise error correction and tables of coordinates, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. It also includes ROI and PPI analyses, but these are supplemental to the reported whole-brain task activations. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social task (Cyberball social exclusion) in healthy adult participants (university students, mean age ~20, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (exclusion vs inclusion) across all participants and within genotype groups, with voxelwise results and FWE-corrected thresholds (tables of coordinates and figures provided). Although ROI and PPI analyses are also reported, whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample are clearly reported, satisfying all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults (n=28, ages 30–50). The task includes social stimulus processing (images depicting humans) and self-referential judgments, fitting the review’s constructs (perception/understanding of self and others; implicit social processing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (main effects, conjunctions, direct contrasts, FDR-corrected maps with cluster extent; peak coordinates and tables/figures) that are clearly from the healthy participant group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants (N=26, healthy adults, mean age 21.2) read passages manipulated for social content (Social vs Non-social). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate contrasts (Social>Non-social and Vivid>Abstract) with cluster-level correction and tables of peak coordinates (Table 1), clearly from the healthy sample.
