The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (canonical vs scrambled biological motion) with corrected significance and tabulated MNI coordinates and figures, and uses random-effects analysis — satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Although it also includes connectivity/DCM analyses, it provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. Participants are within the required age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply, so the study meets all inclusion criteria.

While this paper uses fMRI during a social task (the ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (ages 23–28) and reports whole-brain multivariate classification results (SVM/RVM weight maps identifying discriminating volumes), it does not present a group-level univariate, voxelwise task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM main-effect or within-group contrast) as required. The reported whole-brain results derive from multivariate classification/weight maps and ROI analyses rather than conventional univariate group contrasts. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level univariate whole-brain activation map for healthy adults, this study does not meet all criteria and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=20; mean age ~25, within 17–65). It uses an explicit social-related task (Cyberball) probing social exclusion/affiliation and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with cluster-corrected voxelwise results, tables of coordinates, and figures. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain results are clearly provided and generalizable to a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of task-evoked social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social competition invoking Theory of Mind (social interaction) in healthy adults. Sample: 14 right-handed healthy volunteers (mean age 35.9), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects, voxelwise univariate task contrasts (e.g., I> C; H>I+C>M>I+C; interaction [H(I>C)]>[M(I>C)]) with thresholding (p<0.001 uncorrected, cluster size reported) and tabulated peak coordinates (Tables 2–4). The task is social-related (human vs. machine competition; ToM-like processes). No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or out-of-range sample limitations are present. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults assessing social processing.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and integration of facial and vocal emotions — social communication) conducted in healthy adults (N=24, age 18–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (RFX-GLM) with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., AV > A, CAV > ICAV), thresholding and FDR correction, conjunction analyses, and tables/figures of activation clusters and coordinates. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical. Results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=19, ages 19–28). The task involves social-related processing (stereotype/social-category judgments and person knowledge) and compares social vs non-social semantic judgments. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects contrasts ‘social’>‘non-social’ and ‘non-social’>‘social’) with corrected cluster thresholds and tables/figures of peak coordinates and activations, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are within the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 18.7). Participants completed a task comparing close (romantic partner) and non-close (roommate) others; analyses used second-level random-effects GLMs and report group-level voxelwise contrasts with peak coordinates (multiple contrasts, e.g., Target × Breadth, Valence, Close vs Non-Close). Results are reported as voxelwise activation peaks and clusters (with correction applied within a priori ROIs) and are clearly described for the healthy control sample. The sample falls within the 17–65 range and the paper provides group-level task-evoked activation maps/coordinates generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., patient-only sample, resting-state/only connectivity, or ROI-only reporting without group contrasts) prevent inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (eye contact and mimicry) in healthy adults (N=20; mean age 23, all right-handed, no neurological history) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM contrasts (e.g., Congruent > Catch, Incongruent > Catch, Direct > Averted, interaction contrasts) with thresholding and cluster-level FWE correction; results are reported in tables and figures. Although DCM connectivity was also performed, the paper clearly provides task-evoked whole-brain activation maps for the healthy control group. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI during observation of virtual social interactions (a social cognition task). It reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (social interaction vs. no-interaction) with activation maps and t-value maps based on data from 15 participants, indicating whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy group. Participants are described as recruited with informed consent and standard adult screening; results are presented for the (healthy) participant group rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. These elements satisfy the review’s inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult group, and whole-brain group-level activation maps). Confidence is moderate-high because participant ages are not explicitly listed in the excerpt, but other details strongly indicate a healthy adult sample.

This fMRI study (N=25, Mage=20.2) tests prosocial/family-assistance decisions—clearly social-related processing (affiliation/mentalizing). Participants are healthy young adults within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain/univariate contrasts (e.g., Costly-Donation vs Noncostly-Reward) with tables of peak coordinates and t-scores (Tables 1–3) and whole-brain/ROI-corrected inference procedures. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (no clinical groups). Although ROIs were used for some corrections, whole-brain regression and contrast results are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (20 young adults) viewing dynamic social interaction vignettes (positive and negative), addressing social processing. The abstract and reported results describe group-level, univariate whole-brain activation (right > left activation in amygdaloid complex, inferior frontal gyrus, fusiform gyrus, temporal gyri; p<0.0001), which indicates voxelwise, within-group task effects rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only samples, or non-empirical paper) appear to apply. Note: full PDF is behind a paywall so coordinate tables/figures could not be inspected, but the abstract explicitly reports whole-brain hemispheric activation results. Given available information, the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (representation of social interaction/social context vs. solitary and self-generation) in healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–28). Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., (rSS+rSO)-(rNS+rNO), (rSS+rNS)-(rSO+rNO)) with tables of coordinates and cluster-level correction (p<0.05) and figures showing activation in mPFC, MCC, etc. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state only, and reports healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social (impression formation of Black and White faces paired with valenced traits — perception/understanding of others). (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (n=44, ages 19–34). (3) Group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results are reported (exploratory whole-brain analyses and Tables 2–3 list voxelwise activations; cluster correction via AlphaSim at p<.001, clusters ≥66 voxels). Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain contrasts (e.g., Incongruent vs. Congruent and regressions with IMS) are explicitly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of humor processing, a social-cognition task involving perception/understanding of others and affective social processing. Sample: 29 healthy right-handed adults (mean age 27, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Cartoons vs Neutral) and parametric modulation analyses with voxelwise results (FWE-corrected and Monte Carlo cluster correction) with tables of peak coordinates and conjunctions—i.e., whole-brain statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group results separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This study reports an event-related fMRI task explicitly probing social processing (observing social interactions vs non-social movements; social perception/understanding of others). Sample: 14 healthy adults (mean age 29.4), within the 17–65 range; results are reported for the healthy group. Whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate analyses are presented (SI>NSI contrast), with FDR-corrected significance and cluster reporting (figures and tables of activations described). The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity/resting-state analyses and provides generalizable healthy-group task activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=98, mean age 20.7) using task-based social judgments (self, friends, strangers) that probe perception/understanding of self and others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., self > Bush; friends > strangers) with whole-brain maps and ROI analyses, and results are presented for the healthy sample. Participants are within the 17–65 age range. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, not a review). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social gaze/action control in healthy adults (N=23; ages 21–37). The task manipulates social vs nonsocial stimuli and congruent/incongruent responses. Authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (SPM5 random-effects ANOVA) with thresholding and cluster-level correction, and provide tables/figures of suprathreshold clusters and coordinates (main effects and interactions). Participants are within the eligible age range and healthy; results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: event-related functional MRI during a social cognition task (mentalizing/inferring others’ preferences vs self — perception/understanding of others). (2) Sample: 64 healthy adult participants (age range 18–26) reported separately. (3) Whole-brain evidence: group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain analyses reported (parametric modulation of self–other discrepancy), with peak coordinates, cluster table (Table 1), and figures. (4) Not excluded: results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity/resting-state analyses and include univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This paper reports fMRI of social communication (charades) in healthy adult participants (18 included; mean age 27.5), addressing social communication and perception/understanding of others. The authors performed group-level whole-brain GLM analyses (used to define mirror-system ROIs and reported group activation results and contrasts, with cluster-level correction) and also report whole-brain between-brain Granger-causality maps; therefore the study provides group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from a healthy adult sample. Although the paper emphasizes directed connectivity (bbGCM), it includes traditional GLM whole-brain results and seed-definition contrasts, satisfying the review’s inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria (only ROI/connectivity without whole-brain task maps, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical paper) are met.)

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24 analyzed, ages 19–31) using a social-related task (familiarity judgments of personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces) addressing perception/understanding of others and social cognition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., P1-Cp1, P1-F1) with tables/figures of activations and cluster-corrected inferences. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes healthy adult whole-brain task activation maps; no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social preference (a social-related task) in healthy adults (N=21; ages 23–51). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Preference > Gender and others) with thresholding and tables of stereotactic coordinates (FDR-corrected p<0.05), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally provides task-evoked, univariate whole-brain maps from the healthy sample. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/intimacy/attachment) using a perspective-taking task (Self, Loved-one, Stranger) with pain vs. neutral stimuli. Sample: 36 healthy right-handed adult participants (mean age 23), within the 17–65 range. Analysis: group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects contrasts (Pain vs. Neutral; direct contrasts between perspectives) are reported with statistical parametric maps and tables of MNI coordinates (FDR-corrected thresholds and cluster extents), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain univariate task-evoked results. The paper also reports behavioral measures for the healthy group. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain effects generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (Experiment 1: n=16; Experiment 2: n=13; ages 18–29). Tasks probe social interaction and joint attention—clearly social-related constructs. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses and voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Live > Recorded; Joint Attention > Solo Attention) with tables of peak coordinates and corrected whole-brain results. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and contains healthy adult whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to the target population. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related (charitable donation decisions invoking empathy, perspective-taking and other social-cognition processes). (2) Sample consists of healthy adults (N=22 females, ages 19–38). (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (parametric DN regressor, free vs forced trials) with whole-brain corrected results and coordinates; figures/tables and supplemental material provide voxelwise results. (4) Not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only results (PPI reported in addition to whole-brain GLM). No exclusion criteria are violated. Hence include for meta-analysis of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (joint attention/representation of what another person sees) in healthy adults (final N=12 used in fMRI analyses; ages 20–31). The task is explicitly social (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects contrasts (body > place and place > body), with accompanying whole-brain statistical maps, figures, and a table of stereotaxic coordinates (Table 1). Analyses are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or patient-only contrasts. Results are reported for the healthy adult group and are generalizable to that population. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (self- and other-referential trait judgments) in healthy adult participants (n=13, ages ~19–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses using SPM5, with contrasts and tables of peak coordinates and thresholded statistical maps (e.g., p<0.001 uncorrected, cluster extent), and tests of interactions and covariates (similarity). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and the healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy, perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (n=16 analyzed; mean age 27.8). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., emotional vs. neutral; social relation vs. single person) with voxelwise statistical maps and Talairach coordinates (Table 1) and FDR thresholds—i.e., whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor limited to between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) in healthy adults using a naturalistic Movie for the Assessment of Social Cognition (MASC). Sample: 18 healthy right-handed adults (age range 20–45), meeting the age and healthy-group criteria. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate GLM results (contrasts ToM vs. physical inference) with cluster-thresholded statistical maps and coordinates (Table 1, Fig. 2), satisfying the whole-brain task-evoked map requirement. Although the study also includes model-free T-PICA analyses, it provides univariate, voxelwise task activation maps for the healthy group and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or patient-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study of empathy/social perception (perception of others' pain; social context/agency manipulation), which falls squarely under social-related processing. Sample: 26 healthy right-handed adult volunteers (mean age 24.4), within the 17–65 range and reported separately. Whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts are reported (e.g., main effect of pain: (PCO+PCS) – (NPO+NPS); main effect of social context; interaction), with stereotactic coordinates presented in Tables 1–3 and figures; results were thresholded (FDR p<0.05) and described as group-level effects generalizable to healthy adults. The paper also includes PPI connectivity analyses, but crucially it additionally reports univariate whole-brain activation maps rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While this is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults (group-level voxelwise contrasts reported), the fMRI acquisition used a limited 14-slice split-sagittal protocol optimized for STS/STG and explicitly excluded large portions of the brain (medial regions, medial frontal/parietal cortex, fusiform and early visual cortex). Consequently the reported voxelwise maps are based on partial-brain coverage and do not constitute a whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation map generalizable to the healthy adult population, which is required by the inclusion criteria. Other inclusion criteria (healthy adult sample, social task, group analyses) are met, but failure to provide whole-brain task-evoked maps mandates exclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attachment/affiliation) in healthy adults (n=51, mean age 28.5, within 17–65). The authors report group-level, voxelwise task-evoked whole-brain analyses (masked sad and happy faces vs neutral), with tables of coordinates and figures for main effects and correlations in healthy participants. Results include whole-brain a priori ROI-corrected maps and FDR-corrected activations beyond ROIs; group-level univariate contrasts for the healthy sample are clearly described and generalizable. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses, and reports healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study using a social decision-making task (Trust Game) probing reciprocity and perspective-taking — clearly within social-related processing. Sample: healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed, ages 18–22), satisfying the 17–65 range. Whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts are reported (e.g., defect>reciprocate; regression analyses) with tables of coordinates and ROI analyses; the paper provides voxelwise results generalized to the healthy group. It is not ROI-only, nor connectivity- or resting-state-only, and no between-group-only contrasts or ineligible age-groups limit inclusion. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) using healthy adult participants (14 Japanese and 14 white American, ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (e.g., RME - GD contrasts) with family-wise corrected results and tables of activation coordinates, and also presents conjunctions and between-group contrasts. It is not ROI-only, nor resting-state or connectivity-only, and results are clearly reported for healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=43 after exclusions; mean age 26.7, within 17–65). The task probes social processing (empathy/ perception and understanding of others’ pain) by presenting video stimuli and collecting behavioral ratings. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise mass-univariate analyses and contrasts (e.g., genuine pain – no pain; pretended pain – no pain; interaction) with an initial voxelwise threshold p<0.001 and cluster-level FWE correction p<0.05, and provides activation maps and peak coordinates. Although the manuscript also includes DCM effective-connectivity analyses, mass-univariate whole-brain results for the healthy sample are clearly reported. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (processing of others’ pupil dynamics and social salience), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=14, mean age 22). The authors report second-level random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (main effect of viewing eye stimuli reported at whole-brain cluster-corrected p<.05; effects of pupil-change reported with voxelwise thresholds and cluster criteria), with coordinates and activation figures described for group-level effects in healthy participants. The task clearly probes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) and the results include voxelwise whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only samples, or non-empirical paper) are met. Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, ages 22–37) that uses a social-related auditory task (perception/mentalizing about one versus two walkers). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST; STEP2 – NOISE2; STEP1 – NOISE1) with statistical maps, Talairach coordinates, figures, and cluster thresholds—fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not limited to ROIs, connectivity, or between-group only contrasts. Participant ages are within 17–65 and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26). The task explicitly manipulated social versus individual actions and gaze, meeting the social-related task requirement. The authors performed whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise analyses (second-level within-subjects ANOVA), reporting main effects and interactions with peak coordinates and thresholding (p<.001 uncorrected; extent ≥10 voxels) and presented SPM maps and tables—satisfying the whole-brain group-level univariate result criterion. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group only. The paper is empirical with original task-evoked BOLD data. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, out-of-range sample, non-empirical) are met, so the study should be included.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=19, mean age 28, range 19.3–47.5) that uses face stimuli (social) in a target-detection task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., face targets > novels; shape targets > novels; and direct contrasts), analyzed with FSL mixed-effects (FLAME) and cluster-corrected thresholds; coordinates and activation maps are provided. Results for the healthy/control sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not outside age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (gaze perception/joint attention). Participants: healthy adults (fMRI n=12, ages 18–40). The authors performed group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses using SPM2 (random-effects within-subjects ANOVA) and report multiple task contrasts (e.g. gaze-shift vs no-movement; incorrect vs correct; social vs unsocial) with tables/figures of activated loci and thresholding. Thus it satisfies: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample within 17–65, and (3) whole-brain group-level voxelwise results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy-only sample) apply. Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (vegetable-preference inference and age categorization) in healthy adult undergraduates (n=18, mean age 20). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses with voxelwise contrasts, Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, and figures/tables of activations (mPFC and other regions). It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain task-evoked fMRI evidence of social-related processing.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (approaching figures with angry vs. happy expressions) in healthy adult participants (10 right-handed young adults). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (Angry>Happy and Happy>Angry) with MNI coordinates, cluster sizes, tables and figures—i.e., univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy/control group. The task directly probes social-related constructs (perception of others’ intentions, affiliation/dominance). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within target age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (perception of socially relevant facial expressions/facial mimicry). Participants: healthy adult sample (N=17, mean age 25.9), meeting age and health criteria. Analyses: whole-brain, group-level random-effects voxelwise GLM/FIR ANOVA with reported activation maps and stereotactic coordinates (thresholds reported, Table/Figures provided). Results are univariate, task-evoked, and generalizable to healthy adults. Not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults. The paper reports data from healthy adult participants (initial N=20, final analyzed N=12, mean age 24.6) within the 17–65 range. It presents group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (story and card contrasts; p<.005 threshold, cluster extent reported) with tables and coordinate clusters and describes random-effects group analysis. The task probes social-related processing (theory of mind/social-exchange reasoning), which maps onto perception/understanding of others. Results for the healthy group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-connectivity-only, and is empirical. Note: sample size is modest (N=12) and several subjects were excluded, but inclusion criteria are met because whole-brain healthy-group activation maps are reported.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=12 included; mean age 24.6, range 21–31) that manipulates perception of agency/intentionality (composed vs computer-generated music) to probe mental state attribution/theory-of-mind processes — a social cognition construct relevant to the review. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (Composer > Computer) with coordinates, Z-scores, cluster extents, and multiple-comparison correction; results are generalizable to the healthy adult group. It is empirical task-based fMRI (not ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state, or patient-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked social processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (n=17, ages 20–34) that investigates social-communication processes (gaze- and finger-pointing-based joint attention). Group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts are reported (gaze-following vs baseline; finger-pointing vs baseline; subtraction contrasts), with thresholding, cluster information, figures, and peak coordinates described. The sample fits the 17–65 age range, and healthy/control-group results are presented directly and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not connectivity-only, and does not report only ROI analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social motor response learning/social inclusion–exclusion). Participants: 18 healthy adults (mean age 42±12), within the 17–65 range, and results for the healthy group are reported. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and coordinates (Tables II and III; whole-brain FDR-corrected results and voxelwise thresholded images shown in figures), not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. The contrasts and paired t-tests compare Pavlovian vs Social TD signals and provide whole-brain voxelwise results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (empathy/emotional perspective taking: SELF vs OTHER tasks) conducted in healthy adults (n=26, mean age ~24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (SELF vs high-level baseline; OTHER vs baseline) with FWE-corrected results and tables of peak coordinates and figures, not limited to ROI-only analyses. It is task-evoked (not resting-state or connectivity-only) and provides whole-brain maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study of self-recognition (social-cognitive processing: perception/understanding of self) in healthy adult participants (recruited age 18–24; group results reported). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Sf–Ff, main effects and interactions) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level correction; results are presented in tables and figures and are clearly from the healthy/control group. The task is task-evoked (familiar/unfamiliar judgments for faces and names). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, and includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social interaction (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: n=20 females, mean age 20.8; Experiment 2: n=30 mixed sex, mean age 21.2), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., PD > Gamble) with tables of activation coordinates (Table 2, etc.), statistical thresholds, and figures — satisfying the whole-brain task-evoked map requirement. Although it also includes connectivity and Granger causality analyses, the manuscript clearly provides primary univariate whole-brain results for the healthy/control groups. It is empirical, not a review, and results for healthy participants are reported separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (neural responses to perceived social hierarchy and hierarchical outcomes), directly addressing the review objective. Sample: healthy adult participants (n=24 per social experiment; age ranges reported 19–43 and 19–38; all right‑handed, no psychiatric/neurological history), satisfying the 17–65 age criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., “superior > inferior”, outcome contrasts) with voxelwise statistical maps and tables of peak coordinates, thresholded with FDR correction; results are presented as whole-brain maps and coordinate tables (i.e., not ROI-only). The study is empirical, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and includes appropriate healthy adult group results). Therefore it should be included in the review.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation vs deception) in healthy adults (n=13; ages 22–38). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects), including an initial exploratory whole-brain ToM vs non-ToM contrast and subsequent contrasts between conditions; activated clusters and peak coordinates are provided. Although ROI analyses were used for follow-up, whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an experimental task fMRI study in which participants viewed, imitated, and produced facial expressions and social hand gestures — a social-communication task relevant to the review objective. The abstract reports group-level task-evoked activations in putative mirror neuron regions (inferior parietal lobule and frontal operculum) and contrasts between conditions (e.g., greater IPL activation for hand gestures, greater frontal operculum activation for facial expressions), indicating whole-brain, voxelwise task results generalizable to a healthy adult group. The paper is an empirical fMRI study in a peer-reviewed journal (Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience) and thus meets the sample, task, and whole-brain reporting criteria. Note: full PDF access is limited in the provided excerpt, so specific participant ages and coordinate tables could not be visually confirmed, but the methods and reported group-level activations in the abstract support inclusion.

Meets fMRI social-task and healthy adult sample criteria, and reports voxelwise/ROI analyses with reported activation coordinates. However, the manuscript’s statistical analyses were conducted within restricted ROIs/masked regions (voxelwise ANOVAs “restricted to particular areas”) and primarily reports ROI and masked voxelwise results rather than an unmasked, whole‑brain group-level task activation map. The review requires at least one univariate whole‑brain (unmasked) group-level task map generalizable to healthy adults. Because the paper does not present such whole‑brain, unmasked healthy-group activation results, it fails the whole‑brain evidence inclusion criterion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: Task is social-related (emotional facial expression processing—social communication/perception of others). Sample includes a healthy adult group (12 healthy subjects reported). The paper reports group-level task-evoked BOLD signal increases for implicit and explicit conditions and direct contrasts between them—these are univariate whole-brain activation results (described in the abstract as increased signals in multiple brain regions), not ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. Empirical fMRI data are reported. No exclusion criteria are met. Note: ages are not explicitly stated in the abstract, but subjects are described as healthy (adult) and the study context strongly indicates an adult sample; if ages were outside 17–65 it would warrant re-evaluation, but this is unlikely.

This is an fMRI study using a social interaction simulation task probing friendship (affiliation/attachment), a construct directly relevant to social-related processing. Sample: 28 healthy right-handed adults (mean age 22.6, range 19–27), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (random-effects ANOVA and t-contrasts) with familywise error correction (p<0.05) and provides tables of significant clusters/coordinates and figures (e.g., Table 1, Figs. 3–4). It is empirical original fMRI data, not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state, and results for the healthy group are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults (N=29, ages 18–24). The task explicitly probes communicative speech/social interaction vs description (social-related processing). Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses are reported (contrasts, SPM2; tables and coordinates provided, e.g., Table 3 and figures), showing univariate task-evoked activation maps for the healthy sample. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study directly probing social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking). Participants performed trait-judgment tasks targeting self vs. other and manipulated perspective taking. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activations in medial PFC (ventral/dorsal anterior and posterior dorsal MPFC and left dorsal MPFC interaction), consistent with whole-brain univariate contrasts rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. The sample is described as participants (healthy adults implied); although the provided excerpt does not specify exact ages, the design and journal context indicate a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-empirical) apply. Recommend verifying participant ages in the full text, but available information supports inclusion for the meta-analysis of fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=26, mean age 29.4) that uses a social-related task (meaning relatedness judgments of social concepts) and reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate results (categorical contrasts and parametric regression/conjunction analyses). Whole-brain coordinates, figures, and ROI analyses are provided and results are clearly reported for the healthy control group. The design and analyses directly address social processing (abstract social semantic knowledge). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants are within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates; mean age 19.5, n=10 in Study 1, n=12 in Study 2) performing a social-cognition task (emotion judgments to images of social groups/objects). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects analyses and provides Talairach coordinates and contrast statistics for activations (mPFC, insula, amygdala), meeting the whole-brain univariate reporting requirement. Analyses are within healthy participants and not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and not limited to between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

This is an fMRI study using a social interactive reactive-aggression task (competitive reaction-time paradigm) that probes social processing (retaliation, observing opponent, empathy). Participants: healthy adult sample (n=16 male, mean age 28.6), meeting the age range 17–65. Analysis: random-effects, whole-brain SPM2 univariate voxelwise results are reported (group-level contrasts, parametric modulation, conjunctions) with activation maps and coordinate tables. The paper therefore provides group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-groups-only).

The provided full-text excerpt describes fMRI responses to visible and invisible faces (FFA, STS, amygdala) in observers, addressing social perception. However, the text does not report participant demographics or confirm that at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for a healthy adult group is presented. The results may reflect ROI-based or region-specific reporting rather than whole-brain voxelwise maps, and no healthy participant ages/sample size are given. Because the inclusion criteria require explicit whole-brain group-level task maps and confirmation of healthy adult participants (17–65), and these cannot be verified from the provided content, the study must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria. The study used task-based fMRI in healthy adults (N=11, ages 18–32). The experimental paradigm examined social cognition/perception of others (spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge from faces), addressing social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others; social cognition). The paper reports voxelwise, whole-brain, group-level random-effects analyses with reported clusters, Talairach coordinates, t-values, and contrasts (e.g., faces associated with behaviors vs novel faces; disgusting vs aggressive), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps. Results for the healthy control group are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not patient-only, and is empirical). Therefore it should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=15 after exclusion; ages 20–28). The task probes perception/understanding of self (detection of visual feedback ownership/agency), which fits the review's constructs. Group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., Aa–As, Pa–Ps) with cluster-level inference and tables of peak coordinates and figures, providing generalizable healthy-group activation maps. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65, empirical fMRI data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults: 18 right-handed, healthy male volunteers (mean age 25.9). The task manipulates social interaction/self-involvement (virtual characters’ gaze and social vs arbitrary facial movements). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate analyses (SPM2 random-effects), with tables of stereotactic coordinates and figures for multiple task contrasts (e.g., SOC>ARB, ME>OTHER) and statistical thresholds described (p=0.001 uncorrected, extent 20 voxels; ROI/FWE follow-ups). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind and empathy) in healthy adults. Participants: 13 right-handed healthy males (age range 19–36), meeting the adult sample criterion. Imaging: task-based fMRI (1.5T) with whole-brain, voxelwise, group-level random-effects analyses (SPM2). The paper reports univariate whole-brain contrasts (e.g., ‘ToM – Physical1’, ‘Empathy – Physical2’), conjunctions and interactions, with tables of peak coordinates and thresholding described. Results are reported for the healthy group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROIs or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related task fMRI study of social communication (processing of angry prosody in voices) in healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 24.4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (SPM2), with voxelwise contrasts and a table of MNI coordinates (Table 1) for multiple task contrasts (e.g., anger vs neutral, attended vs ignored). It is not restricted to ROI or connectivity-only analyses, includes healthy/control group results generalizable to adults 17–65, and provides whole-brain statistical maps/coordinates. No exclusion criteria are met (not an ROI-only, resting-state, between-group-only, or non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study uses task-based BOLD fMRI examining self-face vs. familiar/unknown faces — a social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Self). Sample: 12 healthy adult participants (right-handed males, mean age 19.36), within the 17–65 range and reported separately. Whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate analyses are reported with voxelwise contrasts and coordinate tables/figures (e.g., contrasts: unknown vs scrambled; familiar vs unknown; self vs familiar) generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and does not report only between-group contrasts. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=14, mean age 20.6, range 18.3–23.7). The task is social-related (impression formation about people versus objects). Group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts are reported (e.g., person-impression > other trial types; impression > sequencing) using SPM99 with coordinates and cluster thresholds provided. Results are univariate task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults and reported in tables/figures. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The article reports two fMRI experiments on understanding intentions in social interaction in healthy adults, addressing the review topic. However, the provided full-text content is limited (PDF behind access), and the manuscript excerpt does not explicitly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map clearly identified for the healthy/control group. Participant ages and explicit whole-brain results (tables/coordinates or figures) cannot be verified from the supplied text. Because inclusion requires documented whole-brain task activation maps for healthy adults, and that criterion cannot be confirmed with the available content, I must exclude the study. Recommend obtaining the full PDF or contact authors to verify that group-level whole-brain contrasts for healthy adult participants are reported; if confirmed, the study should be reconsidered for inclusion.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment) in healthy adults (n=19, ages within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (Guilty minus Neutral, Embarrassment minus Neutral; direct E–G and G–E contrasts) with coordinate tables and figures, satisfying whole-brain reporting. Healthy-control results are reported separately and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processes (cooperation vs. competition) in healthy adults (N=12, ages 21–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (cooperation vs independent, competition vs independent, and direct contrasts) with tables of stereotactic coordinates and statistical thresholds, enabling generalization to the healthy adult population. The methods describe whole-brain preprocessing and random-effects group analyses (SPM2) and report univariate activation maps and coordinate tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within age range, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of mutual vs. averted gaze) in healthy adult participants (young adults aged within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain univariate analyses: it describes voxel-based group-averaged t-statistic activation maps for mutual and averted gaze (displayed on a standard brain, Fig. 4) and reports thresholding parameters. Although ROI analyses are used, whole-brain task activation maps are explicitly reported. The healthy control group results are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none (note: small final N after motion exclusion but still within age/sample requirements).

Study reports original fMRI data on healthy adult participants (N=13, mean age 27.2). Task involves viewing realistic social interactions (social-related processing). Group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (ANOVA; voxelwise threshold P≤0.05 corrected; coordinates and statistical peaks provided in Table 1 and figures). Results for the healthy group are clearly described. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor between-group-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (Prisoner’s Dilemma social learning) in healthy adults. Sample: healthy adults (11 analyzed; ages 21–36), meeting the age criterion. Imaging: task-based, event-related fMRI with group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (SPM2 one-sample t tests across subjects) and reported voxelwise results and coordinate tables for a priori ROIs and whole-brain effects. The paper reports univariate, task-evoked whole-brain activation contrasts (e.g., cooperator vs neutral, intentional vs nonintentional) clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social evaluation (trustworthiness judgments of faces) in healthy adult participants (final N=14, ages 18–30). The authors report group-level, random-effects, voxelwise SPM contrasts (parametric effects of trustworthiness and task effects), provide peak coordinates and statistical maps, and describe both small-volume-corrected and whole-brain (uncorrected) activations across regions (amygdala, fusiform, STS, insula, etc.). The task is clearly social-related (perception/understanding of others). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical paper) are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers investigating social-cognitive processes (empathy and forgiveness), which falls squarely under social-related tasks (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level task-evoked activations (regions such as left superior frontal gyrus, orbitofrontal gyrus, precuneus, anterior middle temporal and inferior frontal gyri, posterior cingulate), indicating whole-brain voxelwise analyses rather than ROI-only results. A healthy adult sample (ten volunteers) is described; while exact ages are not provided in the abstract, volunteers are implied to be adults and likely within 17–65. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) appear to apply. Given some uncertainty about exact age range reporting and small sample size, confidence is moderate (0.80).

The study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants on a social perception task (racial ingroup/outgroup faces), so it meets the topic and sample criteria. However, the provided full text/abstract indicates results were presented via a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis of amygdala voxels and does not clearly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy group. The inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain task-evoked statistical map reported for the healthy adults. Because only ROI-based results are described and no unambiguous whole-brain voxelwise healthy-group map is reported in the provided content, the study does not meet the whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social interaction recognition (social-related processing) and includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8). Authors report group-level, whole-brain, univariate contrasts (SI > NM) for the adult group using SPM8 with voxelwise thresholds and cluster/FWE correction; results for adults are presented separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although the sample also includes children and adolescents, adult-group whole-brain activation maps/coordinates and between-group contrasts are reported, satisfying the inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=30, age ~24) using tasks with social-emotional stimuli (angry and happy faces) and a neutral control. It reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., faces vs. neutral; main effects and interactions) with FWE-corrected results and coordinate tables/figures, clearly derived from the healthy/control group. The sample falls within the 17–65 range and results are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and contains original task-based fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of face perception (facial color processing), which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). Sample: 25 healthy adult participants (mean age 25.24, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (natural-colored face vs natural-colored scrambled image) with voxelwise results and coordinates (Table 1; group-level maps reported at P<10^-3 uncorrected), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses are reported, whole-brain group results are also provided. No exclusion criteria are violated (no patient-only sample, no connectivity-only or resting-state only analyses, and this is an empirical fMRI study). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical whole-brain fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages 20–34) investigating anticipatory sensorimotor processes during active interpersonal touch (socially relevant task). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate contrasts (e.g., Target, Modality, Target×Modality interaction), whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables (Talairach), and cluster-corrected results; tactile localizer and conjunction analyses are included. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical task-fMRI study of social-related processing (reflected and direct self-evaluations, social domain). It includes a healthy adult group (N=19, ages 22–31) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, voxel-wise task-evoked analyses (a 2×4×3 whole-brain repeated-measures ANOVA and follow-up whole-brain contrasts), uses cluster correction (AlphaSim), and describes adult-group results (with separate adult/adolescent comparisons and supplementary materials). Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain univariate task activation maps in healthy adults.

Although this is a task-based fMRI study of natural interpersonal touch in healthy adults (N=8, ages 22–39) and addresses social aspects, the paper does not report a group-level univariate whole-brain task activation map (GLM-style voxelwise contrast). The analyses are based on group ICA (component spatial maps and component time courses) and event-related averages of ICA timecourses. According to the review criteria, studies that report only ICA/other multivariate connectivity-type results without a whole-brain task activation map must be excluded.

This fMRI study uses a social task (multiround Ultimatum Game) probing social decision-making, fitting the review’s construct scope. It includes a healthy adult group (n=15; ages 19–28) analyzed and reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., unfair > fair offers) using SPM8, with one-sample t-tests and full-factorial second-level analyses; results are presented as thresholded statistical maps, tables of coordinates, figures, and ROI extractions. The analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Adult-group whole-brain effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults (within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing: participants judged ambiguous social interactions (social coordination), a clearly social-cognitive task. Sample: 20 healthy adult participants (age range 23–39), meeting the 17–65 criterion. Neuroimaging: whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate analyses are reported (ANOVA and post hoc t-contrasts) with FDR-corrected maps and tables of peak coordinates (reported in Tables 1–4 and Figures), i.e., voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked results from the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study used task-based fMRI of face perception (faces vs diverse objects), which falls under social perception/understanding of others. The sample includes healthy adult participants (ages 18–37) alongside children/adolescents. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task contrasts (faces>objects) and provides whole-brain results and coordinate tables (e.g., Table 3, Fig. 5) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only outcomes. Thus it supplies whole-brain, task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults and meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

The study is an empirical fMRI investigation of social perception (passive viewing of point-light biological motion), includes a healthy adult sample (n=48; ages 20–35), and reports group-level, whole-brain voxel-wise task contrasts (biological > scrambled) and Sex×Condition ANOVA results for adults with tables/coordinates and figures. Thus it meets: fMRI social-related task, healthy adult group within age range, and whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages 19–42). Task probes social-related processing (perception/categorization of others’ gender). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxel-wise random-effects analyses (contrast gender-different > gender-same) with cluster-corrected thresholds, figures, and Talairach coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable within the adult range (17–65). Not limited to ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria (no resting-state/connectivity-only, not only between-group contrasts, participants within age range). Therefore include.

This is a task-based BOLD fMRI study of social perception (affiliation vs. isolation) in healthy adults. It includes a younger adult group (N=16; mean age 20.75 years, within the 17–65 range) and reports whole-brain, voxelwise, group-level statistical analyses (random-effects contrasts, tables of peak coordinates and thresholds) for the healthy groups, including within-group and between-group contrasts. Results are reported in standard coordinate tables and conjunction/contrast analyses for younger adults, satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. Although an older group (mean age 70.3) is present, the younger healthy subgroup is analyzed and reported separately, so the age-range criterion is met. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 22) that investigates processing of communicative vs noncommunicative vocal signals (social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (vocal > nonvocal and communicative > noncommunicative) with corrected thresholds and peak coordinates for STS/STG clusters, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses and results for the healthy adult sample are reported separately. The task is squarely within social-related processing (Social Communication). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult-only sample, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of affective (social) touch, reporting whole-brain, group-level random-effects analyses for a healthy adult group (n=22; ages 19–35). The task targets affective-motivational/social processing (CT-targeted arm stroking) and reports adult whole-brain contrasts (Arm>Rest, Palm>Rest) with corrected thresholds and tables/figures showing activations in social brain regions (pSTS/MTG, insula, prefrontal cortex). All inclusion criteria are met: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult group within 17–65 reported separately, (3) whole-brain, voxelwise group results for the healthy adults are presented. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, and adults are within the age range). Therefore the study should be included.

This study reports an fMRI experiment on self-face recognition, which qualifies as social-related processing (Perception/Understanding of Self). Participants were healthy adults (16 analyzed; ages 19–24). The paper includes group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM2) with reported cluster-level corrected results and coordinates (e.g., MPFC, PCC, precuneus) and clear statistical thresholds, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy group are reported. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, non-healthy sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study investigating social communication (perception of eye gaze) in healthy adults (N=9, mean age 24). The tasks are social (attention to gaze and identity; passive viewing of direct vs averted gaze). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate activation results (face vs control contrast; clusters identified with z>4 and stereotaxic coordinates in Table 1) and region-wise percent signal-change analyses derived from those whole-brain-defined regions. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The provided full text contains only the references section and bibliographic metadata; no methods, participant details, analyses, or results are reported. I cannot confirm that the study used fMRI with a healthy adult sample (age 17–65), nor can I verify that it reports at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Because key inclusion criteria (clear healthy adult sample and whole-brain task activation results) cannot be verified from the supplied content, the study must be excluded.

The provided full-text content consists only of the references section and bibliographic metadata; no methods, participant information, task description, or results are available. Therefore it is impossible to verify key inclusion criteria: whether the study tested healthy adult participants (age 17–65), whether it used fMRI during a social-related task, and whether it reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group. Title suggests social interaction and fMRI but that alone is insufficient. Because at least one required inclusion criterion cannot be confirmed from the provided full text, the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (causal attributions, self vs other, self-serving bias) in healthy adults (12 right-handed males, ages 20–51). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM99) with voxel-level correction and tables of peak coordinates and figures of statistical maps (internal vs external attributions; self-serving vs non-self-serving contrasts). Healthy-group results are reported directly and are interpretable for the general healthy adult population (though sample is small and analyses are primarily fixed-effects; the authors also report follow-up random-effects ROI tests). The study does not fall under exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, not non-empirical, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition, a social-cognitive task (Perception and Understanding of Self). The sample comprises 10 healthy adult participants (mean age 26.9, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (self>other; other>self) with cluster-corrected statistical maps and tables of MNI coordinates, and details of preprocessing and GLM analysis. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (facial emotion recognition vs age discrimination) in healthy adults (N=29; ages within 20–35 and 23–33). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (FWE-corrected maps and tables of MNI coordinates) for explicit and implicit contrasts and their comparison, with results clearly identified for the healthy/control sample. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and the reported contrasts are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants using a task that probes perception/understanding of self vs. others (own vs. others' body parts/hands), a social-related construct. Participants are healthy adults (two experiments, n=12 and n=15; no indication that ages fall outside 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task contrasts used to localize regions (body minus objects localizer; objects minus body parts for LOC; coordinates and voxel counts are provided and a Talairach peak table is reported), not solely ROI-only analyses. Whole-brain task-evoked statistical contrasts and coordinates are described, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only connectivity/ROI or non-healthy samples) apply. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20, ages 20–34) using an action-observation task probing the mirror system, which the authors frame as relevant to social cognition and perception/understanding of others. Group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (conjunctions and contrasts thresholded at P<0.05 corrected; peak coordinates provided in Table 1), and results for the healthy/control groups are presented separately (Compatible control group used to define mirror areas). The paper reports univariate, task-evoked whole-brain statistical maps (and coordinates), not only ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (fMRI during social-related task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level results).

This is an empirical fMRI study of self-related processing (perception/understanding of self), a social-related construct. Sample: 24 healthy adult participants (ages ~21–24), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses and multiple whole-brain contrasts (e.g., main effects and interaction contrasts) with tables of coordinates and figures (Tables II–V, whole-brain regression, and interaction maps), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not ROI-only (although ROI analyses are additionally reported) and not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study meets inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during an explicit emotion-recognition task (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others), includes a healthy adult sample (21 male participants, ages 21–33 within 17–65), and reports group-level, voxelwise whole-slab (univariate) task activation results with statistical maps and coordinate tables identified for the healthy group (e.g., whole-slab analyses and reported MNI coordinates for effects such as parahippocampal and inferior frontal gyrus, and activation maps including the amygdala). Although coverage was restricted to an amygdala-optimized slab rather than whole-head acquisition, the paper reports group-level voxelwise contrasts (not ROI-only) generalizable to healthy adults. It does not fall under exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it should be included.

While this is an fMRI study of social communication in a healthy adult sample (n=24, ages 18–41) using task-evoked contrasts (audiovisual emotional, voice, face), the reported statistical analyses are based on an anatomist-guided region-of-interest approach along the superior temporal sulcus (parameter estimates extracted from 6 mm spheres at measuring points) rather than group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate maps. The paper reports MP-based T-tests and averaged ROI contrast estimates, and does not present an unmasked whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group activation map (or whole-brain coordinate table from a voxelwise analysis) that is generalizable to healthy adults. Because the review requires at least one group-level whole-brain task activation map from the healthy group, this study fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This study reports task-based fMRI of self-related and reflected self-appraisals (social-cognitive processing: Perception and Understanding of Self) including a healthy adult group (N=12, ages 23–30). Group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses and contrasts (e.g., conjunctions You/Mom/Best/Class vs rest; reflected vs direct appraisals; age-group comparisons) are reported and thresholded with corrections across the whole brain; results for the adult group are described separately. The study therefore meets: (1) use of fMRI during a social-related task, (2) inclusion of a healthy adult sample with reported results, and (3) provision of whole-brain group-level task activation maps/contrasts. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply. Thus it should be included in the meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19, ages 18–58) examining perception and production of prosody and its relationship to empathy — fitting social communication and perception of others. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., “happy–neutral”, “question–neutral”) with SPM2 analyses, thresholding (p<0.05 FDR; cluster k>5), SVC/FWE results, and coordinates/brain maps described in text and figures. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (social expectancy violations along warmth and competence). Sample consists of healthy adults (12 analyzed; mean age 20.4, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses with Talairach coordinates and tables/figures (whole-brain contrasts and ROIs derived from those contrasts). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes healthy-group whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (clinical-only sample, age outside range, methods-only) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (integration of facial emotion and eye-gaze) using an explicit emotion-recognition task—clearly within social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy younger adult group (17–27) within the 17–65 inclusion range, and results are reported separately for age groups. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task analyses (partial least squares-derived voxelwise spatial maps with peak coordinates and cluster tables) rather than ROI-only or resting-state analyses. Group-level healthy-adult activation patterns and coordinates are provided in the main text/tables/figures, and brain–behavior task effects are reported for the healthy groups. Although the analysis method is multivariate PLS rather than a classical univariate GLM, it yields whole-brain voxelwise salience maps and reported coordinates, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results for healthy adults.

The study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=15 final; mean age 24.8) and explicitly investigates face individuation, which maps onto ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (a social-related processing construct). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses of the individuation task (voxelwise ANOVA, cluster-threshold correction, reported contrasts, tables/figures of activation maps), not ROI-only results. Healthy-group results are clearly reported and generalizable to typical adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain task-evoked group maps) and does not violate exclusion criteria.

While the study uses task-based fMRI of social processing (empathy/sympathy) and reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results, the sample is a mixed developmental cohort (ages 7–40) and analyses are reported across the entire combined sample or as age-correlations. The paper does not present a separate group-level whole-brain task activation map or univariate contrast restricted to a healthy adult subgroup (age 17–65) that is generalizable to adults. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one healthy adult group (17–65) with its own whole-brain task effect reported separately, this study does not meet all inclusion criteria and must be excluded.
