This is an fMRI study of negative social feedback (a social-related task) in healthy adult participants (N=21 males, ages 21–39), fulfilling the sample criterion (healthy adults within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (second-level random-effects contrasts and whole-brain correction; tables and figures present activation foci and coordinates for negative social feedback>positive social feedback under placebo), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The design and results are not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts; healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of emotion perception from body movement (gait), a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Participants: healthy adults (N=19 total; analyses report N=17, ages within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects GLMs and voxelwise contrasts such as perceived emotional > perceived neutral, parametric GLM for intensity), with corrected multi-subject activation maps projected on Talairach-normalized brains. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain results are explicitly reported and generalizable to the healthy adult group. The study is empirical, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and provides the necessary healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (eye-gaze perception/inferring others’ attention/intentions). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=18; ages 18–30), satisfying the age and healthy-group requirements. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (second-level GLMs with AQ as a regressor) and lists significant clusters and coordinates (whole-brain FDR-corrected results and tables/coordinates), providing generalizable healthy-group task-evoked effects. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports task-evoked fMRI data in healthy adult participants (n=21 for the imaging experiment) performing repeated retrieval of real-life social interactions (oral examination with an actor), which qualifies as social-related processing (perception/understanding of self/others in a social context). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8), reporting activations across hippocampus, retrosplenial cortex, medial prefrontal cortex, etc., with corrected statistics (tables and figures referenced), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants were healthy adults within the target age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and includes whole-brain task activation maps; thus no exclusion criteria are triggered. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI during an emotional face perception task (social perception of anger and fear), satisfying the social-related task requirement. Participants are described as healthy adults (no clinical group emphasized) and the paper reports group-level voxelwise task-evoked neural activity in canonical face/emotion regions (amygdala, fusiform, insula). Methods cite whole-brain group analysis procedures (FSL, multilevel linear modeling), indicating univariate whole-brain task effects were tested and reported. Although the paper also reports functional coupling (PPI), this does not preclude inclusion because clear whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are provided. Minor residual uncertainty remains about explicit age-range reporting in the excerpt, but the sample is consistent with healthy adult participants. Therefore the article meets inclusion criteria.

Although this study uses task-based fMRI with whole-brain voxelwise analyses of a social cognition task (the Eyes task) and reports control-group activations, the sample consists of adolescents aged 12–18 (mean adolescent sample) rather than healthy adults. The inclusion criterion requires at least one group of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) reported separately or as a distinct subgroup generalizable to healthy adults. The paper does not provide a separate adult healthy subgroup or age-restricted analysis for participants ≥17 years that would meet the adult-sample requirement. Therefore it fails the sample-age criterion and must be excluded from the meta-analysis despite meeting other methodological criteria.

While the study includes healthy adult participants (n=27) and a task-based fMRI facial expression discrimination task, the paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Reported task results are presented as a between-group contrast (patients > controls) showing amygdala hyperactivation in patients; no standalone healthy-group voxelwise task map or coordinates for a healthy-group main effect are provided. The paper’s primary whole-brain results are seed-based resting-state and connectivity analyses and between-group contrasts, which fall under the exclusion criteria. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain univariate task activation map.

The study used task-based fMRI with a social-related paradigm (imaginary sentence completion about ‘My mother’/‘My father’), addressing social/attachment and social communication constructs. It included a healthy adult control group (n=15) and performed voxel-wise one-sample t tests for each group, reporting whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for the healthy controls (e.g., precuneus activation) with cluster FDR correction. Whole-brain between-group contrasts are also reported, but crucially unmasked within-group healthy-control whole-brain results are present. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (task fMRI social processing; healthy adult group; whole-brain univariate healthy-group maps).

Although this fMRI study uses a social cognition task (implicit fearful vs neutral face processing) and includes a healthy control group aged within the target range, the paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. The primary reported results are seed-based PPI effective connectivity and between-group connectivity differences (patients vs controls). The manuscript does not present an unmasked, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (or coordinate table) attributable to the healthy group alone; activations are referenced to a prior publication (Hall et al., 2008). Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation and meets the exclusion criterion for reporting only seed-based/effective connectivity without accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task maps.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (nulliparous women aged 19–29) performing social-related tasks (perception of infant cries and faces — social/affiliative and perception/understanding of others). Group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts are reported (e.g., cry vs pink noise; happy vs neutral faces) with whole-brain corrected thresholds and cluster reporting; results are presented as statistical maps, coordinates, and figures. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range, and analyses report healthy-group whole-brain activation effects generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task involves social-related processing (supraliminal fearful face processing—perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy adult control group (n=25, ages within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses for the control group (Supplementary Fig. S1 and Supplementary Table 1 describe whole-brain clusters using FLAME), not only ROI or connectivity results. Not excluded by any listed criteria. Therefore eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social action planning (pantomime gestures), which falls under social communication/perception constructs. It includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (n=25) matched to patients. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task analyses (within-group contrasts and random-effects second-level results) for controls (figures/tables and supplementary material), with voxelwise thresholds and cluster reporting. The study is not limited to ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (TD) and uses task-based fMRI of social processes (self/other evaluation), the paper does not report an unambiguous, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. Reported whole-brain contrasts are either between-group (ASD vs TD) or combined-group (ASD+TD) maps; functional connectivity results and ROI analyses are provided for TD vs ASD but no standalone TD whole-brain activation map or coordinate table for the healthy group is clearly presented. Because the inclusion criterion requires at least one healthy-group whole-brain univariate task activation map (or equivalent coordinates/figures clearly labeled as healthy-group results), this study does not satisfy the whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

While the study uses whole-brain fMRI during a social (cognitive empathy/emotional perspective-taking) task and includes a healthy adult control group (ages within 17–65), the paper reports only between-group (schizophrenia vs control) differential activation results. There is no unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map or contrast clearly reported as coming from the healthy/control group alone (the imaging analyses focus on between-group differences and clusters derived from those contrasts). Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded. Therefore this study does not meet the ‘Whole-brain evidence’ inclusion requirement.

This study reports task-based fMRI of self-referential processing and perspective-taking (social-related constructs: perception/understanding of self and others) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=28; mean age 21.6, within 17–65 range). The paper provides whole-brain, univariate, voxelwise task contrasts for the healthy control group (within-group contrasts and group comparisons; cluster tables and figures are reported), not only ROI or connectivity analyses. Although a clinical UHR group is also included, healthy-group whole-brain effects are reported separately and clearly. Imaging methods and thresholding for voxelwise maps are described. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While the study uses fMRI during a social-related task (implicit emotional face perception) and includes an age-appropriate healthy control group (n=19), the full text reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked maps and tables primarily for Tourette patients and reports between-group contrasts (patients vs. controls). The paper does not present a clearly identified, unmasked whole-brain within-group activation map (healthy/control main effect or emotions vs. baseline) that is generalizable to healthy adults; the reported control findings appear only as between-group contrasts (control>patient) rather than an independent healthy-group statistical map. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

This fMRI study includes a healthy control group of adults (n=13, mean age 25.6) and reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts for the control group (e.g., all faces vs scrambled; linear contrasts of fear intensity) with peak coordinates presented in Tables 1–2 and figures. The task is social (fearful face processing). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of facial emotion discrimination (social processing of others) including a healthy adult control group (n=12, mean age 24.5). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (within-group contrasts and maps for controls are presented and discussed, e.g., sad > neutral and other emotion > baseline contrasts illustrated for control subjects), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range. The study is empirical and reports whole-brain statistical maps/contrasts for the healthy/control group, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using an explicit facial emotion identification task (social perception of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, ages within 17–65) with results for the healthy group reported separately. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain ‘faces minus animals’ contrasts for the healthy controls (one-sample t tests) with FDR-corrected, whole-brain thresholds, activation maps, and coordinate tables/figures. The study therefore provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for healthy adults during a social-related task, satisfying all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are met.

The paper reports an fMRI experiment in a healthy adult group performing a social task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test; mentalising about others). It provides group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (mind > age contrast; random-effects one-sample t-test, cluster- and FWE-corrected maps, with coordinates and figures). A healthy control group is reported (n=20). Although the control sample includes older adults (age range 51–84), it is not exclusively outside the 17–65 window and a whole-brain healthy-group activation map is clearly reported. The study therefore meets the review’s requirements for fMRI during social processing with whole-brain healthy-group results, so it should be included (note caveat regarding older mean age).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (theory-of-mind/mentalising). The sample consists of 109 healthy adult volunteers (healthy group reported separately). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (ToM > control) with family-wise error and FDR-corrected voxelwise results, presented in figures/tables and described in the text. Results are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to an ROI-only or connectivity-only analysis. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task fMRI with healthy control participants (ages within 17–65) and examines social/emotional face processing, the full text does not clearly report an univariate, whole-brain group-level task activation map explicitly for the healthy/control group. The reported imaging results focus on psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity and group differences (PMGC vs controls), with activations described across all participants or relegated to supplementary material without a clearly identified, unmasked healthy-group whole-brain contrast generalizable to healthy adults. Because the review requires a clearly identified whole‑brain task-evoked map for the healthy/control group (not only ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrasts), this paper does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses task fMRI (viewing happy and fearful faces) in healthy young adults, the reported fMRI results are ROI-based interregional correlation (averaged 25×25 ROI matrices) and group-level correlations; no univariate, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (e.g., within-group activation maps or tables of coordinates) for the healthy/control group are presented. The main functional outcomes are ROI covariance and structural covariance analyses rather than whole-brain GLM activation results. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group-level whole-brain voxelwise task activation map. All other sample and task criteria are met, but lack of whole-brain univariate results mandates exclusion.

While this is an fMRI hyperscanning study of a social task and includes a healthy adult group (80 HCs aged within range), it does not provide a clear group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The primary reported results are cross-brain coupling measures derived from ICA and pairwise correlations (connectivity-like metrics) and between-group comparisons; although INT>NoINT contrasts were computed for group comparisons, the manuscript does not present an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group activation map or coordinate table clearly identified as a HC within-group effect. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain, univariate task activation map from the healthy group (not only connectivity/ICA or between-group contrasts), this study does not meet all inclusion criteria.

This fMRI study uses a social cognition task (modified Sally–Anne false-belief/social-emotion task) and includes a healthy control group of adults (n=17, ages 20–44). Group-level whole-brain analyses were performed (one-sample t‑tests at the second level) and voxelwise results are reported (whole-brain thresholds and MNI coordinates are provided), with contrasts of interest described for social-minus-belief and belief-minus-control. Although between-group contrasts are emphasized, the paper explicitly describes and implements whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses for the typically developing (healthy) group and reports voxelwise coordinate results; thus it meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain task activation mapping in a social-related paradigm.

execution_stats.search_query: ( ('functional MRI'[Title/Abstract] OR 'functional magnetic resonance imaging'[Title/Abstract] OR 'fMRI'[Title/Abstract] ) AND ( 'social communication'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social processing'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social interaction'[Title/Abstract] OR 'affiliation'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social attachment'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social cognition'[Title/Abstract] OR 'understanding others'[Title/Abstract] ) AND 'Humans'[MeSH])
